After 14 hours of gameplay you begin to notice that the game wants you to play multiple runs even if you sink 6 or 7 hours into a run. There are also ways of soft locking yourself on a desert island or even only having one party member alive because reviving party members cost lives which can only be acquired in special ways. I think the devs think you should be having fun getting punished by these mechanics but when 1 random encounter can brink your entire run you know you would rather play something else.

Honestly, one of the best games I've played. You have to constantly think about strategy and the game scales in difficulty quick enough that you have to be constantly making progress, unless you want to risk defeat, but not so quick that you feel you have no chance. A common example of this (at least for me) is doing a dungeon one level above the groups' level which normally includes a boss 2 levels above the group, although normally at lease one member of the group will have levelled up in the dungeon.

Overall perfectly balanced game full of excitement, anticipation and a sense of urgency.

I absolutely cannot recommend this game (or its sequel whatsoever).

The sad truth about this company is that they leave everything in a half-finished (or worse) state. The console versions of the first game never, ever got any updates. They still have day 1 bugs which were never addressed. In addition to that, the console versions also never got any of the DLC even. Not a single one. They simply just don't care about maintaining their games. They seem to be a studio that just rush to production and ship the game without any long-term maintenance or roadmap whatsoever. You can see this by the current state of the Steam release for the second game too.

P.S. I obviously realise console is different to Steam but it's a clear example that they have no intention of supporting development and fixes with their titles. You simply cannot trust these days. However, if you are okay paying full price for Abandonware then go for it.

You should be able to open all the characters inventories at the same time, and drag / drop items between them.  It's also annoying that every time you use, sell or move an item the items list scrolls back to the top so you're constantly having to repeatedly scroll back down.

The game is MOSTLY fun. The problem is that the campaigns are really only possible if you know EXACTLY what will happen next. All of your supplies must be ready for the next part of the quest line. There is no general thought (oh i should stock up on health and poison curing herbs); you need the specific items are the specific time.

For instance, at one point you will need fight some elemental enemies. You have the opportunity to swap gear and weapons before you enter, but if you've never been to the area before YOU WOULD HAVE NO IDEA WHAT GEAR TO USE. You can not switch armor mid fight, switching weapons wastes a turn. If you walk into the Shock Elemental Guys battle with 0 shock protection and a character with a shock weapon (like i did) then you are screwed. You will take 9000 damage.  Better yet, you will get hit with a "shock effect". While active this effect prevents you from 100% your attack roll, which essentially means you will never land your attack since the enemies dodge attacks like muhammed ali.

The fact the dev's say "you will likely not win on your first try" is their half ass lazy excuse for poor game design. You must memorize the game, memorize each encounter, know what every single enemy attack is and when they are likely to use it. Otherwise you will waste resources and that snowballs into an inevitable loss.

The game was made for the sweatiest of sweats, if you're a casual stay AS FAR AWAY AS POSSIBLE.

Overall 8/10. Simple numbers and linear game play mechanic. Not too grindy, no innovation skill needed, somewhat critical thinking involved, not lore intensive nor theory-crafting intensive, and not time consuming from start to finish. Same goes obtaining achievements. Achievements were a great time to explore the edges of what this game has to offer. Great game to play with friend(s) and the art is pleasant from friendly to gore-like pixels. Downsides would be camera mobility being user control limited which interfere with gameplay from clicking, snapping back, and motion sickness (mimic bouncing, fighting on boat, etc.). Also white screen illuminating to max whenever an event completion takes place (very disturbing in dark environment) was annoying. Lastly, random disconnects were a hassle and I had an incident where my file was no longer visible to play due to corruption so my friend and I ended up having to play all over again.

I would still recommend it for others to try out especially if you're a beginner in turn base combat type of games. Make sure to look into the horizon when fighting on a boat while waiting for your friend's turn or enemy's turn, reminder to yourself and your friend(s) to look down/away or close your eyes whenever the white light starts to blare at your screen upon completing an event, and hang in there when fighting mimics! Also, file gets deleted when your entire party wipes so get clever about it! :)

Grossly imbalanced, generic and boring. The game tries to pose itself as difficult to make it feel more adventurous but after a bit of playtime you realize it's because the devs didn't care to adjust scaling or anything at all, really. Campaigns are rushed, the game doesn't show you how much debuffs penalize stats, the end-game meta always ends up saving up teleport scrolls, buying out all shops and prolonging the game as much as you can since the final boss of any of the campaigns are only beatable if either you're incredibly lucky at the same level or grind out way past the recommended turn count until you can eventually fight the boss on fair terms. Certain items have mislabelled properties, random mobs often end up stronger than the final boss, the "lore" store unlocks every best item in every category and the story's blandness tries to deflect how uninteresting it is by filling it with dry humorless jokes. 

Anyways, it's pretty fun the first couple times around and it serves as practice for cooperation and communication with a friend than actually having fun past a point. Flat 6/10, I feel like it'd be worth it for like 10 bucks. Not 20.

Also I forgot to mention it crashed at least 10 times since I first started playing.

Lovely Dungeon Crawler that is perfect for a somewhat relaxed evening. The turn based mechanism gives you plenty of time to think about your strategy. I enjoyed the Online Coop a lot, but it was also fun to replay campaigns on higher difficulties. 
There are some interface issues (e.g. misclicks are brutal and costly, you cannot acces inventory to see the stats in some situations) and it happened a few times, that enemies just pull off purely unfair moves which you can absolutely not anticipate or prepare for. That can be annoying, I pulled the Alt+F4 trick a few times in these situations as they destroyed a game you meticulously built up.

I think I'm missing a lot of the intricacies - I've only been playing for a few hours, and I thought I was cruising along but then suddenly everyone was dead. (!!) Fun to play and I'm looking forward to figuring out what happened there...

I love love LOVE this game so much, it's super addicting. A genuine pleasure to play, especially in co-op. 

BUT

Please, devs, if you're reading this, can you address the increasingly widespread 'unable to proceed past the Understood screen' bug that literally prevents people from playing the game they paid money for? None of the fixes in that 2 year old guide work for people now, and a game of this calibre (that is still being sold...) deserves an up-to-date solution.

I have the Mac version, and it used to work *perfectly*; smooth as butter, no issues at all. And now I literally can't even get to the main menu. I have tried every possible solution suggested by the darkest depths of Reddit, and never can I bypass that infuRIATING PURPLE BUTTON. So, in order actually play FTK, I have to use Crossover to simulate a Windows environment, rather than via the OS my copy was optimised for. :') 

I understand that the devs are prioritising FTK 2 now, but this game is barely 6 years old and has a large and active playerbase. I just think discontinuing support for FTK is kinda lame IMO, especially as it is literally a game-breaking issue. It doesn't even look like the devs have visited the Technical Support forum since 2021....

Please patch it, or suggest another workaround, because this game is like crack to me and I would like to play it the way it was intended to be played on a Mac. <3

A slow paced, extremely relaxing game. It can be as casual, or as punishing as you like. Multiple different campaigns, with multiple different classes. You can only take 3 characters with you, so it has tons of replayability. It has quite a bit of depth in strategy, with status effects, armor, and magic barriers ontop of health. There are tons of enemy archetypes as well as some boss battles. 

You move across a map in hex grid movements. Air travel, ship travel, different terrain types. 

It can be played by up to 3 player coop, if youre into that sort of thing.

A great addition for fans of Turn Based games

---UPDATE---
Ive had this game for years, and have come back to it multiple times, and always end up quitting in frustration.. Like XCom, it relies heavily on hit chances, and this wouldnt be all that bad, it it werent for some of the masochistic designs.. Poison for example, lasts until you use a specific herb. This herb, like any other goods/service, is constantly increasing in price. Its ALWAYS expensive, no matter how far along you get.  Youre ALWAYS fighting enemies at, or above your level, and are playing a carrot on a stick, thats always stacked against you. It went from being cute and relaxing, to frustrating, and tedious. I havent even beaten the BASE campaign, to even bother with any additional ones.. Yet, Ive got nearly half of the Lore books unlocked!

Your damage and abilities are SOLELY dependant upon which weapon you have equipped, and for some, you may not find an update for many levels.. My most recent attempt, my Lumberjack never got a new weapon, and I gave up at lvl 5...

So, no... I would NOT recommend the game. i hate when I feel unable to complete a game, and this is one of a few that Ive quit out of frustrating design. I never beat Darkest Dungeon either, despite really liking that one.

One great thing about growing old is having the fortitude to admit defeat. And I can admit with a smile, this game busted me. I played probably 12 hours straight and being this is a roguelike RPG, I was forced to start over four times. The last time my party arduously achieved level 6 and were horrendously wiped out in an ambush consisting of gank level characters. Emitting a sigh of disgust (and defeat) I hit the uninstall button. 

Starting life as a Kickstarter project, this game exudes attention to detail and an obvious love from its creators. The artstyle is reminiscent of something that looks like the lovechild of Minecraft and a Pixar animated film. The characters reminded me of old Fisher-Price figures stolen from a child's playset. Seeing these characters getting blown to pieces by blunderbusses or perforated with arrows due to the game's rag doll physics were comical. Being from a country that embellishes television comedies with laugh tracks, I never had much appreciation for the genre, but this game made me laugh numerous times. Behind the scenes, however, we have a genuine dungeon crawler with campaigns of various degrees of difficulty. The quests were compelling and reminded me of the tabletop DnD sessions I enjoyed in my youth.  

I feel almost hoodwinked with how easy it was to lose hours to this game and ultimately realize it defeated me. I like difficult games, but the deaths in this game just didn't feel fair. Barely surviving a dungeon and going back to town to heal up, and then getting ambushed by a trio of cursed witches or werebears at full health just felt contrived. (To its testament as a roguelike, one cannot save in the game.) Admittedly, my lack of prowess with this game (and enjoyment of it) could be ascribed to how I was playing it. The designers made it to be a multi player game, and I've read the game is easier played with other people, but there are some games I just prefer to play alone.  I wish I could have finished this delightful little gem of a game.

You play super defensively, build up your party, and then get completely decimated by a monster below your level, and you have to start all over again. After the 5th or 6th time this happens, it stops being fun.

I like the mechanics and the idea is sound, but having to start over from scratch every single time gets very old, very quickly. Either you play so slowly that you never actually get to experience the game, or you get wrecked by a monster that apparently has the ability to destroy all your progress without warning. It's just not enjoyable.

I haven't enjoyed a turn based fighter this much since Pokemon! Honestly I love the style, graphics, design, gameplay, customization, replayablitity, etc. That sort of DnD vibe, but their version so not as heavily relied on imagination but still creates endless unique and actually challenging adventures with at first seemingly impossible difficulties but options to change them to learn and improve. Plus with it being co-op I don't have to set up a night where maybe friends and I can regularly get together for DnD with a DM but instead hop an and try to beat each campaign with a different strategy whenever we please. Not arguing that FTK is better than DnD by any means, they're two amazing different beasts but FTK allows me to sort of scratch that DnD itch. Having a job with a full schedule makes it rough to even enjoy your off time let alone set up a campaign but at least i can come home with some cold ones and hop on FTK with the Boys anytime!

A typical RPG to avoid.
It abuses of the random where every single hit may take up to 5 throw to succeed. Even moving on the map rely on rolling the dice, making every game very random and hard to plan any strategy...even at the easiest difficulty.
I finished the game a few times but only by abusing the ALT+F4 functionality allowing me to replay the previous turn (the only way). Which is absolutely necessary (even at the easiest difficulty, I repeat) to go forward in the game since a single fail of your throw is extremely punitive and may kill one of your character. When I say abuse of the ALT+F4 it means (in average) 2 to 3 times every turn, from 10 times a single turn in dungeons...

The game as a good potential but the options should allow us to play at a playable difficulty and without relying too much on luck. Not to say that a reroll functionality would be more than welcome.

[h1]Review of For The King[/h1]

[h2]Introduction[/h2]
[i]For The King[/i] is a strategic blend of strategy, JRPG elements, and roguelike mechanics, offering both solo and cooperative gameplay experiences. It marries well-thought-out strategic planning with the unpredictability of procedural generation to ensure every playthrough is fresh and challenging.

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
[b]For The King[/b] requires the player to make crucial decisions, from combat strategy to choosing your journey's path. Each action could lead to glorious success or catastrophic failure, especially given that death in the game is permanent, forcing a complete restart of the adventure.

[h3]Combat System[/h3]
The combat system combines classic turn-based mechanics with special dice rolls adding a layer of chance and strategy to each encounter.

[spoiler][i]Tip: Utilize the environment and characters' special abilities to gain an upper hand in battle.[/i][/spoiler]

[h2]Graphics and Sound[/h2]
The stylized graphics and an immersive soundtrack create an unforgettable medieval fantasy atmosphere in [i]For The King[/i]. The game looks beautiful, and each level is infused with a sense of adventure.

[h2]Multiplayer Experience[/h2]
[u]One of the game's standout features[/u] is the cooperative play. Teaming up and strategically interacting with friends adds a special appeal to [i]For The King[/i].

[h2]Conclusion[/h2]
[b]For The King[/b] is a challenging treat for tactical game enthusiasts, rewarding intellectual planning and the ability to adapt to evolving scenarios. It is a game that invites multiple playthroughs, each time offering new surprises.

This review is a compilation of my insights on [i]For The King[/i] and is intended as a starting point for those considering purchasing the game. I hope it proves useful in making your decision.

This game is excellent! Far superior to the sequel!

This is an interesting combination of an RPG and a board game with very well thought-out mechanics. There is a lot of content. Lots of classes, enemies, equipment, encounters, etc. I don't know if I would enjoy this alone, but playing with a friend is great and requires close cooperation. Every turn is a debate on how to best spend your resources. THIS IS NOT A RELAXING GAME (unless you are playing on the easiest difficulty).

My first impression is that this is pretty cool, but probably not the most fun playing alone. It would be better with friends/other people not because it would be easier but because the failures would be more fun together.

It feels like playing a board game complete with having to move the characters individually across the board. Its a small thing, i know, but after two hours it started to really annoy me. If i'm playing alone, why not just let me move them together as a group? If characters have different distances they can move, then let me move them together at the distance of the lowest character then. It's just a weird piece to manage playing alone.

I will come back to it. My initial experience has left me with a fairly mixed impression but certainly not negative. I think the solo player experience is for a very certain kind of player that might not be most people. I think it's worth checking out though, especially if you have people to play it with.

Such a fun game! Definitely can be more fun with others, but the story is straight forward and allows you to get right into the action.

Overall, each scenario has it's own challenges, and creating different team setups is fun. Though I found myself realizing that speed trumps everything because it's better to hit first and kill an enemy then worry about healing. Also making it so that enemies can't act or you "rush" your own party to act before others seems to be a bit cheesy, but extremely effective. However, doing that takes away a lot of the risk and challenge.

In either case, I found myself playing multiple scenarios and multiple sessions just to unlock more things with my lore points. It made the replay ability of the game that much more interesting. Great job, and well worth the $5 I got it for while on sale (which included all the extra dlcs).

All of the below happened on 0 chaos journeyman difficulty with all gold going to 10-20% bonus char.
This game literally works against you 24hrs 10 days a week. The ailments/debuffs are super fucking cancer. You're against the imp that can only be hit with perfect rolls? fuck you take this aoe shock effect that lasts 2 turns that ALWAYS fails 1 die roll making it impossible to kill the imp. Damage over time like burn/poison works on turn ends and in a game where the best offense is the best defense, it just results in you taking tons of unavoidable damage if you try to outpace the enemy. You're against a 80 health enemy? fuck you take this enemy caster's buff that just added 15 resistances on top of their base 15 armor while you deal 20 damage max at that level. Losing a single turn is the equivalent of losing the entire party, that turn could've killed an enemy before they used a 5 die aoe attack to deal 70% of the middle guy's health and 20% to the other 2. That or they will just use a regular single target attack and just finish off a teammate. Enemy dice rolls are straight up rigged too, I've seen them roll more perfect dices than any other combination while my characters could all attack and either roll too low to go through their armor/resistance or they will just dodge.

If the enemy has an aoe attack and its possible for them to inflict a status effect, it's guaranteed 3 of your members will be hit with it. Scared, Fleeing, and Confused are all the same, just on separate level of cancers. Scared/fleeing is literally exactly the same, you will just run away from the fight making it a 2v3. Confused is stage 5 leukemia, you lose control of your nerves and your character does random shit including using random inventory items, fleeing, or attacking a random enemy. Holding onto a 100% hp heal? fck you suck a fart out my as s cause confused just used it. Getting hit with petrified is also pretty much game over for the fight because it turns the fight into a 2v3 for 3 TURNS. 3 TURNS!!!!! There's even a debuff called acid that destroys a piece of equipped item if you con't cure it. The chaos system is cool but it also means you are constantly being rushed to do the campaign or search for cult tiles to lower the chaos. It's honestly manageable but being pushed around constantly to do the quest instead of exploring fucking sucks.

Tanking through the hits are straight up not viable because even the tankiest characters die in 4 turns max because at least 2 enemies will target a single teammate causing them to lose 80% health in a single turn while you are chipping them away because of their high armor/resistances. Let me tell you how armor/res works, when you get hit it just gets reduced by that amount depending on physical/magical damage. There's piercing damage that goes through those defensive values but only applied on perfect rolls (all dices) on certain weapons. So you need to perfect roll every weapon or else you will slowly chip their 80+ hp down with your 5 damage attacks while the enemy constantly barrages you with debuffs/ailments/curses. This is the same game where "84%" dice rolls into 2/4 dices hit constantly, resulting on a block because its literally throwing a wet towel. I really hate the pierce/armor/resistance system because the weapons don't scale fast enough for enemy armor/resistance so relying on perfect rolls to deal any type of damage is extremely volatile in fights. Rolling 3/4 instead of 4/4 is the difference between dealing 2 damage and 14 damage in early/mid game.

It's simply not possible to carry enough healing AND a cure for ailments AND curses. That's 3 items alone and now multiply by 3 to supply each character with one of each. Not to mention most of your gold will go into buying every healing item, healing in towns, and buying weapon upgrades. You can get gold from quests but you will use all of them bringing chaos down so it's not even viable to do one for like 60-120 gold.

In the realm of digital diversions, few titles dare to entwine the fates of monarchy with the common pixelated populace, yet "For the King" embarks upon this audacious venture with a flourish of regal ambition. The game, a curious concoction of strategy, adventure, and role-playing elements, beckons the player into a fantastical kingdom besieged by calamity, where the echoes of a fallen monarch reverberate through the valleys and dales.

Upon the first glimpse, one is immediately ensnared by the quaint charm of its pixel-art aesthetic, a deliberate nod to a bygone era of gaming, yet imbued with a modern finesse that is as crisp as a freshly minted sovereign. The hexagonal tapestry upon which your quest unfolds is a patchwork of peril and promise, each tile a step closer to either glory or ignominy.

The narrative, albeit a trite tale of heroism and the inexorable march towards a preordained destiny, is served with a garnish of earnestness that is almost endearing. Almost. The dialogue often teeters on the precipice of archaic verbosity, threatening to plummet into the abyss of cringe-worthy cliché. Yet, it holds fast, a testament to the game's unwavering commitment to its regal theme.

The gameplay is a gallant gallop through familiar territories of turn-based strategy, with a sprinkle of rogue-like unpredictability that keeps the player on their tender toes. The combat, a dance of dice rolls and stat juggling, is as ruthless as a winter in the royal courts, where a single misstep could spell doom for your motley crew of adventurers.

The cooperative aspect of "For the King" is where the game truly dons its crown of distinction. The camaraderie forged in the crucible of shared adversity as you and your companions traverse the treacherous terrain is reminiscent of a fellowship of nobles, albeit with a touch more pixelated pizzazz.

The musical score, a herald of your heroic exploits, is a melodious medley that escorts your every move with a touch of orchestral opulence. It's a sweet serenade that cushions the often harsh blows of fate meted out by the game's relentless RNG gods.

In conclusion, "For the King" is a whimsical waltz through a kingdom where danger and delight are but two sides of the same golden coin. Its posh veneer may veil a core of conventional gaming tropes, but the cringe-worthy earnestness with which it embraces its royal motif is a guilty pleasure that one might find hard to abdicate.

Recommended: Yes

Playtime: 48.8 Hours

Achievement Completion: 100%

Game Length: 10.5-71.5 Hours

Reviewed on: PC

Pros:
1. Engaging Strategy: For The King offers a captivating blend of turn-based strategy and roguelike elements. The need for thoughtful planning and decision-making keeps players engrossed.
2. Co-op Gameplay: The multiplayer mode allows for seamless cooperation with friends, adding a layer of depth and camaraderie to the experience.
3. Unique Art Style: The game's visually appealing low-poly art style creates a charming and distinctive atmosphere that complements the fantasy setting.
4. Dynamic World: The procedurally generated maps and quests ensure that no two playthroughs are the same, providing a high level of replayability.
5. Deep Progression System: The leveling, equipment, and skill progression offer a satisfying sense of growth and customization for characters.

Cons:
1. Steep Learning Curve: New players might find the initial learning curve to be a bit steep, as understanding the various mechanics and strategies can take some time.
2. Randomness Factor: The procedural generation, while adding replayability, can occasionally lead to unbalanced encounters or quests.

Overview:
For The King is a delightful blend of strategy and roguelike elements that offers a fresh take on cooperative gameplay. Its engaging mechanics and charming art style create an immersive fantasy world that is as challenging as it is rewarding.

Gameplay:
The core gameplay of For The King revolves around turn-based combat and strategic decision-making. Players must navigate a procedurally generated world, complete quests, and battle a variety of foes. The inclusion of hex-based movement and positional tactics adds an extra layer of depth, requiring players to carefully plan their actions.

One standout feature is the seamless integration of both single-player and multiplayer modes. The cooperative experience shines, as players work together to overcome challenges and leverage each character's unique abilities. The game encourages communication and teamwork, making it a highly engaging experience for groups of friends.

Graphics and Sound:
For The King boasts a visually appealing low-poly art style that lends a distinctive charm to the game world. The environments are beautifully designed, and the character models are expressive, despite their simple geometry. The use of vibrant colors and dynamic lighting adds depth to the world, making exploration a visual treat.

The sound design complements the visuals perfectly. From the whimsical tunes in towns to the tense battle music, the soundtrack sets the tone for each situation. Sound effects, like the clashing of swords or the creaking of a ship, further immerse players in the world.

Story and Narrative:
While For The King doesn't prioritize an intricate narrative, it provides enough context to keep players invested in their journey. The overarching goal of vanquishing the chaos threatening the kingdom serves as a solid backdrop for the gameplay. Memorable moments arise from the unexpected twists and challenges encountered along the way.

Character development, though somewhat limited in terms of individual narratives, is driven by player choices and the progression system. As characters level up and acquire new equipment, they become more versatile, allowing for diverse strategies.

Performance and Technical Issues:
For The King runs smoothly overall, with short loading times and stable performance during gameplay. However, there were occasional instances of minor graphical glitches, such as objects clipping through terrain. These were infrequent and didn't significantly impact the experience.

Multiplayer and Community:
The multiplayer aspect of For The King shines, allowing for seamless online co-op. The game provides various options for connecting with friends, whether through Steam integration or by sharing a lobby code. The community surrounding the game is active and supportive, with forums and discussions readily available for those seeking advice or looking for others to play with.

Final Thoughts:
For The King is a standout title in the strategy and roguelike genres, offering an engaging cooperative experience with deep gameplay mechanics. While it may pose a slight learning curve for newcomers, the rewarding progression and dynamic world make it well worth the investment. With its charming art style and robust multiplayer features, For The King is a must-play for fans of tactical RPGs.

I know not every game is for everyone, but this is a game type (RPG) that I typically enjoy. That being said, I'm a casual gamer. I have small pockets of free time to play a game. I don't have the time or energy to grind and fail repeatedly. I was really disappointed that the "beginner" mode has broken scaling. The first task is a level 2 dungeon, and none of my characters were remotely close to level 2. It only gets worse. Level 5 and 6 tasks that you have to attempt because of the chaos mechanic, and my party was at level 3. The XP gains are way too low (for beginner mode, at the very least). The game wants you to explore, but then punishes you if you aren't grinding out battles as frequently as you can. It's sad the developers are intentionally cutting out a large section of gamers by making the beginner setting "hard for hard's sake". The next time I see a game that starts off by telling the player they are going to fail, I'm walking away before I waste any time.
Gotta embrace the odds and go all in.

Way too much rng. 

Team comp abilities like taunts are too inconsistent to be something you can rely on. An ability that consumes my entire turn to protect my allies has like a 30% chance of doing nothing at all? And lasts one measly turn if it does work?

Meanwhile some enemies have really bullshit abilities like the mindlord, which casts confusion on your entire party making them take random actions for multiple turns. My tank proceeds to consume all his rare consumables "curing" status effects he doesn't have, my archer just sits there swapping his weapon back and forth, and the scholar whales on the magic resist enemy. While my characters are effectively stunlocked, the enemies are casually murdering my squishies.

To compensate for the artificial difficulty of all this randomness, the enemy AI acts dumb and doesn't just prioritize characters at low health or weak resistance. While this is pretty necessary to make the game playable, it just further adds to the feeling that I'm playing a slot machine.

It's a shame, this game could be really fun if it was less random.

Listen, this game could be a great chill and play with your friends experience. Was looking for something me and a friend could relax and enjoy together. This seemed like it was it. It has the weighty TBC with art and animations pleasing to look at and appreciate. Me and my friend are playing a good 2ish hours and we decide to get off for the day, looking forward to resuming our progress the next day. Well... Low and behold the apparent dreaded "DisconnectByClientTimeout". This has to be the most frustrating issue in a fully released game i have ever encountered. You basically have to start a whole new game once you receive this error. There is no fixing it. This issue has been around since the beginning of the games development, and the developers have no interest in addressing it for some reason. 5 whole years people. 

   Went trawling around the internet for any potential solutions and i came across this gem of a comment, which if listened too at all by the developers they could potentially fix this said issue no problem instead of expecting paying customers to learn how to open ports, download VPN's and mess with modem settings(I love to have port forwarding and VPN's a part of my games special features...FUN!!!). 

Here is the gist of the comment by user "Apocalypse_555":  "when you do an heartbeat (the network exchange to check if a client is still connected) on any program, you do it on TCP not UDP. Why that? Because UDP is not reliable, it's not subject to debate or anything like that, it's a fact due to the technology. UDP is fast but unreliable, TCP is slow but reliable. So none is better both are used for different things. If you can afford to lose some packages, they go on the UDP, if you cannot, they go on the TCP. So guess witch protocol to use for the heartbeat. The TCP! I learned that in 2nd year of computer engineering and that's pretty basic knowledge."

This comment was made in 2020. Already 3 years ago. Not only that there appears to be a common pattern of developers completely ignoring this error, and directing paying customers to 3rd party solutions. Absolutely unacceptable behavior from the people that advertise the feature of an online cooperative experience. If a Developer reads this, please, for love of all that is video game developer integrity fix this error. Because as it stands i will not be playing this game and neither will others who have had to deal with this error. This is ultimately a question of ethics. I, as a consumer have no idea what goes into creating a game. But you must do the bare minimum and fix glaring issues that impact player experience. 

- DO WHATEVER IT TAKES!!!!

If you want to enjoy the game, ALT+F4 will let you.

The premise is enjoyable, the feeling and vibe are incredible without dramatizing too much, and if you know what you are doing, it becomes exciting. However, it suffers Darkest Dungeon syndrome, and that is, not a true feeling of RNG. Good rolls will stack up and bad rolls will stack up higher. And there is always a priority to dump bad rolls your way at your weakest. Which is not random, it is weighted. However, there is one key difference that makes this game different and not hindered critically by the comparison:

If you want to enjoy the game, ALT+F4 will let you.

It's an autosave after every iteration of turn and "expect failure" bs, sure some people will like that but like I said above, it rubs its ugly head in the way at least for me personally. And its difficulty is redoing an hours long campaign because you got the shortest straw. That's where alt+f4 comes in. Besides multi-level dungeons, you can escape most really awful rolls, and you know they are awful because the statistics are very garbage, which I will go to into detail in a sec. Most of the time you go back to the start of the last turn to try again. And granted to be reasonable, you wont get all rolls, and that's okay. It follows a pattern of good streaks and blunders. And you won't really have too much need to, except for specific results which specifically put you in a bad spot for the run. And that's where a friend taught me a valuable lesson during co-op:

If you want to enjoy the game, ALT+F4 will let you.

Let me give that example. I decided to run through a trap on level 3 in hilbert's cellar. My best character for the agility check has a 38% chance success naked and a 68% chance with one focus point spent. I ran it seven times using it with one focus, with the results
Fail Fail Fail Fail Fail Fail Fail Success (obviously after succeeding finally I wasn't going to spend more time on it). Now, statistic speaking, each roll is independent of each other and has no effect on the other, that's what we are assuming (null hypothesis). Here are the odds of that happening:
32% First Fails
32% x 32% = 10.24% Two Fails in a row
32% x 32% x 32% = 3.2768% Three Fails in a row
32% x 32% x 32% x 32% = ~1.0486% Four Fails in a row
32% x ... (five times) = 00.3355% Five Fails in a row
32% x ... (six times) = 00.1074% Six Fails in a row
Now to fail six times and we are assuming it is fair, that's a 1 in 931 chance of happening. Now if I am subject to a 1 in 931 chance event, is that fair? If you say no, that's where I was headed (I know it is moreso negative binomial distribution and needing alpha values (to find confidence intervals) and such but let's be honest this is a steam review)

Just wanted to give everyone some background  to know what kind of game you will deal with and all of its tricks of the trade. It isn't rng, it isn't fair or truly random, it is conveniently easy and situationally aggressive for no reason, numbers irrelevant. But it isn't all that bad, I enjoy the game, it is fun and it has a lot to offer. Satisfaction and fun come from a true understanding and acceptance of how the game works. Don't take my over-analysis for cynical ranting, there's much to have here. But if you decide to go for it, don't beat yourself up, don't struggle or redo everything due to a fluke chance that has a 1 in 931 chance of happening, take in all the devs have in store, and remember:

If you want to enjoy the game, ALT+F4 will let you.

As you can tell by my play time that I should be writing a positive review for this game and I do like some parts of it but the cons out weigh the pros. Below will be a list of pros and cons for this game. I would really think about how much you love self punishment before you play this game. This game punishes you but just punishes you to make this game seem hard and difficult to play. 

Pros:
Combat system, It is sort of like rolling dice which to me is fun.
Itemization, Lots of fun and neat things to use and unlock in this game.
Class System.
Enviorment and Maps

Cons:
Game will punish you to just seem hard. (The fact that enemies never miss a roll and its always perfect for them is just unfair. I roll I have a 80% chance but each roll also has its own percentage which is lower then that 80% they show you. So as a player expect to miss a lot of attacks and spell cast even though the enemy is built unfair to never miss rolls. Also don't go into fights thinking you and the computer monsters are the same. They get to perfectly roll everything 99.9% of the time and will always do twice or three times more damage then you will.)

Sound (Its just not entertaining or fun to listen too. The ad video for this game makes it seem like you will get fun battle music that is engaging. You do not. False Advertising comes to mind.)

Overall Feel the game says in a warning that it is hard and challenging which it is I have beaten this game multiple times in all story modes but at the same time I am doing college level calculus to figure out what move I should do next all while the computer is just unfair. 

TLDR: If you like a even playing ground against a games system this isn't the game for you. This game is unfair and puts itself above the player when it comes to fair play.

Take this as more of a "mixed feelings" rather than a negative review.

The game is quite fun early on. There's no complicated tutorial to bog you down, and the game is simple while giving you enough freedom to give you lots of options. Whether you play alone or with friends, you will enjoy the challenges the game provides at the various difficulties the game offers. Sometimes you may get lucky, other times you may get unlucky, but if you game over'd somewhere it was very likely avoidable with better play somewhere earlier in the run.

Unfortunately the problem is that "playing better" mostly comes from prior knowledge of the game outside of your character. Knowing things like when the shops refresh their stock (and also increase their prices) is very important, but the game doesn't even tell you when it happens. Knowing which enemies you're going to face beforehand is also very important. The only thing you can see about enemies is their HP and armor/resistance. You can't know what kinds of attacks they can do (and therefore which immunities to bring) without first experiencing them. Monsters also have a loot table that's basically impossible for you to figure out in a reasonable amount of time. Some enemies end up being a waste of resources to fight, and some overworld encounters are even tougher than boss battles.
Additionally, player weapons are not balanced very well and you are often reliant on randomness to find a good weapon. Weapons have a huge impact on how well runs go: some weapons unlock combos that essentially become infinites while some bad ones might make your character almost useless.

The last thing to mention is that like some other roguelikes, you are able to get unlocks. Some are fine (new character classes, different encounters), but some just make the game easier (more stats, better weapons). The game is noticeably easier if you use these unlocks, which I don't think is good design.

Overall the game is still very playable, but don't expect an RPG where the skill is in the battle strategy. It's really in knowing the secrets to make the game easy.

I really hope there is a "mid" rating on steam as I have mixed feeling about this game.
Overall, the game has great overland exploration mechanic, sadly dragged down by EXTREMELY SHALLOW AND TEDIOUS combat and character system. Story is basically non-existent so this is more like a roguelite dungeon-crawler rather than an RPG. 

Exploration
Exploration mechanic is pretty good. The party moves around the board to complete objective. Get packed together to get better combat power, or split up and rapidly dispatch the objectives on the map. One can also expend "focus", which can also be used to improve the stat rolls, to move around the map faster. All of these create some interesting strategies during overland exploration. I would love this game if it's other aspects also has this depth......

Combat
Unfortunately, the combat is just general tedium. You have characters lined up and beating up each other like old JRPGs, and each character perform exactly 1 action, chosen from like 4 options, per turn. The weapon skills are uninteresting and you can easily find some weapons meant to be on the same tier, to be objectively better than its other counterparts. The combat options are pretty limited. So in many battles, you are just performing the same action, over and over again for multiple turns. Also as mentioned by several other reviews, the RNG is not in your favor. Even if you spend your resources to power up the big attack to like 97%, you can still miss. It's extremely frustrating and makes you just want to save scum.

Other 
The following aspects are something that I consider not as important when judging a roguelite dungeon crawler. 
The story is basically non-existent. This is okay if this is just a dungeon crawler, but for a real RPG experience (or as other people might claim "DND experience", the game NEED a real story with real characters. 
The graphics are pretty nice and the arts are pretty stylish. But again, this does not redeem a game from its bad mechanics.
The lore unlock are somewhat grindy, and the gameplay certainly doesn't make it as replayable to justify the grind. Again, this would be much better if the combat is better.

Summary
The game could be some casual fun if you play it with friends, but there are much more sophisticated games on the market with more engaging combat. Buy it if you want to play it with friends, or if you really just want to look at funny animations and click some buttons. Don't buy if you are craving a tactical RPG. If you really want have DND experience with friends, and without a DM, maybe just go with divinity original sin 2.

It's a decent fun game for a little while, MAYBE worth the price for 50-70% off or more as long as you don't take it too seriously.

I did finish the game. But it was entirely luck that I got builds that synergized. I can not recommend it for most people because it's mostly luck, and IMO strategic turn based games like this should be about decision making and strategy. And there is precious little of that here.

POSITIVES:
Looks pretty good for what it is.

NEGATIVES:
- Gameplay is very shallow, poorly explained, with ZERO character customization. 

- Success is found through luck (see below) and developing synergies between your teammates which often isn't possible due to RNG. 

-Cheezing the stack with stun-lock tricks is your money. But it really feels like cheezing. And often isn't possible anyway.

- There is no crafting.

- There is no customizing your character at all on level ups. None.

- The only customization you get is in gear, which is randomly dropped. So basically any detailed planning is out, and you're at the mercy of the dice.

- You can play well strategically and not get a good result and die 8 hours in. Start another game, same happens. Etc. etc. until you get lucky.  

- At about level 7 difficulty ramps up exponentially for no apparent reason.

- In higher levels enemies simply out scale you.

- In game documentation/explanation of mechanics and abilities is terrible. 

- Grinding for character and gear unlocks is a waste of time as most of it is complete junk. Like they just threw a bunch of stuff in to make it look like there is a bunch of stuff in. Totally lazy developers making it look like there is more here than there is.

- There are only a few good classes which are far better than the others. Again, making it appear like there is more here than there is.

- Very lazy software development overall. The game feels half finished at best.

- The expansion ramps up difficulty in all base game scenarios dramatically and sabotages you. Don't install the expansion!

- Don't expect to play co-op with friends one night and succeed. Try several nights then you might succeed, only if you're lucky. So it won't feel very rewarding if you do complete the campaign.

I played/ground about three times as many hours as I would have if I'd known the grind was bunk and I was wasting my time. 

CONCLUSION:
Highly overrated, shallow as a puddle, and if you win, its just pure luck. 
There are many similar far BETTER games out there for the money, including:

Slay the Spire
Divinity Original Sin 2
XCOM Enemy Within
Gears Tactics
Wasteland 3
etc.
etc.

NOTE: The positive reviews are from the first 5 hours of gameplay. They just haven't figured it out yet that there is nothing to see here. I guarantee that almost nobody who upvoted this actually finished it.

Unforgiving mechanics and uphill odds makes the game all the more challenging. Online co-op works well, no bugs I've run into. The art style is solid and is perfect for the table top setting. As a budget priced game, there's not much to complain about. A sequel is right around the corner.

It's one of those games in which you are guaranteed to fail your first run

Being a big fan of rogue likes myself, at first I was a little skeptical about random chances deciding the outcome of many actions, but in this game it isn't as annoying as it is in Xcom for example, the mechanic fits perfectly here. Managing your chances and progressing through the game at your own pace with 3 different difficulties to choose from whilst being pressured by time has been very elegantly implemented. I can't stand it when games pressure me with time in any setting or mechanic, but here it doesn't feel as daunting, or at least you can select an easier difficulty to get familiar with the game, which is a very specific and big upside for me personally

This game can be played with 2 or 3 friends, which I did and enjoyed a lot. Frankly, it leaves very little room for actual cooperation or working in the team because at the end you still shuffle the loot in accordance to who mains what stat, who has the gold multiplier, or who has the party heal ability, so I'd say coop is quite poopy here, although the game was so fun we had a good time nonetheless, but if you want a proper "work in a team" experience, this game is definitely not for you

There are plenty of different scenarios for a campaign and 3 difficulties to choose from, as well as one multiplayer only scenario. With a few fails it took me <50 hrs to complete all scenarios on a single difficulty (I also played the infinite dungeons gamemode and completed one scenario on 2 difficulties) and this is not all the content available in the game. I think it's a good amount of time for such a neat and cheap game, and it is definitely worth the investment. I shall play more in the future to fully experience the hard difficulty, all the available classes and a lore store, which is where you unlock new items, POIs and classes to use in future runs

Overall, whilst looking goofy, this game is a hidden gem which I would've missed if not for my friend showing me it in person, if you're familiar with rogue likes, then I couldn't recommend it enough

Do you like RPGs? Do you like turn-based combat? Do you like goofy little items to customize your character? Are you a masochistic gamer(DM me)? Do you like getting absolutely butt fucked by RNG and dying to a parrot? Well if you checked 3 out of 4 then I highly recommend this game to you. It's got easy on the eyes graphics, many different classes to play from incel Hobo to sweaty sniper Hunter, funny campaigns to run where your little character gets brutally murdered, goofy items to put on your brutally murdered characters, many different weapons to commit war crimes with, a colorful cast of monsters and absolute-top-tier-based-peak RNG you will ever fucking lay hands on. The RNG will flip your ass sideways and fist you harder than your dad to your mom yesterday. The complete randomness of the game will make for hilarious moments when playing alone(Fucking loser) or with friends. Getting comedically murdered after failing to land a single hit on a troll and landing 3 crits after the whole party attacks is all just luck of the draw Jimbo. The story is simple and enjoyable with funny mini-bosses crashing your murderspree while adventuring through the lands of Fahrul. There are only a few things I'd like to see added like achievements that say you completed a campaign. I was also hoping to see them add a 'Chaotic Mode" where you could have 4-6 players in a single campaign. I can't really expect these additions due to FTK 2 so oh well. There are many reviews that will say the game is too hard, to them I say nay cur for thou hast a 'skill issue'. The game being 'too difficult' only fuels me to beat the game because admitting defeat is lame and for beta cucks. I spent 40 hours getting plowed by RNG and I will continue to spend more because I'm a super-mega-gigachad and it's based to get plowed.

I always play multiplayer games as single player (Inconvenient but my friends have a life). One of my worries was that this would be another game that would become way too challenging very fast for one person to juggle but so far it isn't! As single player, you're given 3 characters to take turns between and build your own team, a lot of negative reviews about this game not being single player friendly didn't mention that. 
I haven't gotten far into the game but I already started to have to grind to level up my characters, but I expect that for every game especially one like this. It kind of reminds me of Wizard101, Icarus: Lord of the Dead, Adventure Quest, and similar games. Definitely recommend to anyone looking to play single player! Like I mentioned, there's a lot of games that are "single and multiplayer friendly" but ends up getting to difficult to stay single player, but this doesn't have that issue.
The only problem I've ran into is the game completely freezing when a turn ends. Not sure what causes it, maybe I'm clicking too fast on something. But that's pretty much it. Not a big deal since it saves at the beginning of every turn. Confusing at first but took me around 15-20 minutes to figure it out.

For the King is an amazingly well put together game, with an overworld map to explore, random encounters, planned encounters, and a ruthlessly well thought out system. Definitely a lot of fun to play with friends and very a engaging adventure to take on.

The graphics are nice and have a cartoonish, almost Nintendo feel to them. Unfortunately, that also means battle animations are on the slow side.

What I especially miss in this game is the "party" feel. All the characters basically operate by themselves - they come together when fighting a monster when they're in each other's vicinity, but that's it. All party characters can use all weapons and items in the game and there's no real reason to prefer a certain profession over another. Also, when you use a "tent" only the character that actually used the tent can heal in it - even if the other characters are in the same square.

I've given it a good try but it's a bit slow. Also - things keep popping up all over the screen and it gets hard to keep track of all of them - especially if you're a little OCD and like to keep the map as clean as possible.

If you want something casual and just chill to play than play something else. I'm someone who NEVER mods a game but I am looking into getting a mod to turn off chaos.

Some things to keep in mind.

- Enemy is faster than I am and almost always attacks before my team does except for maybe one of my team members. I basically start out at a disadvantage. This is something that should've gave you the advantage early on and slowly changed as the game progressed.
- I get the feeling of being rushed even on the easiest setting because the chaos setting is so low it happens very quickly and makes the enemy stronger. Easiest setting should've had it extremely high as a default. If you want to adjust this you lose the ability to get achievements. So fun vs. achievements.
- You can't just stick in one zone/area and build your characters up. The enemy starts to out level you if you do that instead of being a level range per zone. Again, makes you feel rushed.
- If you die you don't get a tome so it will feel like you aren't able to unlock things in the lore shop due to getting zero on some runs. Tomes are used to unlock other classes and better gear that you can get from quests. Again, feels like you need to rush to get at least one tome before you get landslided by chaos and enemies out leveling you.
- XP and gold acquisition seem really slow vs how fast enemy level.
- If you use guns you are punished because you get one shot and next turn you have to reload so basically you deal half damage because one round you do nothing but reload. I love using guns in these types of games but not even worth it. So sad.
- The RNG is not your friend. 
- Everything in this game seems to be against you. It detracts from the enjoyable experience I thought I was going to have. Definitely NEEDS a chill mode or super slow mode.

EDIT: The game mode "Into the Deep" is probably the most punishing and over leveled of them all so far and just ruins it all.
- There is no Chaos mechanic which is good but there is now a flood meter which if three are collect the game is over and there are no quests I've found to drop it so the (6) other ways are few and far between and in zones with enemies 4+ levels higher than you.
- EVERYTHING outside of small starter island are 4+ levels higher than me and the only enemies I can kill are on starter island. I'm level 3 and all enemies are level 1 and give maybe 3Xp a fight while I'm needing 200+XP to level. :(
- I now have 4 debuffs/enemies up. One has a chance to steal drops which it normally does to the REALLY good ones, one increases all shop prices, one puts black clouds ALL over the map and one has a chance to destroy sanctums which are those things that allow you to rez when dead.

Whilst the last two points may make the entire game sound bad I can assure you that this game is wayyyyy worth it. I paid 5 bucks and I would even recommend it for the 20 it costs right now.

Oh, how my heart brims with sheer delight as I traverse the digital realms of For The King. Inspired by the companionship of a dear friend, Melezprens, our initial foray into this enchanting world was short-lived but filled with cherished memories. While circumstances have led me to embark on solo quests, the game's simplistic yet captivating artstyle and adherence to classic RPG tropes continue to beckon me.
For The King effortlessly marries a delightful polygonal artstyle with a sense of nostalgia, invoking memories of classic RPGs that once graced our screens. The world unfolds before my eager eyes, revealing lush landscapes and ancient ruins, each brimming with untold adventures. The attention to detail, from the delicate sway of the grass to the intricate designs of ancient artifacts, adds an immersive touch to the overall experience.
Although my journey now treads a solitary path, the memories of shared laughter and camaraderie with Melezprens linger like a comforting breeze. Our early escapades were marked by playful banter and jovial mockery, with the occasional tease when misfortune befell our dear companion. Those moments of camaraderie, even in jest, forged a bond that I hold dear.
As I traverse the ever-unfolding tapestry of For The King's world, I am reminded of the simplicity and beauty that lies within. The game's adherence to classic RPG tropes, from turn-based combat to questing for legendary artifacts, invokes a sense of familiarity and warmth. It is a gentle reminder of the foundations upon which modern RPGs are built, paying homage to the genre's illustrious history.
Though the desire to rekindle the fires of friendship within For The King remains, I have come to appreciate the solace of venturing forth alone. The serenity found in the rhythmic footsteps of my character, the quiet contemplation as I strategize my next move, all weave together in a symphony of solitary exploration. While the allure of shared adventures lingers, there is solace and joy to be found in my own personal odyssey.
In conclusion, For The King is a testament to the joys of exploration and camaraderie, evoking a sense of euphoria as I immerse myself in its captivating world. The simplistic, polygonal artstyle serves as a visual feast, while the game's adherence to classic RPG tropes pays homage to the genre's storied legacy. Whether forging ahead alone or in the company of cherished friends, For The King invites us to revel in the beauty of this digital realm and savor the adventure that awaits.

then this game is for you

if you answered no I would imagine any time allotted for gaming is few and far between, so when you make progress over a course of time( in my case 14 hours), and then lose it all because the enemies always seem to have rolls on their side. This will leave a bitter taste in your mouth like myself.

now I do want to point out the game is NOT bad it is actually really interesting and offers plenty of random and unique encounters all while balancing a myriad of different resources, but with the blatant lack of regard for your personal life and basic respect of stat mitigation due to RNG oversight it is rather punishing. 

I cannot recommend For The King to players who are looking for a more casual experience and to move at their own pace.

[h1]A Strategic Quest for Glory[/h1]

[h2]Unleash Your Tactical Prowess[/h2]
For The King is a strategic and challenging game that puts your decision-making skills to the test. Assemble a team of unlikely heroes and embark on a perilous quest to save the kingdom from an evil force. Engage in turn-based combat, carefully plan your moves, and use your heroes' unique abilities to overcome enemies and emerge victorious.

[h2]A Visual Feast of Fantasy[/h2]
Immerse yourself in a visually captivating world of fantasy. The hand-drawn art style of For The King breathes life into the game's diverse landscapes, from lush forests to treacherous dungeons. The attention to detail and vibrant colors create a visually stunning experience that draws you further into the game's rich lore.

[h2]Unravel a Gripping Tale[/h2]
Prepare to be enthralled by a captivating narrative that unfolds with every step of your journey. For The King weaves a compelling story of heroes, sacrifices, and the fight against darkness. As you progress, you'll encounter intriguing characters, face challenging moral dilemmas, and witness the consequences of your choices, adding depth and emotional weight to your quest.

[h2]Immersive Soundscapes[/h2]
The atmospheric soundtrack of For The King sets the mood for your adventure, enhancing the sense of exploration, danger, and triumph. The haunting melodies and ambient sounds immerse you in the world, while the sound effects bring battles to life with their clashes, spells, and heroic cries. The audio design truly adds another layer of immersion to the game.

[h2]Endless Possibilities[/h2]
For The King offers a high level of replayability with its procedurally generated maps, quests, and events. No two playthroughs are the same, ensuring that each adventure feels fresh and unpredictable. The game also features a variety of difficulty modes, allowing both newcomers and experienced players to find a suitable challenge.

[h2]A Quest That Never Ends[/h2]
With its wealth of content, For The King provides countless hours of gameplay. Beyond the main campaign, there are side quests, challenging dungeons, and even cooperative multiplayer, allowing you to team up with friends to tackle the dangers together. The game's dedication to updates and additional content ensures that the adventure never truly ends.

In summary, For The King is a strategic masterpiece that combines challenging gameplay, captivating visuals, and a rich narrative. Whether you're a fan of turn-based strategy games or simply appreciate a well-crafted fantasy world, For The King offers an immersive and satisfying quest for glory. Prepare to make tough choices, assemble a formidable team, and embark on an epic adventure that will test your skills and leave you craving for more.

Starts off fun, but gets tiresome and unfair very quickly. You'll reach a point in the mid-to-late game where enemies will start doing more damage than you can heal, start landing crippling debuffs every turn, and start buffing themselves flawlessly every other turn. Meanwhile, even with the best of luck, you'll fizzle spells and fail to cast even the simplest of buffs/debuffs from the start of the adventure straight to the end. 

I think the issues in balance come from enemies being treated like players as far as their hit chances, where the harder the enemy is, the more likely they are to hit/crit/buff/debuff. That might sound stupid and obvious, but beyond a certain point it becomes almost guaranteed that enemies will succeed every turn they make, whereas even with 95 in a stat, you'll regularly mess up every action you make for entire turns at a time. Enemies also scale their damage ridiculously high, to the point where even having the best armor available to you will hardly reduce it, not even mentioning some of the positively sadistic enemy design in the latter half of the game. 

This game was made to crush balls, and I'm not into CBT.

The idea of this game as a adventuring party traveling a board map sounds interesting, but this game is super punishing/tedious in a variety of ways.  A lot of fights I don't want to take because I know my characters will lose most of their HP as fights are just slug-fests; it's hard to roll special abilities to protect yourself and even so most of your characters are too slow to get a good opening move. A lot of events that involve RNG rolls not in your favor I do not want to do because of the possible lose of multiple turns or experience that is hard to get as monsters quickly out level you for the dungeons you need to do. Getting equipped is based on RNG; I just happen to find a decent weapon from random fight or on some dead body that appears on the map; if I do not get that at the start of the game, the dungeon ahead will really just roll over my lives. You might have one character who gets a weapon they use while your bow user just gets nothing or you need to burn all your gold on a bad weapon from the shop if they even have gear you can use.  The Chaos bar, which pushes you to make desperate choices or to ignore far away markers on the map discouraging exploration, can make encounters more annoying with monsters getting a decent boost in HP.  You don't get anything if you want to play the game at high Chaos and it just makes the map more annoying to get around.

For The King as a solo experience is pretty tiresome or tedious. They give you the choice of playing solo to be fair, but really it was meant as fun for 3 people to communicate with.  You really need your party together for some tough encounters or to even trade gold/items when it counts, moving 3 characters solo to the same spots over and over again just makes this game drag it's feet. Also there is not much you can do if your mage just got stomped for most of his HP and he needs to wait a few turns to get 50% HP. In the end, when you play this game, to really succeed, you need to map out your moves exactly from your many failed attempts of being stomped by monsters you don't know or even how to get your characters powerful enough to make it past the mid-game. 

Get this game if you have a lot of friends for online play and when on discount. As a solo experience, it's mostly not fun for the punishing, boring, and tedious reasons mentioned

I love the look of the game. And I can imagine it is likely really fun for very experienced players. But, I find, even on the most basic level, that is much too difficult with EXTREMELY too many obstacles to ever win. I understand that may be the point. But for for a novice player, it is depressing. I purchase these games to escape and enjoy some good vibes and positive energy. But, it is really depressing and mind-numbing to feel like you are finally doing really well in the game only to be thrown insurmountable odds right near the end. Please add an apprentice or novice level that allows novice  players to enjoy a win occasionally. After all, both experienced players and novice players pay the same price for the game. Maybe consider throwing us a bone.. Maybe take a hint from The Banner Saga or WilderMyth and add an easier learning level for newbies. If I wanted to feel constantly defeated I would just read the daily news. The obstacles thrown in near the end of the game feel like unfair developer tricks...not clever gameplay.

I played solo as hunter on my first game died, then on my second go I won, it's a very enjoyable game, you improve your character and develop overtime doing quests and random dungeons, whats enjoyable is the ability to play your own way, building your character to fight with specific weapons and using herbs to beat high level enemies that would otherwise destroy you. 

Its art style is very enjoyable sometimes funny, especially when you blast someone in the face with a gun and they go flying, you also get to have intense fights that have you on the edge of your seat, for me on my solo play I died many times but because of mushrooms and totems i was able to come back mid fight and clutch it.

However if you decide to play solo with additional players you'll have to micro manage each player which can be a pain, I was hoping that there would be an option to have AI on your team so you could play without needing to control each player, that's the main reason I play this game with only one character. 

However my review is based on single player rather than group play, so if you are a person who's wonder if they can play this game without friends then yes you can, although it is more difficult but also very intense and enjoyable, because you only get one life unless you have mushrooms or totems, also totems are just statues you pray to for a backup life and some perks, you can only have one on at a time and they get destroyed on your death, for anyone wondering.

I definitely suggest this game to anyone. And i will also be buying the new one when it releases, although i'm hoping they have an AI option. I'd also suggest other reviews if you are going to play with friends as I haven't done that yet.

For The King 을 들어가기 앞서 10계명
( 반드시 준수 할 것 )
1. 사냥꾼을 해라 가장 회피가 좋다.

2. 내 앞에 있는 적만 생각하지 말아라 내 옆도 적이다.

3. 항상 도주를 생각해라 내 옆 라인을 고기방패로 사용하고 도주해라

4. 골드는 일단 공유해라, 80골드 이상일 경우에는 실수인척 획득을 눌러라, 다시한번 말하지만 내 옆도 적이라고 생각해라

5. 유리,사파이어로 된 무기를 피해라, 부서지는 순간 마법사에서 몽크로 바뀔 수 있다.

6. 전투에 들어가면 일단 거리벌리기를 써라, 딜 보단 내 생존이 우선이다.

7. 짜잘한 골드는 넘기기를 눌러라, 내 다음턴이 공유를 누른다면 너에게 아이템을 얻을 찬스가 올 수 있다.

8. 너가 죽는다면 너의 탓이 아니지만 남이 죽는다면 그건 걔 탓이다

9. 집중력을 소모해서라도 최대한 성소를 획득하자 죽더라도 한번 부할이고 다른 놈이 먹으면 다시는 못먹으니깐, 다시말하지만 내 옆도 적이다

10. 좋은 아이템이 나오

Great game, terribly balanced as many reviews say. Simple things like taunt so that your tank actually takes any aggro (enemies heavily focus your squishier party members) are made frustrating and inconsistent by low success rates, low speed on the relevant characters meaning most enemies will get at least 1 attack off before activating it is even an option, and the low duration (only 1 turn). Not a bad purchase for a few hours, but feels more like faceplanting a wall after a certain point.

Somewhat repetitive gameloop however the rogue elements keep it fresh and I'm still unlocking new things from the Lore Store after 27 hours. It is definitely challenging as well (some of that due to very annoying RNG at times); I only beat the main campaign one time after 5 attempts. Overall a good game despite a few gripes that I share with most turn-based RPGs. If you enjoy Raid: Shadow Legends but you ACTUALLY want to finish the game and feel progression/reward, this is the game for you.
TIP: SPEED is king. Just keep that in mind. If you find you're struggling to get attacks off or evade attacks or even MOVE efficiently on the tiles -- build Speed. Hell, just make a full speed team. You won't regret it =)

For The King is an insanely fun game to play solo or with friends. The game is overall designed to be played on it's medium difficulty, as the real game experience comes to life with it. Easy difficulty is great for casual play through where you don't have the heart to game over with a few hours invested (or just minutes into your gameplay..) 

Your decisions matter, A LOT. Teamwork is required to succeed, this game is everything you want in a co-op RPG in the modern day. Every battle victory is earned and a game win is well deserved.  The games overall design is fantastic, 40 hours and quite a few campaigns in I've got more than my monies worth and I have many more adventures to take before I am bored. I've convinced a few friends to purchase the game and none of them were disappointed. Neither will you.

For The King has been released for awhile now and #2 is on the way. I couldn't be more happier. If you're looking for a fun RPG and CHALLENGING game, this is absolutely the right place to be.

I am 42.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

I paid $6 during the sale. Got on it with my partner. 
We spend 7+ hours on our first go, failing 3 times.
Regardless, each time we ran the game, we understood more, and were able to progress faster. It is a hard almost rogue-like game.

WHAT I LOVE:
- How many companies give you FREE cosmetic DLCs for your character? You can be a goblin. for free. that's rad.
- Re-playable. Each map is randomly generated with random events happening. You learn and discover new things as you play.
- Really fun in a group. Although the movement on the map being turn-based is a bit challenging sometimes, it kinda adds to the charm. Forces you to strategize together. You can play as two characters instead of three and do pretty well.
- You gain currency in (almost) every game to purchase new additions to the game; classes,  cosmetics, random events, items to be added to the game. A really nice thing to see in a world of real $$$ for more content.
- Unique artstyle. Very stylized and cute. Items and names of characters are charming. Really seems like there's a lot of love poured into this game.

8.5/10 so far.
