So to clarify at start why I'm giving thumbs down for the game. It's to hopefully draw devs attention to this review. Game is very fun, i recommend playing it. But it's terribly unbalanced.First, i don't understand were the necessity is to rush you with time based mechanic where your game just ends if you reach max chaos. Game is hard enough without it and personaly I play games to relax not to have some sort of deadline and stress about it. I have it in my job and thats enough.Some characters just suck compared to others. It's mainly due to items available in game. So if your character is based on some sort of stat that goes with overall weak wepons they are just much worse. For example talent based guns. They are terrible. If you don't have focus you risk so much using them and the reward isn't even that great because they don't deal that much damage. And let's say you succeed - you have to reload next turn skipping your turn. In practice that means that if you always hit your shots you deal half damage in 2 rounds. That's just not enough compared to other weapons that maybe hit just a little less but you can deal that a little less damage 2 rounds in a row. And even if you fail to make perfect rolls you usually do some damage not 0. And if you fail your rng check on guns? You just did nothing for 2 rounds. And since game is quite complicated you can get rekt by this so much. You can get stuned rendering you useless another round, you can get shocked and if you don't have focus you will always fail your shot so you are useless for multiple turns. And not doing something in your turn is massive in this game since there are monsters that will obliterate your party if you let them move a couple times in combat. Same goes for buffs for you/your team or debuffing your enemies. In order to do anything to buff yourself/party you have to hit all rng rolls. In practice that means that if you don't have focus it's almost never worth it to try due to how punishing it is to fail. Same goes for debuffs, if you fail even one roll you do nothing. In practice that means that only party buffs are worth it to try if you can't guarantee them going though. Also i don't understand why some mediocre buffs/debuffs require so much rng checks to go though. And then you have items like bows for hunters. They have low amount of checks for insane rewards. For example you can speed up your entire party making them move a lot more just by rolling 2 checks. Also since hunters stats support bow skill accuracy you can pretty much secure game breaking party buff for 1 focus. Same goes for slows/aoe slows on enemies. Slow is so good that not only it lasts multiple turns ( same for party buff haste ) but it makes enemy move so rarely they become a joke. You have to understand that high hp, high defense monsters in this game hit insanely hard. They can kill one of your party members in 2 hits. So when you slow them you make them move so rarely that you basicly remove them as a threat. And as they hit that hard every move they do is game breaking. Thats why i think slow is actually a good mechanic: it's quite easy to debuff and rewards you with delaying Mike Tyson's punches to your team that obliterate your party. Not to mention some monsters do that but AoE! But it's overpowered compared to other buffs/debuffs in game. For example you have a skill protect that requires you to hit multiple rng rolls to put a barrier on you/your team to negate next attack. So you risk so much that you will not only fail and skip your turn but also as you fail to buff your team that big monster due is moving next soon and he just slams you. Even if you win your rolls and you protect your party there is a chance that fast moving monster will take down your protect or even better - monster will use AoE ability and take it down. Thats just trash compared to slow. Next you have stuns. They also require a lot of rolls to stun and they skip 1 turn of monster moving! Insane! Slow basicly does that but for multiple turns and it can be AoE, just xD. There are other weak abilities but those are my top 3 examples on how unbalanced the game is.Monster damage. Monsters hit sooooo hard in this game. There is a point in the game when it's not worth it to attack many camps due to how hard they will devastate your party and that you will have to use gold purchased herbs to heal or spend gold in town to heal. Oh and to and so spice, some monsters can kill you in 2 turns and they have CC effects such as shock/stun/entangle/daze. But lets say monster damage and their CC abilities can still be managed. Well they could but then you have just big fuck you abilities in game like: Minotaur attacks you and destroys your item, it's gone. Fun right? Cool, you lost your great gear and you couldn't do anything about it because I guess you were suppose to nuke down that big hard beefy guy with high HP and defense before he moves. I suppose if party buffs other than haste or debuffs like slowwere balanced you could do something to prevent it. But oh! You failed you multiple rng roll on ability and did nothing aaaaand it's his turn so get rekt. There are other abilities such as monsters that aplly acid on you and in like 2-3 moves of your character break your gear. I don't get what is fun in making a player lose their gear when often there is no counterplay due to rng. Confuse is another broken one and oh yeah it can be AoE. Monster confuses you and you perform random actions in your turn. In practice that means your character can use a very expensive consumable item for nothing and then flee encounter. Not only you are probably damaged by fighting with your enemy but you lost your consumable for free. Great mechanic! Well you could always try, ofc if you have such skill in party, to cleanse this effect from your party member ( if you are lucky enough to move before them ) but then again you have to take extreme risk to perfectly roll multiple rng checks. Monster camps. They are just not balanced. If you see that it's a camp of hard hitting high hp high defense monster it's just not worth it to do it. You will get your party hardly injured for some gold ( you will probably have to spend it to heal up your party ) and random items. You see camps always have 3 monsters so if you see camp of such op monster you will have to deal with 3 copies of him. They are sometimes harder and more dealy then final game bosses - that should tell you something. And the fact that you don't receive some better quality loot from such camps is just... bad. You can do a camp of some wimp monsters and get better rewards ( although those beefy guys give mover xp, but it's not that important compared to risk imo ).Me and my friend played all campains and you know which one we had most fun in? Water campain with sea king. And it's because it was quite easy to manage instantly ending game chaos mechanic and mechanics of the boat. And it wasn't easy. monsters were still challanging. But at least there was no stress about game ending and movement around map was not horrendous. You see, on land each hero, on his turn is rolling how far they can move, yes it's rng. So slow characters can sometimes slack off behind your party so much that its just annoying. On the other hand when you go on the boat your entire party moves together. In practice that means that even if your slow character rolls low movement your entire party still moves a little bit not just him and when your high mobility character moves he carries movement of slow hero. You can also get out of boat, explore a little and on another character turn they can pick you up back to boat - so basicly you save all that distance of backtracking. It feels nice.Okay im done with ranting. To sum up: game is still very fun and challanging even when it clearly lack balance in many aspects. I do recommend buying it. I just hope in time devs balance it a little bit to be more strategic and tactical.

I recommend this game for single player experience, if it's on sale.

As a co-op game, however, I find it boring, with not enough content to engage more than one person at a time.

PROS
- Many maps and scenarios to choose from
- As you play you can unlock new classes, equipment, and events, adding a roguelike feel.
- Difficulty settings are adjustable
- Unique environments to explore
- Clear mission objectives

CONS
- UI isn't the most smooth
- Not enough depth for enjoyable co-op. The game design makes it difficult to share various responsibilities equally. In CO-OP mode, there's a lot of waiting too.
- Not much content to unlock, and the pace to unlock it is slow.

Fun game for the first 10-20 hours. Catchy graphic, easy mechanics, easy combat system - everything thing is just fine. Pretty much looks like very simple Low-Poly version of Heroes without any city building / economical part.

However the pain starts hitting slowly after playing a bit more.

The game hides the fact that You almost can't finish the story in 2 ppl. Max players is 3, but the game still lets You start with just 1 or 2 ppl in team without actually telling anywhere "We didn't implemented any scaling, the game can be fully played only by 3 ppl", so any attempts hopes of slowly finishing the game in 2 ppl turns into anger.

First attempt to win... second... third... 4th.. 10th - all just to keep getting smacked by the lack of scaling.

This becomes even more problematic because in the main story the economy slaps You in the faces and slowly the prices of everything are so high that the only thing You can do with items in shops is "looking on them". There is no sense to fight to get money for healing herbs if You need to use the herbs You get to win the fight if You want to get money for more herbs.

Ofc. the further it goes the harder the foes are, and the more annoying they become, so it can happen that in single fight You'll get wiped without even doing to much at all, because of the "speed up move" skills which foes can use to move You on the end of line. To many items in inventory? Not a problem, You'll get a condition which will make Your character randomly consume items in inventory.

Want more? 

The game item drop / shop supplies is terrible. As for me the favorite character is Hunter and in expansion Treasure Hunter, but for 60+ hours of playing as hunter in 95% of time there is NO WEAPON AT ALL. Imagine going few levels further with annoying pistol from lvl 1 just because it's nowhere to be found - nowhere at all, no drop, nothing in shop, nothing in night market, nothing in treasure - zero. Over escalating? Nope, because other ppl in team got the items they need, staves, swords, tomes etc.

Expansion?

The expansion is not worth it because it's just lazy copied and pasted content with some more trees and few more foes. Even the so called "Scurge" are the same and now in expansion they worship some god instead of following "the chaos"

So playing is possible only with full team, 2 ppl in team requires A LOT of organization and planning, and that still can end up badly.

I was sceptical about this game but after all the hype I read about it in the reviews/reddit I gave it a try. It's lackluster. Played coop with a friend and we made it pretty far into one of the sccenarios. The story is boring, generic, travel to a town 7x times, fight in the arena 7x times, find the temple 2x times, find the same item 5x times. The combat feels like you don't have any control over it (feels unfair at times), decisions feel meaningless because of RNG (you can have 90% chance to succeed and get 2 fails in a row etc.). I played a blacksmith (made it into a rogue type character) I only had 1 button to press per turn and that was it, too many dice rolls. Items are simple, +stats or +immunity to stuff, you get the same item in every shop and on every drop multiple times. Meh. Positives? Artstyle is ok, animations are good, not much.

No, just no, avoid at all costs.
It may seem fun to watch other play it online, but when you get to be the one playing it the following shall be realised:
- is RNG against you? (monsters roll perfect 80% of the time, but you that have 89% chance is ~60% of the time)
- story sucks and repeats itself, simply no vision when it was written
- heals? just a few, go fuck yourself
- items? ctrl+c ctrl+v but change some stats to be +1 higher
- curse, poison, bleed? of course, go fuck yourself again
- easy mode just to practice? get a penis enlargement operation and go fuck yourself
- monsters attack first? of course
- wanna make some "interesting" content? add 'breakable" items & traps that destroy items if failed
- wanna fuck yourself? play this game

For The King is a relatively simple but still not easy coop roguelike party RPG that is a nice introduction to Party RPG games. Don't be scared that the "if you wipe, your save file is deleted" aspect might be offputting. Most people adjust much more easily to such than one might expect.
It has a nice vibe and some funny writer moments in campaigns don't take themselves overly seriously in tone.

If you're playing as 2 people, I recommend to still use a third character and have one of the two of you control that character, as despite there being some rebalancing for 2-character parties, most encounters, and especially the difficult ones, don't seem rebalanced for that, and there is a lot of synergy, buff and debuffing that is an integral part of both the game balance and the stimulation of trying to figure out what's best to do. If 1 of your two party members debuffs all the enemies or buffs all the friendlies, it definitely is much less effective than if you are 3 party members, and thus is kind of ruins the power of a lot of crucial debuff and buff centric weapons and playstyles that are standard and optimal.

It would have been a crazy good game if 90% rolls feels like it happens 9 out of 10. But in this game, 90% feels like it happens 6 out of 10 on good day, 3 out of 10 on a bad day. At least, last time i studied probability in high school that is how it should work.

This game is incredibly addicting, from its simple systems to its satisfying art style pleasing sound design. Its incredible game but its ruthless, incredibly so actually no its absurdly unfair to the point of rampantly shitty game design I honestly don't think I would be able to recommend this in good conscious Its criminally unfair everything hanging on a thread of balance that seems to never be in your favor and seems to actively fight you the more you try and break it to be in your favor its frankly frustrating and the worst part about this games design truly is how long the runs take, in everything other roguelike you die fast play fast, its not the same in this game you play slow die fast it feels like hours can slip through your fingers because of a dumb fucking mistake that in the grand scheme of things is truly never your fault. But its absurd how addicting this game is it's an incredible experience filled with a surprising amount of nuance to its mechanics even if they seem simple there is always another layer to the game that can slightly improve your chances from turn movement management and managing your focus properly, to understanding what you need to do to get the best benefit out of your class's playstyle to something so common like what weapons are bad and good and even on that last point the variety of weapons in this game is nuts, there are at least a 100+ weapons and 100+ armors theres something for everyone. I can truly only recommend this game to the most hardcore of roguelike fans and gamers who are used to playing games where they get shit on over and over again and can still get back up, because the experience of success is only worth it if you can truly look past failure otherwise this game isn't worth it at all.

This game is decent, but I cannot recommend this to people unless you want a ball-breaking experience where the AI is [b] exclusively always cheating even on the easiest difficulty [/b]. There is very little thought put into the balancing of this game which really shines once you hit the steepest difficulty curves and you will more than often rely on the filthiest of team builds in order to have the 'slightest chance' of making it through a battle unscathed if at all.

Pros:
+ Visually appealing polygonal design, similar to Deep Rock Galactic or Valheim.
+ Challenging bosses that require you to figure out their weaknesses in order to defeat them easily.
+ Grid based world navigation with interesting random encounters that add to the randomness.
+ Variety of weapons, armors and items that make each run unique and forces you to experiment with builds.
+ Online 3 player co-op so you can suffer with your friends.

Cons:
- The aforementioned sadistically cheating AI who will always roll perfect RNG in order to maximise damage against your team. They rarely miss unless you are able to use the TWO debuffs that will guarantee a missed roll unless they can resist said debuffs, which MOST OF THEM WILL.

- Most elemental debuffs (Burning, Lifesteal, Bleeding, etc.) will very lightly inconvenience the enemies, but against you the effects are unfairly devastating and vice versa for buffs. Enemy buffs are incredibly strong but on your team will pale in comparison. Your only hope is to find armors and weapons that will resist these debuffs against you, but again, there's always something that can and will counteract that.

- With how heavily the game cheats, it feels like you've wasted hours when a boss wipes your party solely due to RNG as each run autosaves to the cloud and deletes immediately upon your defeat. Good luck trying to save scum too.

This game is great on the surface and starts out enjoyable, but quickly snowballs into a mess of unbalanced builds and sadistically designed AI with rigged dice rolls sprinkled on top. There's a good reason why only 3% of gamers have beaten the main campaign on it's Medium difficulty.

Fantastic barebones rogue-like RPG. As you can tell, the art assets are not amazing, but it has fantastic replayability, great difficulty curves, and a lot of heart under the slightly shabby surface. I keep coming back to this more than any fantasy RPG, because the basic gameplay loop is so well done. Every level feels dangerous, even as you clearly grow in power and capability. Every choice feels vital, yet it's never stressful.

That said, if a bad roll of the dice ruining several hours of an otherwise great run is something that will ruin it for you, don't play this game. It's rare, but occasionally the RNG will mess you up beyond a reasonable level to handle, and you just lose a run. Nothing you can do.

This game is a YES if you pay under 10$ for it. 

Right out the gates it's seeming rogue-lite, but it really doesn't feel like it. The campaigns are forays that take around 7-10 hours to complete. You create 3 characters that have specializations, but are somewhat flexible in what you can have them do once you're in the campaign. On the surface the game doesn't do anything wrong and was really enjoyable for the first 10 hours, but after that you can really see the flimsy scaffold holding the experience together. 

The system gives the allusion that you'll be able to take these classes and maybe do some interesting things outside the mold--like for instance, creating a Paladin type character that heals, taunts and soaks damage--however, the kind of perfect RNG you'd need to do so is baffling. On top of that the armors and weapons aren't truly dynamic or varied enough that you can really stray too far from the class archetypes. 

It was fun to chase loot, but the pool is so small that you aren't really gonna have any surprises after you make it through the first playthrough. 

In the end the combat is dull and punishing. You mostly smash the same button over and over. I likened it to early turn based games like Final Fantasy 1-4 or something, but it has no deep story to hold your attention or real nuances to the characters to allow for attachment. Every battle, even against normal enemies usually leaves you drained or poisoned or cursed. Combat only feels fun for the first few levels, when you don't have to full heal/cure/bless after every battle. There isn't that sweet spot where you ever really feel strong, you always feel like you're hanging on by a thread. 

I feel mostly disappointed. Really wanted a game to sink my teeth into, but it just didn't have the depth I wanted. I tried to make it more than it was: It's a simple game, if you go in with no expectations you'll be pleasantly surprised, but it's a NO for me.

For the King is the second best thing in my life; the first best thing is The Way of Kings by Brandon Sanderson. I can only think of a handful of things that rival these two entities. Chief among that handful of rapscallions is King Kong, the large primate hero. The Lion King movie is, in fact, there. Of course, there's The Curse of King Tut's Tomb (the 2006 movie). King Kong, The Lion King, and The Curse of King Tut's Tomb are joined by A Clash of Kings, authored by George R. R. Martin; this is a legendary book and personal favorite of kings everywhere. In summation, I would recommend For the King because it is in a prestigious league, flanked by The Way of Kings, King Kong, Lion King, The Curse of King Tut's Tomb, and A Clash of Kings. Fair?

I'm giving this a thumbs up solely because of co-op. 

I don't particularly enjoy the over reliance on rng. Improving your stats feels unreliable because of this feature, and winning certain battles feels entirely up to chance. However, in co-op with friends, it makes the session feel so much more alive. The lack of consistency adds a lot of adrenaline pumping action and excitement. And because of this, I'm willing to overlook my negative opinion about this.

But there's one thing I can't ignore - pure support spells. 

For example, attacks that can cause bleed, stun, burn, etc, are fine the way they are. If they don't get a perfect roll, the status ailments don't apply. However, some damage still goes through, so even if you get a bad roll, the attacks aren't completely useless. But when it comes to support skills that solely boost armor or even attack, it feels too punishing to use. If you get a bad roll when trying to armor up, absolutely nothing happens. Not even a small bit of damage, not even a smaller portion of the buff gets implemented. 

Why? 

It feels much more reliable to use another attack that just deals damage than to use a spell that only "tries" to give you an attack buff but nothing else. Even if it's a party buff, the risk seems too high for the reward it gives. Why can't you get an incremental buff based on how bad of a roll it is? Maybe instead of giving you nothing when you roll a 3/5, it should give you 60% of the original buff. Or maybe, in the case of a party buff, it applies only to the caster on a bad roll. That way, it doesn't feel like the spell is so significantly more punishing than all the other attacks you could use instead. And these are just a few examples I personally came up with. There's probably a ton of other better ideas out there. 

I wouldn't have cared so much about this if not for the fact that most users of these support spells are magic users. And because of this fact, magic classes feel inherently weaker than their physical counterparts given that they have less options to damage the enemy. Honestly, I'm all for making the game more punishing, but if support spells suck, you should also make every other attack in the game suck just as much. Because with how it is right now, it makes playing support classes feel somewhat obsolete. 

This is just one problem I have about this game. I'm sure there's more that others have mentioned. Overall, the game feels unbalanced... as if it's in early access. But maybe that's just me. It's still pretty fun though.

I am a 51 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he helped me. Loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Good game, especially for a fiver. 
I played on normal difficulty all throughout and have only completed one campaign (there is three campaigns and then a few extra decently fun modes). 

I do think the game is brutally unfair at times, even warranting an alt-f4 to reload (I think for the next game unless they fix this brutal unfairness they should have quick-save/quick-load). 
By brutal unfairness, there is some things that can demolish you simply because of a bad dice-roll. I do understand this is intentional, as it is meant to mimic a DnD type style, but I think it would put loads of people off - even saw some reviews that echoed this thought. 

Again, on a sale it was well worth my money. Spent about 20 hours to beat one campaign on Normal and had a lot of fun. Looking forward to the next game.

This game is intriguing in several ways.  The synergies required for success are extremely useful.  This game is very close to traditional dungeons and dragons combat rule style of play.

When you begin the game, there is a pop up box that does warn players that they will not be successful at this game initially, and that there is a significant learning curve required in order to become successful.

That being said, do yourself a favor and withhold judgement on this game until you really understand how it works.  I can honestly say, it took me well over 30 games to truly understand how ALL of the mechanics work, and how to manipulate them towards success.

The designers of this game took into account all aspects of traditional D&D and you have to respect the mechanics to win.  I will list a few examples to demonstrate what I mean by this.

1. Low armor will result in higher average damage taken.
2. Balance attack damage with some sort of defense (armor, magical, dodging...)
3. Understand which weapons relate to which primary stats.
4. Comprehend which types of weapons deal greater damage towards certain monsters.
5. Pay attention to the defenses of the monsters, I.E. Immunities, armor, etc...
6. Always keep in mind who has the next attack in the rotation.
7. Try to eliminate monsters in fights BEFORE they can attack.
8. Invest one character in your party as a designated healer.
9. Understand what is worth spending gold on, and what can be easily farmed.
10. Make sure your party is balanced from a statistical point-of-view. STR/INT/DEX etc.
11. Be sure that all party members use different types of equipment.
12. Eliminate Scourges as quickly as possible and avoid battle until you do.
13. Always reduce Chaos as often as possible, do not rely on replenishing life heart.
14. Always allow Scourges to emerge.  Once killed, they have great items.
15. Pay close attention to the health of your ship.  Particularly if the Kracken is still lurking.
16. Avoid the Kracken by staying close to shore.
17. Always replenish your health/magic BEFORE you purchase items in towns.
18. Perform all quests from towns, the rewards are substantial.
19. Buy out all God's Beards every opportunity you have.  They are your health potions.
20. Make sure EVERYTHING on all characters are in synergy before you attempt to finish the game.

I could go on about the mechanics, but I am sure you get the idea.  This game will punish you for not having the proper balance in your party.  The game will punish you for going into a battle that you are not prepared for in any way.  Most all battles in this game have the ability to end your quest.  Take them seriously.

Once you have learned the mechanics effectively, this game is a blast to play, particularly on a LAN with your family.  Happy hunting and I hope this review is helpful to somebody.

[h1]Gameplay: 9/10[/h1]
[h1]Graphics & Sound: 8/10[/h1]
[h1]Narration: 6/10[/h1]

Don't take note of my low playtime - I've been mostly playing local co-op on my partner's account.

✔️ The combat & exploration mechanics are both rather simple to understand for a new player, and deep enough not to become bored on a longer term.
✔️ A huge amount of content to explore, including some that is unlocked over the course of several playthroughs.
✔️ The difficulty is rather enjoyable, with a constant risk of failing the run if you make mistakes, while remaining quite forgiving of a few mistakes.
✔️ Pretty cool (despite being simple) low poly environment & character designs.
✔️ Remarkable music, that really contributes to the ambience.
✔️ Very nice couch co-op experience.

❌ Some gameplay elements are (probably voluntarily) obscure and require the player to kind of figure them out by themself (and maybe lose a game or two because of that). Some additional clarity would have been welcome - for instance for details on some status effects, or the descriptions of some weapon skills.
❌ I'm not sure about the balance for games with less than 3 characters. I think the game has been balanced for 3 characters, and I don't think it really adapts to smaller parties?
❌ The story is more of an excuse than anything else. It works well as an excuse too, but having a bit of a thicker plot could have been enjoyable.
❌ Online multiplayer seems a bit weak, it only works with both a really good ascending and a really good descending internet transit on the host's side.

Overall I definitely recommend this game as a fun co-op experience in couch play. Not sure I would have enjoyed it as much in solo, but with friends it's definitely worth it.

This game is a ton of fun and is one of the most mathematically comprehensive while still being a streamlined video board game.

The starting campaign is For The King though, which if you buy the DLC, is no longer the default one. I figured the "Lost Civilization" campaign it started us on was a tutorial or something, no, it's the much harder DLC. So my first couple games were miserable.

But once you get on the first one, it's a phenomenal (through brutality) D&D-esque game.

You move on a hexagon grid map, can manipulate the movement and actions in different ways, and overall have a lot of tools to empower your weak party into becoming mighty enough to take down the boss. But watch out for the strong enemies, random encounters, Kraken, economic inflation, and more.

Great time with friends, awesome time locally with my wife. Just make sure whoever is playing wants to 1. Be mentally involved in the game they're playing, because it's a lot of math and making decisions based on information available on screen. 2. Is ready for a multi-hour expedition that you will open, play for awhile, close, come back to, possibly close again, maybe die, who knows. You could try to speedrun one of these campaigns but I'm assuming it'd at least take 4 hours still as you argue about how to optimize parts of your run.

Awesome game, I got it on sale for $5, but if this has caught your eye before and you and your friends got money burning a hole, it's well worth the $20. Just make sure you're prepared to die For The King.

This is an awesome D&D adventure hex-board game, with turn based actions. The graphics lean towards an 8-bit style that will allow you to play on older systems with no issues. The one draw back is that you can only have 3 players in a party instead of the traditional 4 player party in classic D&D fashion. There is no pay wall or pay to win scenarios. Definitely get the DLC with this purchase. I was lucky enough to know about this game when it was on sale and got it for family and friends. There is an escalating difficulty as you play so the better you get the harder it gets if you take too long dispatching the enemy events. Plenty of item variety to create custom characters outside you class and no restrictions on what you can use. It all depends on how you level up and increase your stats.

FTK is a "tabletop" kind of game, hexagonal map tiles with turn based movement (for your characters. Enemies are stationary but change with time), with RNG events, settlements, dungeons, quests, etc.
It's a bit like real life DnD.
Combat is like the old Final Fantasy games, a bit more like Golden Sun games though.
Several modifiable difficulty affecting parameters. 
Nice easy Multiplayer setup. 
Options to save game and continue later.

After about 5 runs at the lowest difficulty, I feel compelled to say the game is just not worth the effort.  It's very "cute", interesting premise, great animations, etc, but is NOTHING more than a grind.  You move your characters across the board, fighting the same enemy types, leveling your characters from 1-? until you finally hit a level where the gameplay becomes a war of attrition between the enemies' exponentially growing damage and your healing supplies.  The strategy is very thin and hitting the wrong combination of enemy types can turn your 4-hour grind-fest into a quick end.  My recommendation is to get this on sale and enjoy the concept and beautiful scenery until you eventually ask yourself why you're wasting your time on the treadmill.

For the King is one of those games that seem daunting at first, but quickly becomes a satisfying round of combat, loot and upgrading your character. However it isn't the best single player experience, with 3 characters that divide your attention in an almost D&D like model. This game is best played with friends, helping each other to learn, loot and coordinate across the board. For me it definitely beats playing it on my own, and adds overall value to the game.

While the systems and stats are hard to get a grasp on at first, much of the game's internal systems are quite straight forward. Buffing up certain stats and making tradeoffs with gear all appeal to the idea of management and min-maxing your adventure RPG get up. Different classes and gear unlocks also keep the campaign fresh, making sure that the endgame will never quite feel the same across campaigns. 

In a nutshell, pretty fun and best played with friends

I am new to this kind of game. I have played RPG of and on for many years. I like this game because it is fun, the animations of the characters and monsters are very clever and enjoyable. There are a couple of things I don't like, the main one being you can be punished severely for an errant click. There is no one step back kind of feature to cover an mouse or touch pad error.  Also, a player cannot save the game in combat and TPD is common and a trip back to the beginning.  Each character gets a golden bail-out coin for dire situations but I always forget to use it.  To summarize, it is clever, fun, pleasing to the eyes and the theme music is really catchy--just watch your click discipline or frustration will follow.

I like the lore store in that you collect lore books in game to unlock mini-encounters, new characters, gear, and different things to interact with in the world map in your next game through the main menu. There are multiple types of maps you can play to switch up the variety and that was a really nice change of pace compared to most games where it's only one story. When the game says you will fail your first try, you more than likely will. BE WARNED: IF ALL PARTY MEMBERS DIE IN THE SAME BATTLE THE GAME WILL END AND YOU CANNOT START FROM BEFORE YOU ENTERED THAT ENCOUNTER AND YOUR SAVED GAME WILL VANISH FROM THE LOAD GAME SCREEN AND YOU WILL HAVE TO START OVER!  It's like darkest dungeon in that aspect and while I didn't like it in that game, I like it here. I actually enjoyed that every time my party died we learned something new to take with us on our next play through. I highly recommend having two other friends to play this with because it is unforgiving. At the time of writing this review I have not completed the main story, but I definitely plan on it in the coming days. This game is an absolute steal while it's on sale and I think it is worth the full price. I cannot wait until FTKII comes out!

TLDR; For the King is a fun experience for around 50 hours of 3 player coop or singleplayer fun. 

FTK is worth it at full price without DLC. DLC are worth it on sale. 
I recommend this game if you are not familiar with this genre of games. It does not have a whole load of mechanics so it is a good starting point, but it might be too simple for people who have played more complex turn-based strategy games. For the King has remote play together, which means if someone on your friendslist has it you can play together without the other people needing to buy it.


For the King is a singleplayer or coop isometric turn-based open world RPG. It can be compared to games like Xcom, Wildermyth, Battle Brothers and Wasteland, and although it is a much simpler than those games that is not necessarily a bad thing. 
The simplicity of this game makes it a great starting point for this genre of games and also makes it allot more casual, great for chill coop with friends.
For singeplayer, there are better games out there but this one will do the job, coop is way more fun though. There is an official discord where you can find people to play with, but it is better with people you know.

The game has 4 main campaigns, 1 DLC campaign, 1 Endless mode and 1 versus minigame (Still PvE but more of a race against your friends). 

All 5 campaigns are very well done, they each have their own unique mechanics. I am not the biggest fan of the end dungeons in most of the campaigns (except for the Into the Deep) because they have allot of special enemies with unfair attacks. The dungeon crawler campaign is my favorite as it is randomly generated and very replayable.

The endless mode does away with the campaign map in favor of a dungeon, just fight after fight with only events like shops in between. This was enjoyable and a good way to test synergies.

The versus minigame is not good. It doesn't really work as the game is built for coop and people stealing items from each other or having to wait for someone's fight to end was not fun.

This mode could use a rework and I would not recommend giving this one a go until it gets changed. I doubt it will though.

The game has allot of replayability as the campaigns are semi-randomly generated.


The game has a lore store, which is your main form of progression. As you do quests and dungeons in campaigns you earn lore books. You can use these as currency in the store to unlock new events, cosmetics and weapons for your campaigns. This is good, not too grindy and always gives you something to work towards.

The difficulty system is not too great. The game has 3 difficulties; Apprentice (easy), Journeyman (medium) and Master (hard). Apprentice is nice and chill, Journeyman is a good challange but Master difficulty has some problems.
Most campaigns have some sort of threat which increases over time if you don't continue the quests, incentivising you to push forward. The higher the difficulties have more time pressure.
Master difficulty forces you to speedrun, which isn't too bad on it's own but if you combine that with the random nature of an RNG based game, you get a short time to get allot done.
In my Master campaigns I was forced to abandon and retry campaigns when the RNG wasn't going my way, turning the game into more of a rogue-like as opposed to a multi-session campaign.
I just recommend avoiding this difficulty unless you mean to 100% the game.

As a completionist, this game is quite easy to 100%. The hardest steam achievement is doing the main campaign on the highest difficulty, which is just trial-and-error.

8/10 - an indie gem which objectively falls flat in a lot of ways, but also scratches an itch that no other games quite do. 


It is unpolished in many areas such as UI, story [there isn't really one], and end-game balance but the low-poly models look great and fit the aesthetic of the game perfectly. It's very difficult but fair when you consider all of the options you're given as a player. It's one of the rare games that requires you to understand nearly every game mechanic to have even a chance of survival. Campaigns are also time-sensitive and players start out extremely weak in comparison to enemies, which feels like an cheap way to inflate difficulty. Nearly every other game rewards mechanical skill in the player, but there's no aspect of mechanical skill in this game - only preparation and knowledge. It's an interesting take, but a somewhat frustrating one for a pseudo-random roguelike. 

Overall, For the King feels like the rough draft for an amazing video game. I'm excited to see what For the King 2 might look like, but I'm also happy to play this while I wait!

This game could have massively benefited from simultaneous turns. Playing 3-player co-op ends up with an insane amount of downtime. For example, one person can go to a town, peruse the shop comparing equipment stats against the ones equipped, and the other 2 players have to wait for them to finish. Players can get into combat without the whole group and the players not in the combat just have to sit there and wait until their turn comes up.

Looting in combat is a terrible round-robin mechanic where one player gets a piece of loot and can choose to take it or pass it on, until someone takes it. It then gives the next piece of loot to the next player letting them take it or pass it on. Repeat until no items left. This is bad, because RNG can screw over a player from getting any useful loot. If players are trying to be helpful, then it just leads to asking if anyone needs something every single reward, players comparing their equipment, etc., which just leads to more downtime. The game should just give everyone their own loot.

Ultimately, the game isn't too fun. The events, combat, items, etc. are very bare bones and extremely RNG.

For The King is a fun turn base strategy games. It is quite difficult as well, and every action requires a motive with a bit of luck. RNG is crazy in this game. It is much better with friends for you have to work together as a group or suffer the wraith from the enemies and crazy map events that happen in this game. Each play-through is different, so when you lose a run; don't fret. You will have knowledge and experience from before, and hopefully do better in the next new game. I have yet to beat the For The King campaign which is the only game mode I have played, but we made it to the end tower, and are not giving up until we beat the mad wizard. As you travel, you collect lore points which you can use for a lore shop on main menu. This lore shop provides events, weapons, and new heroes to unlock for your next run to make it that much better. 10/10 recommend. Check out the YouTube and Tik Tok @ThisIsYourRandom. Feel free to ask any questions or if you're looking for someone to game with and start a run. Good luck to everyone!

The game is not compelling enough for the main gameplay loop to revolve around multiple playthroughs. Nothing that matters changes between campaigns, and for the most part you just watch the game play itself.

Like if you took a CRPG game like Pathfinder, Dragon Age, Baldurs gate and stripped out most the role-playing-game aspects of it. Or if you took the tenseness and gameplay out of Darkest Dungeon, or if you took 99% of the things you could do in a DnD inspired game away. There is not a fun game left over. The game is short, and boring, and has fairly little to do, and you have to beat a "run" to unlock more points of interest, which are also not fun, and add little more content even after unlocking all of them. This is probably the worst iteration of a Roguelike concept I've ever seen, falling just shy of Oxygen Not Included.

Waaaay too RNG heavy. In a game like this, RNG isn't necessarily bad, but this particular implementation is terrible. Whether a fight will be a breeze or resulting in heavy damage is often decided by a singe dice roll in the opening turn. These extreme binary outcomes make fights shallow as it limits the influence of player choices.

The overworld navigation is a drag, every party member has to be controlled individually one after the other. And again poorly implemented RNG playes a role in this, as the number of moves is partly decided by a dice roll at the start of a turn. It is tedious. This also means every character has it's own inventory and gold, which doesn't add anything interesting and just leads to tedium as you'll have to do a bunch of inventory management via a sub-par inventory screen.

The game definitely has some good aspects to it; I particularly like the dungeons as well as the optional quests. But the negative aspects outweigh the positive ones.

The fart burns when you have 6 hp and the opponent has 6 hp and at 90% you miss (XCOM approves) only a miss promises you a Game Over, the game removes your saves ... Bg.
The pukan burns when the acid cube dissolves your legendary armor forever...
the pukan burns when the fire elemental blows, burns forever the magic cap that gave the buffs overdrive...

In general, an interesting step-by-step bagel, with friends in a co-op over the network or on the same computer, it's the most important thing. The parties last from 4-7 hours. The graphon is pleasant, the mechanics too, the sounds are magical.

Fix what? the core system

Over 300 hours in-game. I've unlocked all the lore items. Completed all the campaigns on Master now.

This is a fun game being held back by some glaring issues. Many people complain about the RNG with the rolls, but at the end of the day, that's just RNG. What truly cripples the fun in this game is the fact that everything is so heavily stacked against you. Even when you have everything unlocked.

There are enemies you should just straight up ignore on your playthroughs because they can cause an end to your current run. Thats not "challenging design". There is no fun in having to completely avoid something implemented in the game because its just scaled so heavily against the player.

This mainly stems from enemies almost always getting perfect rolls. While we start at around 70-80 in our main stat while eventually and hopefully scaling it up to 90-95 for late game, enemies seem to clearly have 95 in their main stat from the start. You genuinely pray and grit your teeth whenever the enemy goes. The only solid counterplays to avoid this is to shock them so they always fail 1 roll, or have high evasion so they just dont touch you, or the 3rd option, which is the meta, just outspeed them to the point they never go.

That's right. One of the successful ways (in my opinion with the least amount of stress) to beat Master is praying you get the right items that allow you to just never let the enemy go while you kill them, because it is simply too risky to ever let them damage you. 

Why don't enemies scale stat-wise with progression? Or at the least, don't have all the enemies main stats at 95 so they are perfect rolling in Apprentice and Journeyman. Save the unfair uphill scaling of their stats for Master.

I genuinely think the game would be so much better if they just appropriately scaled the enemies instead of claiming "you will die a lot, just keep trying". Trust me, after 300 hours and everything unlocked, you are still dying a lot. It's just bad design. You can keep the "seemingly" skewed RNG rolls, it's just defeating when the enemy almost never fails their rolls unless you conterplay it, whilst they get to laugh as you miss 1 single roll out of your 3 and they dodge for two turns straight.

Don't get me wrong, you can definitely enjoy this game. But it seriously feels like they just gave up on some mechanics and just artificially inflated enemy stats to compensate. 

There is so much more - I think the biggest issue is there simply is too much RNG. To the weapons you get and the positions of your start and towns and what sanctums spawn and even what enemies show up when and where. There is very little that is "constant" in this game. While I love having randomness in every run so there is always something new, it just feels gross and unforgiving, like there is no incentive to truly explore because going in the wrong direction could mean chaos creeping in since you cant make it to the right place in the right time or a random event that skews more to just screwing you instead of helping you.

This leads me to my second and probably biggest complaint. The multiplayer networking is atrocious. The first issue is they don't advertise any of the already in-game options for multiplayer, instead funneling everything to Discord, a 3rd party app, for multiplayer networking. This is fine and all, but believe it or not, Discord doesnt make up the majority of the playerbase. Most people want to just join in-game and use in-game chat; not having to worry about having to use a 2nd app just to communicate in-game.

There should be an in-game friend list, an in-game block list, in-game voice chat along with the already existing text chat. Implement a matchmaking queue instead of having us make lobbies and name them "JOIN" so people do. And then you have the region-hoping issue. Since they split the servers via region, the majority of the playerbase is heavily fractured. I have played with plenty of people across the globe and there is almost never latency issues, so why separate the servers into regions? If there isn't going to be a latency issue anyway (especially since its a turn-based game where thats not really an issue), just merge all the servers into one so your playerbase doesnt have to leaf through the different regions to find open rooms.

With all of this said, I still think its a fun game, just seriously being held back by some issues that in my opinion are just too much to overlook. I really hope their explanation of having a small team when they initially made For the King can excuse this, and that their continued work on For the King 2 with a larger team and larger budget will come to fruition.

There are things that I enjoyed about this game after a few restarts at the lowest level.  One, the unique "board game" style of movement and turns.   Two, the loot/gear was fun to gain and upgrade (though weapons can break at any moment during a fight, so don't invest too much into one weapon)  The different type of enemies and challenge to find the best strategies to fight them.

However, after a few restarts to try to get past about 10th level without the world collapsing in on you, I gave up.   My partner and I were looking for a fun and relaxing game, not a rush against time where you either have to rush in and get killed (and you only get so many lives before you lose the game), or try to take some time to level up so you can not get killed so easily, and end up dying anyway due to the "doomsday timer" type mechanic.   Even on the lowest level you are toast either way.   

Kudos to those that love it, but if you are looking for a relaxing, fun game that you can play at low levels - say with your kids - this is probably not it.

Unfortunately, while this tickles a little bit of the hexcrawl nostalgia, the battle mechanics are shallow and the RNG is the only factor of difficulty. Multiply that RNG with awful mechanics like player stunning, items being destroyed, and gold being stolen, and this game is just a full bag of frustration.

The game is well built and nicely polished. It's a damn shame the game design is "how can we randomly punish the players with RNG", all of it completely out of the player's control. For example, one "fun" global effect is a jester that reduces all of your chances to succeed on your rolls. Cool.

Combat is 99% "press attack" over and over and hope you win. The support skills on weapons don't last long enough to be useful and most enemies have immunity to the common status effects. Fortunately, items can be used in combat without using your action! Unfortunately, the amount of useful and interesting items were extremely limited, even hours in. The game suffers from every bad "classic" rpg trope there is, and brings nothing to the table to balance the scales.

This game was not designed for players wanting an easy win or simple mechanics, and it warns you as such on the title screen. Rather, success comes through learning the systems, opponents, and outcomes, as in many roguelikes. There is a surprising amount of depth to be found in team composition and character build, and learning and adapting how your team operates can be crucial to victory. The graphics portray just as much as they need to an no more. The soundtrack perfectly captures that oldschool D&D vibe. The gameplay could be considered slow, but there's an animation speed-up key for the less patient. 

On the whole, a solid offering that reminds of Tabletop/RP gaming, with enough depth to be challenging, and enough reward for the risk to have you taking chances.

Of course, sometimes you greed a mysterious chest on your last point of HP, which turns out to be a mimic.

There's a lot of Dungeons and Dragons vibes in the game and the random elements bring back the energy of the earlier editions of D&D. Its charming appearance is a touch deceiving, though. The animations make the game lively and cute, but don't let that adorable piece of shit fool you. This game is brutal, unrelentingly unfair, cruel to your mental health and unforgiving in a way that only a roguelike game can be. At its core, it's a hard-core RPG, so don't expect it to be easy; it even warns you before you even start the game. You're gonna die. A lot. But hey, maybe this is exactly what you're looking for in a game. If you're into feeling real pain and it makes you think of your daddy spanking you over that cigarette you've found lying around in the parking lot and if for whatever reason that memory makes you wanna get sexual, grab two equally fucked up friends of yours and you'll have an absolute blast playing this game.

While this game shows a new kind of concept in its roguelike gameplay, there are some lackluster in it. They say you get punished for the mistakes you made in the game but no, most of the time, it is just RNGesus and somehow a global miniboss trying to screw you alive because you cannot kill him due to its imba abilities which is fine because you get learn and get stronger as you play, right? Wrong. We have been playing RNG games too long to understand that we always have a backup plan, but turns out the game forces you to have a success cap at 95%. Not that bad huh? Wrong again, because once it fails, one of your teammates might be targeted by every enemies in the fight, with their good rolls against your lousy rolls, downing you to near death state. There are heals right? Yup, one way to heal battle, one way to heal after battle, and that's it. You have to drag your way back to town for more pots or rest again and again for each time RNGesus decide to mess you up which feels like a chore and that makes the game too long. When a run is long, value of replayability becomes a question, and it is further depreciated when the story quest is linear. If you think that each character have different builds, think again, especially for their starting passive skills, you will be probably be sticking to the build meant for that skill, thus, it becomes a no-no to replayability. Furthermore, no matter what enemy encounter, they will always attack first most of the time and no such thing as winning a fight without taking any damage which is fine until you realise taunts by tanks and cures by healers can fail even by a one failed die roll (imagine failing 4 times in a row with 80% success rate) meaning there are no mitigations on your failures when the dev decide your backup plans will be capped like your character stats. When you think of playing and working smart, the game says no you should be playing and working hard. You cannot even avoid RNG at times, and will be forced to take the pain and death because RNGesus decide this will not be your successful run. In this game you do not make and solve your mistakes, you begin the game with a mistake to solve in order to become another mistake, With the current variety of gears in this game, I dare say that some of the gears are pointless as there is stats capped and even with the different classes involved, you will know that trying different build is not worth the time since RNGesus, once again, is involved and decides to give the same loot roll to you. Not that you can lock out the equipment that you are not going to use because of your party setup.

Long grinding game runs should not be a market of game's replayability. The variety of choices and different story quest pathlines should be what makes roguelike game value in its replayability.

I met a lot of people in my life. Some of them were rude and unpleasant. But none of those people spit on my face as this game did.
Its like joining your local cult. It seems fine at first glance, everything is so welcoming so you dwell deeper only to find yourself surrounded by crapload of unfinished ideas.
This joke of an adventure can be describe with one word -> "random". Starting this game is commiting to the RNGesus himself and his abyssal predecesors to find out that your warrior can't find through entire campaign single item and what is worse - this is your daily For The King. Shops are so randomized that only thing that is sure is that half of that items will probably be useless to anyone. After a few hours you will find ourself traveling to find very limited healing game is offering you.
But lets talk about enemies. At first lvls they have their gimmicks, they can be a problem but futher you go, you start to feel like lost peasant who meet a casual horde of rampaging orcs. Enemies hit like a truck that makes you wonder if you are supposed to be reincarnated in some neiche isekai after what they done to you and everyone of them is master swordsman who can't miss a single hit and is immune to every negative status to make sure you will feel the pain playing this game.
What is funny that im still playing this game and will probably play For the King 2. But im not playing it for fun, im doing this to feel pain, to gaze straight into the rng abyss and drag not only me, but also my friends into this unique experience that will make us all insane in the end.

This game sucks

[h1]From Kickstarter with "Love"[/h1]

Game looks nice, sounds promising - tabletop elements, multiplayer, several adventures to play, positive reviews...

So why there are only ~1000 players ever playing it?

[h1]It is not what it looks like[/h1]

This game is another grindfest for your time in disguise.
Except you are grinding for your own feeling of pride and sanity.

[i]I cant be that bad, right? I am doing something wrong? Game even says it's okay to lose my first adventure, I am surely gonna open few more power ups and get good![/i]

Nope, you are not.

People will tell you most basic things ever - "buy healing potions", "dont the party", give heavy hammer to your str hero. Whaow, high level tactics!

[h1]Game is very unfair toward players[/h1]
- Players roll seems rigged. You can regularly miss 3-5 concussive rolls per run with your main stat.
- Enemy stats are higher than players on the same level.
- Enemy abilities and items are better than players. They also allow themself to suicide just to stale the party. For example - wolves and some spirits will AOE drain your Focus on first turn. They have extra high speed, there is no counter to that.
- Enemy rolls seem rigged as well. I've seen one enemy roll 28 concussive success rolls, that was fun (reset-stun-damage combo).
- Healing is limited. Amount of damage you can safely take per encounter is limited, or you are loosing in the long run.
- Gold limited. Means town rest is limited too.
- Inflation means you cant save a penny, lategame tavern rest costs 250 gold.

The list may go on. As someone have already mentioned in another review - this game is lacking any feeling of progress. Enemies will always deal ~1/3 damage to your HP, unless hitting your main defensive stat and you are not nullified. Best case scenario it wall always take you same amount of turns to slay enemies, otherwise game will punish you for prolonging battles by dealing damage you cant recover.

By the time I got my "cool" 45 magic damage staff enemies have 180 hp and 20 magic shield. Not so cool.

The main lie this game tells you - is presence of options. You wanna win? There are no options for you.
Forget about such things as:

- Lifesteal, cure, protect, reflect, wet, ignite, bleed and many others. That's pure garbage, that will give you a hard time on mid difficulty and insta fail expert run.

You need: focus restore, reset, bash and some other top-tier weapons/skills.

[b]May I find this type of game fun?[/b]
Only if I am in SM mood with my toxic friends to laugh at our fails and wipes.
Would I invite someone I care about in this game or recommend it in general? Surely not.
Impossible to complete the game in standard difficulty, enemy stats rising too fast. Player defense can't keep up at all, mages are useless compared to melees cause the lack of armor and damage.

I find this game fun as someone who likes [i]the idea[/i] of D&D and similar board games but never actually gets to play them. The game can be approached with friends as a co-op adventure or solo as one of those turn-based RPGs with multiple combat units. It's been a good experience so far. As I write this my party and I are on the verge of completing the main campaign and defeating the final boss.

Everything in this game seemed well balanced, though we were playing on Apprentice so perhaps "Normal" difficulty might change this opinion. The weapons mostly all have their advantages and drawbacks. Firearms are very powerful but require a turn to reload. Some of the strongest weapons will shatter if you miss a roll (sometimes feels unfair). Two-hand is stronger than one-hand but you can't use a shield. Some weapons are weaker but apply DoT or some other ailment. Etc etc.

The enemy types are creative and are what's to be expected from an RPG of its type. There are around 30 base designs with some having regional and "difficulty-scaled" variants. Wizard Crabs are unexpectedly strong. I think the Scourges, various unique bosses that scale with difficulty and arise in random orders, are a nice addition.

The Chaos mechanic hasn't been much of a threat since we've managed to keep it down through various means. As I understand, if Chaos reaches level three, every few tiles will be monsters.

Overall I'd say For The King is a solid title; a good time with friends or family if you can convince them to try it with you. Use your imagination and see what kind of character you end up with. Although the RNG might set you back, just about any build is achievable. I'm eager to see what kind of team I'll put together in future runs.

P.S. It allows cross-play between Steam and Epic Games.

For the first 6 hours my friends and I had a great time, the game was a challenge but it was enjoyable and fair. But at some point in the game, the enemies just become super overwhelming. It feels like they are playing a different game then we are playing. 

Our "heroes" just feel like regular townsfolk who wondered too far out of the village while every enemy has 40 dmg AOE abilities that add a burn and take away your focus. Don't worry you can use your very limited God's beards that end up costing 200-300 gold at level 10 to heal every turn so you don't die. Every enemy is immune to 8 things, has physical and magical shields, and hardly ever miss their rolls. 

In my opinion, this game doesn't need to be a rouge-like. The game feels very long and tedious which is fine in a classic RPG adventure, but not in a game you have to restart when you die. Our 9 hour first run has exhausted me and my buddies. We don't feel satisfied about the 9 hours, in fact we feel like they were wasted, which makes us not want to start another run at all. I think this game is awesome, i really like turn based games and one i can play with friends is just icing on the cake. But with how much dice rolling and time each run takes, its just much too exhausting to put the hours in to get a lucky run to make it all the way. Give us a way to turn off the rogue elements and i would have a much better time spending hours and hours developing my character.

The game has a great concept, and there is potential for fun. However, I think the balancing is what really ruins it all. For many fights it seems the enemies aren't playing with the same system the players are forced to play with. They'll succeed every attack even stuns and dazes, despite those same options for players being much less likely without focus or very high stats. The only chance for success is either an insane level of min-maxing, or just an incredible amount of good RNG. There's no good form of healing for the players, and instead we're forced to rely on a limited form of resources that get increasingly more expensive. The random elements make some runs feel not worth it, and it feels especially bad to get hours in only to be put in a situation that's impossible to recover from. Even more so because you will be punished even if you aren't playing poorly.

Craziest turn-based rogue game I ever played.

- enemies spawn and despawn randomly
- random events, ambushes, curses determines you win or not
- dying = cant continue where you left

90% of the time it will be against your odd, you have to exit so the odds sides ya

It also uses accuracy for attacks. Lets say you have 80 strength, and the axe you use have 3 rolls:

- each roll has 80% chance to be succesful.
- 3 rolls succesful = full weapon dmg.
- 2 roll succesful = 2/3 weapon dmg.

Focus system is introduced to guarantee success for rolls.

Where to get health/focus is via herbs through killing things, bought at town or rest. Every supply is very important you need to prepare before you enter any dungeons. Once entered you either complete the dungeon or die, restarting the whole game again. Complete madness!

TLDR: unreasonably unfair RNG, basic mode is ok but the other modes are lame, buy it only if you plan to play at most 10 hours on the lowest difficulty

I think I can leave an honest review after around 150 hours, played all game modes in single and multiplayer and got all achievements.
The idea is interesting, the game appeals to tabletop enjoyers, but it is not very fun. Quite boring at the beginning until you unlock a few items, decent in the mid progression, boring again when everything is unlocked. Classes are not very different from each other besides some insignificant stats and some passives that never seem to activate.
The RNG is horrible especially on higher difficulties, sometimes it feels like it is not random at all. It feels like the devs wanted you not to have fun on a game you just payed for. Higher difficulty only means that your attack rolls fail more often, that's all. For example on the highest difficulty I had a character with 50% critical chance, but only dealt critical damage in 40 hits out of 200 attacks. This does not look like 50% to me and it happened in multiple runs.
The only way to beat this game at higher difficulties is to reload your save when any fight goes wrong (and oh boy, everything will go wrong).
The story is unremarkable, after 150 hours I can safely say that it is nothing that might be remembered even accidentally.
Maps feel quite the same, similar enemies, similar goal (beat that boss with huge health bar and no new mechanics compared to normal enemies before a counter reaches 4 for absolutely no reason), similar maps (one on normal land, one on snow, one in jungle, one on water, and a combination of all without a final boss)
The bonus game modes are garbage, infinite dungeon rooms (great! you took out the exploration from the game, sure, just delete the best part and leave the unfair RNG) and a 5 minute long pseudo-PVP.
Personally I think that games that have hidden achievements are just lazy and of course this is one of them. Feel free to disagree with me, i still think this is a small minus for some people.
I bet my left nut that "For the king 2" will be just the same regarding RNG and difficulty.

I love this game sooooo much. It's the perfect blend of rogue-like, Rpg, board-game and co-op fun-fest. I'm really excited about the coming sequel as well (so look into that!) but here's my review of the game;

Pros:

Big time replayability -- and if you like there is a cheap DLC that adds new campaigns and characters to keep things fresh.
Unlockables that encourage "One more Game" -- but if you can always play with other people who have other stuff unlocked to get a sneak peek.
Classes are variable and play differently, community that plays the game is instructional and positive -- unlike other games with community toxicity I've only had good experiences finding partners to play with.
Simple to learn but with astounding depth, game has just the right mix of intensity and humor to it.
Loot is fun, varied and very enjoyable and RPGs that get their loot systems right so much more fun!

Also a great entry point for RPGs and can be played both casually and very challenging depending on settings and scenario.

first off, look at my achievements. I beat it. Onto the review:


Slow! Interrupted! Petrified! Pierce Interrupt! Entangled! Unconscious! are just a few of the myriad ways this game goes out of it's way to stop you from playing it. And that's what most of the time the game tried to do. Stop you from playing it. 

oh and you can't do the same because about 75% of enemies are immune to stuns and daze. 

This game holds promise at first and keeps you coming with it's challenge, but after a while it gets boring. really boring. and TEDIOUS. I cannot say that enough, this game becomes the height of tedium very quickly due to the mentioned endless spamming of status effects, some of which have no real counter. 

Most character classes are hot garbage and not worth using and exist as little more than another attempt to steal your time with substandard characters. and you realize it's just a boring unbalanced mess of garbage that wastes what promise it holds

 And let's not go into how the developers abandoned the console versions which are like 2 years behind updates. but hey it's not like any of the updates heighten the experience. 

At the end of the game enemies are bags of health that spam status effects nonstop. It's cheap and boring. Don't waste your money on this junk. there's better roguelikes out there. MUCH better. 

Once the veneer wears off you see it for what it is.

It's got a bunch of funny dialogue, you can play online with friends, and there are many different campaign styles! It's also very easy to save and quit, so if you have limited time to play games, this one is ideal for you.

For The King is good looking, has good music... and totally misunderstands the roguelikes it's modeling itself after.  

This shows up in two ways: the first, perhaps forgivable error is to put everything on a clock.  You have only so many turns until bad things happen or the game ends.  While the time pressure in and of itself isn't bad - lots of roguelikes have a food mechanic to keep you exploring - one of the keys to success in traditional roguelikes is that sometimes it's better NOT to fight!  Tackling some really heinous monster might end your run, or if you survive, have to expend far too many resources like potions or wands to make the victory worthwhile.  Unfortunately, For The King is pretty bad about this: there are too many fights you absolutely have to have, because letting a miniboss run free would simply be too punishing.

The second, more fatal flaw: the game seems to be built around the assumption that you will shamelessly exploit mechanics that allow you to deny the enemy a turn or never let your own turn end.  A number of bosses seem to be designed to be unbeatable in any other way.  The two problems with this are that first, One True Build To Win is pretty boring; there's no room for creativity.  The second, fatal problem is that denying the enemy a turn/giving your side more turns is entirely gear dependent, since this is a roguelike.  You are 100% reliant on RNG (Random Number Generator) giving you the right puzzle pieces to win the game, and since you're on a limited map with a clock, there's no guarantee you'll get those pieces.  

This is, to put it mildly, incredibly frustrating and disrespectful of the player's time.  

There's nothing wrong with a game being hard, and there's nothing wrong with being heavily RNG dependent, but to have a game where the ONLY path to victory is dependent on the RNG giving you just the right pieces of gear is mostly just a timesink.  

Save yourself some time and roll a six sided die.  If you get a six, congratulations!  You beat For The King!

Summary: If you like the idea of a rogue-like tabletop rpg, with the story boiled down and the challenge high, then this may still interested you. It is fun + frustrating, a bit of a challenge for those interested, and that's a good thing.

I can't recommend the game however, because I found the artificial difficulty in the procedurally generated + a near 30% full system crash rate at launch to be beyond my threshold of tolerable frustration. 

Details: Honestly, my personal taste on the pitfalls of what I am deeming "artificial difficulty" should be taken with a grain of salt, obviously, that may be exactly what you are looking for. The part that soured me was after running into many situations in game where I felt that I was unable to proceed (which was to be expected, sure) I wasn't dead, and was left without an avenue to progress. An example of this is being in the bog and then surrounded by poisoned ground with absolutely no path to my goal. There are items to use to fix this, but having to move in then out then back into the bog, it quickly burned up my resources. Okay, rogue-like elements at play, fight-Die-Repeat, I understand. So, I take a break, let my stupid brain digest come back. 

The steel I-beam that broke the camel's back was in coming back and starting up the game, it was a roll of the bones on whether it would crash my system. That's a bit much. I think about who I could recommend this game to, and honestly, anybody I know who plays games would quickly get pissed at me for recommending this based on that experience, thus I am unable to confidently recommend, sorry.

So,
let me start with this:
This game is actually a blast, the only reason I am giving this game a negative review is because it has a mechanic that really annoys me when I run into them in games. But that is what reviews are, to state your opinion and preference of a game. So here we go with the good first:

1. I love the exploration of this game.
You can build boats and ships, sail across seas, fight Kraken and pirates, as well as skeletons and magical creatures; there is plenty of creative beings and lands to explore!

2. The loot itemization is also pretty decent.
-It's not like....Diablo 2 itemization, but it's still pretty good. There is always plenty of gear to find and you never know what you are going to get; there are plenty of different variations of items for you to be able to complete your build for your characters.

3. The builds are actually pretty cool and just advanced enough to be fun.
-As you play, you can start unlocking different character builds as well, which adds a much more diverse experience.

4. The currency is well balanced.
-I always seemed to have JUST enough for what I needed each play through I did. I was never super rich, but I was never super poor either. I could always afford what I needed without being seriously way to broke for something.

Alright so, out with the bad now....

1. The speed of the game:
-Ok, there is like....no chill in this game. Which really ticks me off tbh because the game is sooooo good otherwise. Unless you are decently smart and efficient about how you move and spend your time, the game entire starts making the enemies tougher. I am not sure what the point of this is, I already have a quest and am already battling enemies as it is. I get that my aversaries would normally be getting stronger as I also progress, but it just seems a little......too fast is all. I wasn't able to slow down and feel the adventure of the game because it seemed like every time I looked up to the top of my screen, the Queen was raging about how the darkness is spreading and I would get an update about how the enemies got stronger.

I understand the concept behind this, but it just made me feel rushed and anxious, it made me feel like I missed a lot and that the END was my only goal. The same feeling I get as if I were late for work.

Anyways, that is my only complaint, but for me, I really DO NOT like being rushed in a game.

I hop this helps for anyone considering to buy, if you don't mind the challenge of being rush somewhat against a ticking clock, then you'll have a blast with this game.

Happy Adventuring out there!
