It's for the king

Didnt even realize I hadn't given this game a review yet. 

Absolutely incredible co-op or solo roguelike table top-esk RPG.
It plays a lot like a DnD campaign without the roleplaying, you can move across the over world, explore, go to towns, buy boats, upgrade gear, fight stuff and level up or find a bunch of random events that can pop up while playing through the questline of a few different campaigns.

The game is slow, bad luck can ruin a run. But otherwise you've got a game you can play with your friends online, locally or even enjoy alone.
Each run will feel different, especially now that they've added so much content. There's multiple ways to play every class, mix that with coming across an gun and your blacksmith that used to be a tank is now the top damage dealer. Find a legendary glave? Your minstrel support is now a hard hitting melee.

The difficulty in this game used to be a huge turn off, I personally HATE really time sensitive games. Especially when RNG can slow you down in games like this. But thankfully you can change the difficulty. It wont be time sensitive where you cant waste time but you've BASICALLY got all the time you'll need. It's a very nice addition from when I first started playing this.

On top of that, there's some roguelike unlocks. I personally wish the classes were easier to get because when you mostly play with friends you dont want to go achievement hunting due to how long a campaign can take to play with others. I do like unlocking random events, visit structures, items, classes, cosmetics over time but the classes feel a little too important and add such great variety to the game to hide behind achievements and meta progression.
Now on meta progression, you dont really need the unlocks, it's just variety. Side grades to what exists. Maybe some of them could be better than what's in the game from the start due to some stats being better than others but i've beaten the game without any of them on a few campaigns. Outside of that there are some buildings that do make the game easier. But you'll get those unlocked before you have enough of a grip on the game to really win.

For a tactical rpg it is great, fun characters, fun outfits, tough but zany monsters. There is a problem that I hope they do not repeat for FtK2, finite healing. Each healing action, either individual or group heal takes one 'Godsbeard' herb to do and there is just not enough, there is just 3 in each town and there is a finite amount in each town which is never replenished. I understand the reason the mechanic, forcing you to explore, looking for new towns but time and time again I found myself being forced to go into the final battle with less than four godsbeard and i new that would be impossible.
If you are going to use this mechanic the at least have the towns refresh plus one healing herb per every so many turns once a town has exhausted theirs. Otherwise a refreshing and interesting game that I have recommended.

For The King is one of the best top down, D&D, RPG and Co-Op games ever made.

Pros,

Several campaigns, all of which are extremely well polished with an amazing difficulty curve.

The random loot system is probably on tier with Diablo, something that is strange to say but true.

The mild humour is both adorable, immersive and bonding with your Co-Op partners.

The lore store is quite possibly the best unlock system I have ever seen in a game. Play more, earn more lore, then choose to add various things to the maps, even those already started.

Spend lore on either more weapon and armour drops, cosmetic items for characters, random events and so much more.

NO microtransactions.

Limited DLC which only one person in the party has to own.

Awesome demi boss fights, scourges.

Awesome final boss fights which can punish you dearly for hours of work.

A fully custom economy system, how many lives you get and how the economy inflates.

Endless possibilities for character builds.

Funny and challenging enemy types within all encounters and dungeons.

Graphically incredible.

So much polish it will burn yout retinas.

WAND OF DEATH.

Cons,

The sequel isn't out until 2023.

This game is outstanding, if you have no friends, not a problem, play with three who are all you.

Take a bow guys, better than 99% of AAA releases, so much time and content on offer.

1000% worth a buy at any price.

~~ FOR THE KING ~~
This game has been an absolute blast to play with my friends. I've never had so much fun getting randomly destroyed.

Just shy of 6 hours in and I'm fairly satisfied. One thing that really sticks with me in these RPG/Roguelikes is the ability to experience various events and encounters. It sort of has a D&D feel but instead of one character you manage a 3-man crew, there is no carry weight so you can hoard as much loot as you want, the combat uses a sort of token system, and when a character dies you have the option to revive with one of your characters or to use a Life token, giving the game a better sense of progression without robbing you of your hard work.

I find there to be an enjoyable degree of content that keeps the player from feeling a sense of repetitiveness, although occasionally some events do repeat themselves. There is a wide range of options for adventuring between raiding dungeons and taking bounties against higher tier enemies. The Chaos meter adds a bit of extra challenge and reward by making targets stronger but also increasing the rewards after each combat session. Combat is fairly straight forward utilizing Focus Tokens to help with skill checks and land criticals.

My favorite concept is the fact that any class can utilize any weapon, and that each weapon has it's own set of abilities. Some are base attacks, while others have unique abilities that have various additional effects. Some items like amulets and armor also possess immunities to certain debuffs. Consumables consist of scrolls and herbs, with some unique items that have specific functions.

Overall I ended up enjoying For The King more than I was anticipating. I will be putting more hours in and eventually updating this review with some opinions on the end game. 9/10

An RPG, turn-based, board game - Best played with friends, but can be played solo.
Edit: What a champ, free cosmetic DLC's, only pay for content DLC's.  <- Perfection.

It can be difficult, the RNG can be brutal, but it can also be surprising, each play-through is different enough from the last to keep you replaying, and as you discover more characters and stuff in game, you earn lore books to add even more to the board.

There's a lot of crying about how a lot of enemies have different rules to the players, they can AOE debuff for example... Which isn't necessarily a bad thing, it keeps you on your toes. You can completely negate certain debuffs by finding and equipping armour that gives you immunities to it, which means you have to be wise about how you spend your cash so later on should you find that 'perfect item' in a random vendor, you can get it, if it doesn't drop from a boss first.
Should someone else get the cash or the item, well, you can help your teammates by throwing them that shiny sword, armour or cash at them, to work together to complete the game and teamwork goes beyond material gifts. For example: If someone has poison immunity, let them go first through the poison bog to dissipate the poison for you.
Tactically, it's quite in-depth.

Graphically polished, not bug free, but the only bugs I've seen so far are things like 'you completed this quest from the STR_DUNGEONNONEDISPLAY..." type thing in the quest text, very rarely.

A simple yet very fun turn-based RPG that provides a great challenge for casual and seasoned players alike. That being said even on the easiest difficulty it's still quite difficult if you don't prepare properly. Highly replayable as well as each of the campaigns have randomly generated maps so doing the same campaign multiple times is still quite fun. It goes on sale for about $6, and for that price i'd say it's very worthwhile. Pick up deluxe edition for the extra couple bucks as well as the items, two classes, and new campaign are worth the very tiny amount of extra money, about $1.50 on sale.

You have a wide range of classes to choose from which you can unlock as you play the game, although most of the classes don't seem particularly well balanced. Basically you're almost always going to be playing characters who have a high speed stat as they go first in combat, while those with lower speed only end up hindering you. Your damage isn't based on your class either, it's based on the weapon you're using. Only your stats which can help with accuracy and with getting better luck in the various random events, starting items, and passive skills are affected by your class, but ultimately speed reigns supreme which is a bit unfortunate. Plus nearly all of the classes play the game. There's no real difference between a strength-based character and an intellect-based character since all skills your characters have are based off the weapon you're using. A strength character could use an intellect weapon if they wanted to although they'd have very low accuracy with it. It would be nice if each class had some innate skills they could use regardless of their weapon (some like herbalist which has party heal do but its one of very few) rather than random passives that don't really mean too much. For example: The Blacksmith class being able to use a stun against an enemy no matter what weapon he's using as long as it's strength-based rather than it being complete rng what skills he'll get. I also wish that when you leveled up you could maybe get skill points to spend into extra health or damage or something instead of it just being a flat boost for all of your stats. That being said, I still do like skills being based off of weapons as it keeps things fresh as you play the game and replace your gear, I just wish it was a bit more complex.

The enemies and dungeons are well varied, and while the combat is very simply designed it's still quite fun and easily accessible for anyone unlike some other RPGs such as Divinity Original Sin (which is also a great turn-based RPG). It's rather neat that many enemies have special abilities like being able to destroy your items, steal money, or cause your character to flee combat. This however, sometimes can cause fights that are more difficult than they should be when you get an enemy that can destroy your gear, another that will steal your gold and flee with it, AND one that will do massive damage to your party, possibly killing someone all in the same fight.

The campaigns are all fairly enjoyable. The story is generic, but that's fine for a game like this. Each campaign has its own unique theme and mechanics, and combined with the random generation allows you to play multiple runs of the same maps and still experience something new, or at least, different. On top of being able to purchase new encounters on the map as you play, there's enough here to keep you entertained for a while. There's even an endless mode that's nothing but combat if that suits your fancy.

The balancing is a little off sometimes. I've mentioned classes already, but the rng in your campaigns can really screw you over as well. Entire runs can end because you didn't get a good enough gear drop and now you have outdated weapons and are unable to obtain new ones since you've cleared what dungeons you could and towns don't stock anything useful to you. Some status effects can completely cripple your run as well by nuking your stats or destroying good equipment you have. For the most part this hasn't been a problem for me, but it does happen on occasion, so make sure you keep backup gear with you instead of immediately selling it.

Overall, while not my favorite turn-based game it comes in a close second. It's a lot more fun to play with friends but still an enjoyable solo experience. I rate it an 85/100 due to it's cheap price tag and simple but enjoyable fun that provides a good challenge that isn't too bs... a fair amount of the time anyways. Points are deducted for your runs being heavily dictated by good rng and the necessity to grind at times in order to prepare for later parts of a campaign, and while for me this was only a problem some of the time I can very well see it being a lot more problematic for others depending on your luck. They are making a second For The King game, so it'll be exciting to see what they do with that when it comes out.

Game that has "open world" area and yet it punishes player just in case player decides to explore uncharted areas of the game. You may ask how it punishes the player? Well, this game has "Timeline" mechanic meaning that every day, the chaos will rise in the world which will grant additional 10 % hp to monsters. To get rid of chaos player must take bounty from a city. Sounds easy? Not quite, it is 1 bounty per city and so player must find new city that can give another chaos bounty OR if you are lucky enough you can stumble upon Chaos camp somewhere in the game. (Timeline can not be turned off/disabled)
Besides the chaos there are also other disasters, e.g Scourge 

Speaking of Scourge the timeline shows up weird icon that is slowly moving towards the player however there is no INFO about that icon what it is or what it will do, then a bit later game announces that "SCOURGE" is coming - "You have to deal with it fast before it appears in the WORLD", so i start to panic and looking where it is around explored area BUT nothing, until it actually appears and guess what it appears in uncharted area. Yeah great design.

This so called scourge is leprechaun and he is lvl 6 that is 2 levels above the player. I decided to give a try bit later and get rid of this scourge, brought entire party and we start combat however after few of his turns he STOLE all my GOLD from one character and fled the combat afterwards, that rose bit of frustration since gold is crucial in this game. I then thought "fine" i'll come back later and get that gold back.

Now, the problem is that i need to lvl up to 6 with entire party BUT all other enemies are also 2 lvl above the player and its not single enemy lvl 6 it is entire party of lvl 6. Pretty cool huh? Not only those enemies have a LOT more HP but also deal 2/3 damage to one of my characters - nearly instant kill.

It is nice that there are enemies that randomly spawn in the world however the rate they are spawning is insane, it is because the world is made like a maze and there is no free path to go, usually blocked by enemy. Often when player sets a path to one of characters and as soon as the character steps foot in next hex enemy spawns onto and sometimes there is no other option as "Defend" that means combat and since player controls each character individually, he/she must fight alone and again the enemy is two levels above the player.

Moved entire party to closest city healed them then set next destination and as soon as one of characters stepped out of city enemy spawned onto. Whats this? You just spent gold to heal? Nah, you will have to do it again.

Remember i mentioned leprechaun? That was only slight tilt for me, i had no idea what will happen next.
Then there are enemies that steal from the player not only it is gold but also consumables from inventory. And no killing the enemy who stole from you wont return stolen items or gold - they are GONE for GOOD.

For some reason even though I took entire party to start combat only 1 character was in. He was my tank guy, quite slow too for combat. He had to kill Acid Slime, little did i know that this slime applied ACID which results destroying random item. It destroyed two equiped items (ring+boots) and weapon+shield from inventory. Seriously such a fucking dumb mechanic?

Oh yeah, debuffs from enemies... Well, a really bad way to make this mechanic without getting rid of debuffs after short period of time. What i mean is enemy applies poison debuff which results in reducing overall characters stats BUT even combat is done the poison still persists and game does not show for HOW long poison will reduce my stats no fcking indication. Normally, in other games when something was applied to character it will wear off by itself (e.g. divinity II). BUT nah i guess devs want you to spend gold in order to get rid of it and again just by wasting time getting from point A to point B across the map to closest city so you can activate even more CHAOS IN THE WORLD.

My quest ended at the King's Maze fighting Undead Bisontaur, my party didnt had a chance seeing how AI perfectly rolled every hit without ever missing rolls. And at the same time interrupts my attacks. Im pretty sure that the poison was the main reason why i lost because that lowered chance to hit enemies, however that wouldn't be the case if PARTY HEAL could remove THAT DEBUFF.

So yeah, there is difference between game being [b]difficult[/b] and game being [b]unbalanced[/b].

If you like dice rolling/RNG reliant board games such as D&D then this is the game for you. 
For being early access this game really blew me away.

If you really like adventure turn-based games, then you'd love this game.  

Looting:  Personally, I enjoy looting in games and I feel that in order to make a game feel personal, you have to give a lot of customization options.  For The King does just that by allowing plenty of weaponry/armor/clothing character items and I was able to make all of my playthroughs an enjoyable experience. 

Adventure:  The adventuring aspect of the game was enticing from the start and with each new playthrough, more items became unlocked using a Lore (in-game currency system) and I had a better chance at progressing further into the game/campaign.  Admittedly, after over 100 hours of gameplay, I think it is safe to say that playing the same campaign was feeling slightly repetitive, but I took that as a chance to try different character sets/builds as a way to spice up the gameplay.

All in all, it's a great game! Definitely fun to play with a couple of friends and even solo.  I can't wait until the full game is released, along with more content.  Keep it up, but more importantly: hurry up, IronOak!

Edit:  Iron Oak delivered!  Additional campaigns and characters, new items and enemies allows for a great party-based RPG.

This is the closest thing to DnD you'll get as far as video games go. Yes I know Divinity exists and I know about Baldurs Gate, too. But what For The King does well is the bite sized story adventures, almost everything having a roll, and the never ending fear of team wiping!

Speaking of teams, man is it fun to play with friends. The only thing you can't do is cast guiding bolt on your friends, which is a shame. It's got tons of story options, every run is randomized, and it really pushes you to play as a team. 

The gameplay is relatively simple. You have encounters, events, and you fight through a series of bosses. There's a difficulty level for everyone, and you can even make a custom one if you need to (no shame, honestly). I've had a lot of fun with this game, and I'll continue to for longer. I highly recommend this game if you like DnD or story based battle games.

Initially I was quite enjoying this game, an interesting RNG system where you had the ability to force a limited number of successes in intense situations.  It felt like the type of games I enjoy where you are forced to succeed with a limited number of resources.  However, as I continued I found some aspects quite frustrating.

The game forces you to control and move characters around the map individually, I had thought this would lead to an interesting dynamic of splitting the group to get more resources vs staying together for a combat advantage.  In practice since health is such a premium resource I found that the cost in health for fighting things individually was never worth the tradeoff.  If I could keep my party together as a unit I would in a heartbeat as it would remove a 2/3rds of the clicking and time on the world map.  Eventually I chalked this up as an annoying UI decision that enabled multi-player control of individual characters.

The thing that made me put the game down was enemy ambushes.  Typically you can see enemies on the map and any unit within 2-3 hexes will be included in combat.  You can position your units to help on tough fights or try to split things up.  However when you are ambushed (which happens rarely but seemingly completely randomly) it will pull the one character into combat with the enemy and no help for other units standing nearby.  You better hope that it's a good matchup and not your physical tank against a magic enemy that will shred him in 2 attacks or so.  Things like this that seem to have no indications and no counterplay can just kill your characters and really soured what I felt was an otherwise interesting strategy game.

I feel like "fun with friends" is a cop-out phrase because literally doing nothing is "fun with friends". You don't get to take credit for that, game. It doesn't tell me anything to say that something is "fun with friends".

That being said if you have a couple buddies and you're looking for something to play, this is a quirky little co-op tactical turn-based RPG that y'all can kill some time in pretty easily. 

I'm not going to lie, I don't really remember what difficulty settings we played on, but it felt like it was decently tuned if maybe a little harsh. You can get majorly screwed over by RNG in this game, straight up, and while it's funny from time to time you *might* find yourselves a bit frustrated at times. On the flip side it's got a few tiny moments where everything is coming up aces and you're in tune with your co-op partners and the combat can feel pretty good.

The biggest problem is that you're really going to run out of game pretty quickly here unless you *really* enjoy essentially the same game over and over again as different classes. Once you've basically got everything figured out the novelty wears off, at least in my opinion. 

I've never once endeavored to play this game in single player mode, it's probably fine? I could not imagine it gripping me without having people to talk to and cooperate with.

I mean full stop it's worth the money if the concept sounds appealing, you'll get a solid week or two of game nights out of it and move on.  I haven't looked into the DLC and well hey, maybe someday?

The game is fun initially, but RNG is poorly thought out and that ruins the experience over time. Rolls are not fair, probability is always against you. The game feels awesome until you get to a point where you have like 95 strength, is 2 hours deep into your campaign and then completely fail a roll with a 5-roll weapon that, according to probability, is only supposed to fail all 5 tests 0.25% of the time. You think to yourself "hmm that's fair, 95% per roll is not the same as 100%. My rolls will fail every now and then". Then you get curious, decide to test it out and reload the game just for that purpose, believing you won't see such an occurrence again so easily. Nope, you try the same roll 10 more times and it fails in 4 of those. That's not 0.25% chance. It COULD be, but try this type of thing enough and you'll see the probabilities don't match what's on screen. The numbers just don't feel right, what you see is NOT what you get. That creates a lingering feeling that difficulty feels unfair. The "challenge" can't be countered because it's embedded in almost every action the game offers you. If the game decides it's time for you to have a full battle of unlucky rolls that will cost you hours of gameplay, that's what's going to happen. Doesn't matter what you do against it. That's not to mention some other utterly weird decisions by the devs — I still don't get why you need to roll dice in order to move your characters on the map, it just makes the game slow down to a drag and feel frustrating. The UI is horrible and looks super lazy. Animations take way more time than needed, even when you speed them up. Runs feel largely the same every time, there's little variation in what happens. You unlock tons of stuff in the Lore Store only for those items to never show up in any of your runs. There's lots of potential here, but the lazy execution from devs cutting corners unnecessarily hera and there just throws me off completely. I felt like this was a magical experience for a while, but the more you play it, the more glaring the game's faults become. I'm out.

I do not recommend this game. While the general concept of the game is at first extreme fun, the experience overall falls apart with the very poorly done weapon and enemy design.
 There is hardly any tactics involved in building your character, as often you just have to decide gear based on damage numbers. While that is not bad itself, the fact that your skills are determined by the weapon, whereas many skills simply have no viable late-game weapon, means that there is virtually no variety whatsoever in your build choice. 
 As for the enemies, most enemies either have extremely unfun gimmicks such as avoiding anything that wasn't blessed by perfect RNG, or have AOE-damage and AOE-debuffs. Also, the prior problem with skills kinda gets negated by enemies, since most enemies are straight immune to whatever status effect you can apply, even if that basically leaves tactless attacking as your only option. This is managable but it is not fun. It causes high difficulty but not one that is challenging and satisfying, rather it is obnoxious and frustrating.

This game begins with a warning to expect to not succeed, this would lead you to believe it is a hard game. I suppose it could be called that if you count incredibly terrible RNG as difficulty. The game itself is not difficult, it is a standard dungeon crawl for the most part, and it's not even that long in any of the campaigns. However, what artificially lengthens the time you play this game is that you live and die by rolls that are plainly stacked against you. You can play as good as you are able, you can make all the right decisions, you can even have the best gear. But they will not save you from an enemy that rolls good, (and they roll better than you can ever hope to), has better abilities than you, and has far more armor and damage than you could ever hope to come close to achieving. 

There are other things that add to this game being so much less than it could've been. All the characters you can unlock with in game currency (Lore Points), or random encounters, are all worse than the ones you start out with. Some have good gimmicks but that is all. Every seasoned player will tell you that the optimal party consists of the 4 beginning classes. Some of the best items in this game are the ones that you will find early on. As the higher tier items trade accuracy for damage, and even maxing out the stat required to effectively wield it will have you hitting less than half of the time. Monsters are always faster than you, at every level, the only exception to this is the Hunter sometimes. Combine this with the fact that they do absurd amounts of damage, have a tendency to dogpile a single character, and you can occasionally see one of your party members die before anyone of you has gone. The game is also heavily biased towards playing with multiple people, as singleplayer controlling 3 characters gets very frustrating and while i have no way to verify this, i always seem to have the worse luck when selecting singleplayer as an option. 

Another horrible thing about this game is the abilities. Inherent to characters, gained from items, and attacks derived from items themselves. Inherent abilities are incredibly unreliable, and have a tendency to proc when they are the least useful, and for the ones that proc on attacks only do so on perfect rolls. The attacks gained from items are middling with either a high number of rolls to achieve full effect, or low damage otherwise. For some reason this game seems to hate it when players use defensive abilities but loves it when the enemy does. Commonly you'll see enemies with full party buffs that have very few rolls, while you as a player require double the amount of rolls and only targeting a single player. There are exceptions of course, but they're very few in number.

This game could've been spectacular, as the core mechanics of the game are very appealing on the surface. As it stands the game styles itself as "difficult" but the most difficult thing about it is finding people who can stomach playing it. This game is more of a loaded dice rolling simulator than a dungeon crawler.

This game is a ton of fun, only played about 12 hours but I really enjoyed how much there is to the game.

I would highly recommend playing this with friends!

I was really enjoying this game up until a known bug which causes the graphics and motion of the game to be incredibly slow, basically slow motion. After reading up on possible solutions, this is pretty much something that has nothing to do with the state of your computer, and is a graphical oversight of the devs, wherein the game will open multiple menu pages without displaying them, drastically slowing down the in-game experience that you can see. To get the final boss yet unable to finish this fight and the game as a whole, is very very disappointing and frustrating. It is such a shame, that despite the many reports of this bug and the amount of time the game has been out to the public, that the devs and team at Ironoak do not seem to care or have made any effort to fix it.

The game, after a while, will just slow down massively. The devs have no official fix and have since apparently abandoned this game. 
Gameplay is fun when it works, yet after just 39 hours of playing, about nine of them have been fixing this issue. FPS will suddenly drop to 5-10 after opening, despite it running at 60fps hours beforehand. Only fix so far is to uninstall, reinstall and repeat each time this becomes an issue.

Game's really good. Its got a lot of content, a lot of difficulty sliders and settings, and the DLC is fun, with an asterisk.

I only had one run beat the final boss on Journeyman, which is the "normal" difficulty, on the default campaign. It required a lot of luck for the perfect weapon setup, but once we figured out how to out-cheese him, we got there. Technically you're supposed to die to him, so being able to beat him with a bit of strategy and a lot of luck is nice.

The game can get really difficult, because its definitely unforgiving. A missed roll at the right time can send your run on a doom spiral, but IMO thats fine. A fun loss is way better than a boring win.

My biggest criticism is that the DLC works in a weird way. If you buy it, it injects *all* of the monsters into the normal game, even outside of the DLC campaign. Theyre a significant difficulty jump, which can lead to some unfair feeling situations. It'd be a lot less frustrating if you could just toggle whether or not you want to see dlc items/monsters, but unfortunately that's not the case.

I was going to write a big review and explain all my viewpoints but it was getting wordy and I was loosing my thoughts.

Basically, the game is based on RNG to a fault, and you can play with 3 characters, either solo or multiplayer and not doing so puts you at a disadvantage. At higher difficulties it seems you're forced to use meta combos and weapons instead of what can be more enjoyable, funny or cool, as getting later into the game basically denies you all forms of usability in weapons that aren't just 'blahh I do damage, blahh I have 1 check and deal pierce damage'. The game is objectively unfair as the enemies you fight can do things that are impossible for your character to do, and hit RNG checks that are statistically impossible for you aswell. Level ramp up feels imbalanced as later on its not uncommon to be dealt half of your health just because Mr. rock man can consistently hit all 5 checks on a heavy attack that with max probability you couldn't dream of getting more than 2. Shop prices ramp up aswell, but gold ramps up decently to compensate but feels unnecessary.

These seem like alot of complaints, but I do find the game genuinely enjoyable as my review status shows, and in the grand scheme of this game its not that much, just minor annoyances viewed through a microscope just to see the problem and overall I would recommend you play this, just try to find a couple friends willing to join as it makes it so much more enjoyable.

(Some of these points were brought of by people I've played with, not by me, and are included because I agree with them)

An interesting take on rogue-lites in the DnD format.  This game is considered hard, with two ways to improve:
1) Git good, which means understand the min/ max strategies, best armor/ weapons, worst enemies, etc.  The games randomness frequently overwhelms your control, but your control is mostly defined by your classes.  The designers did a good job of making every class viable (in theory), but really reward you when you select an appropriate mix of primary stats (going with Intelligence + Awareness + Strength, for example, allows you to almost always find a use for new equipment/weapons, while going all Hunters / Awareness means you compete amongst yourselves for weapons and fail int/str checks).  From there it's all about learning which enemies to avoid, since the wiki is only half baked.

2) Lore store is basically locked content that helps you.  So for a game designed to be hard when you first start out, they actually just gate you via the lore store.  You should unlock all encounters ASAP.  Unfortunately, the game doesn't tell you how to unlock them all, and they don't all match up with achievements, so you have to look that stuff up on the wiki.  Also how to best grind lore (play on master and defeat the first chaos camp, then quit before ending your turn to repeat it endlessly) so that you can pay for the unlock once revealed.

In the end, the story is meh, there are no cutscenes and it is just playing out the repetitive mechanics of the game.  The favored strategy for beating the hardest difficulty is hoping to get the right weapons to enact a cheese (group reset or group rush), because the game itself so often cheeses you to your death.  So it's tactical fun progression offering medium depth, but nothing deeper.  I've enjoyed unlocking it all solo, but it's more frustrating than fun with friends.  Get it if you can live with unlocking everything except for beating the hardest difficulty.

This game is a perfect combination of rogue like, co-op, turn based, table top, RPG and open world. 

 Every play through will be different. The rogue-like style to this game adds so much replay value to it. Topped off with the addition of the Lore Store, a place where you can unlock then buy new equipment, in world encounters, locations, classes and more for use on your next journey. 

Each campaign and game mode offers a great variety of obstacles that will make you adapt. From dungeon crawling, land and sea battles, survival in winter lands and more. There are also affordable DLC's that are great!

The combat and levelling system is pretty standard and simple but also in depth enough to keep you interested. There are lots of weapons, equipment and clothing to make use of. 

My only problem with this game that with the new addition of the "Lost Civilization" DLC there are new enemies that have been added to the game that you will come across in your campaigns. While this shouldn't be a problem, it seems as if the new enemies weren't properly balanced or scaled in terms of strength.

Very fun 2-3 player party game, a go to for me and my friend. You can also play solo and control the 2-3 characters. It can be frustrating at times since with RNG, the game may decide that you're just gonna die. The game is great and you should give it a shot. ---UPDATE---
The below review is still accurate, although I did play coop. We found a way to abuse saves, this way we can retry when we are super unlucky, making the game fun. I encourage you to cheat.
------------------

(This review is mainly meant for devs to improve the game)
This review is spoiler free, though I will talk about some game mechanics.

The game is ridiculously unfair. Lets go step by step together to see why it is so.

First, ailements (burning, frozen, etc):
- Shocked basicaly means my character (most often my entire team) cannot do anything for multiple rounds, since not doing perfect barely does any damage and no effects. Shocked needs to be nerfed heavily, wether by making it last only a round (still plenty strong) or changing it so its not guarantheed to "shock" you, 50% chance could be alright.
- The fact that ailements are temporary is NOT explained anywhere or not obvious enough. I lose a couple of my first runs because I kept paying to remove poison for example.

Second, curses:
- All of them have the same issue, they are permanent unless you pay to remove them. But then you have to walk all the way back to a town (or have one of the rare items which can remove curse). The issue here is, it is very commun to get cursed, walk all the way back to town to remove it and then get in an encounter just outside town and be cursed again. Ok, so what do I propose to make curses more interesting and less rage inducing? Make them temporary, its that simple. Curses got annoying and  game breaking to the point where the only way forward was to stop curing them. I ended up with 6 curses on my blacksmith, luckily for me none of these was affecting his strength.

Third, the lore store:
- Most of the items you can purchase are pretty meh.. like I wouldn't even want them in my game even if they were free to get. So why would I pay for them at all? Point is, I won't, but thats very disappointing to see.
- The 'Yes' and 'No' buttons are reversed when buying. It is ALWAYS 'Yes' then 'No', never the opposite. This small difference from.. well every game, application and everything that exists, made me purchase something I didn't want by accident.
- There should be something to tell me or at least give me a hint of how to unlock something in the Lore store. I really want to unlock more classes (hoping they are good enough to make the game playable), but I have absolutly no clue how. I will have to google it.

Forth, monsters:
- They do an excessive amount of damage, and I haven't even tried the other difficulties yet. A normal monster I encounter, when he is alone too, shouldn't be able to kill one of my characters in a single turn (from full health) yet it happened, multiple times. And yes, I was the same level or above as he. Theres also that monster (no spoiler) which did 50 damage to all members of my team + status ailement in a single turn and did it pretty much every second turn. Enough example, the excessive amount of damage enemies do, and I mean all of them from start to finish, are about 25-50% too high, depending on the monster. Yes that much. Lets remember here I am talking of easy mode, it should be clearable by a child after a couple tried (10-20 maybe), but here I am planning each of my move and calculating the odds of everything trying to min max the game and still getting crushed by a random bat in the forest. If this game is meant to be this impossibly hard on easy mode, well this is a bad game design, because it really limits who can and cannot play this game, which is a terrible shame.

- Enemy ambushing is terrible. When your only option is to Defend and you were walking back to town to heal, what are your options now? Well die of course. I am not saying enemy ambuses shouldn't exist, but there should be an option to attempt an escape at least. Even if it has no probability, it will at least offer the possibility to spend focus on a possible escape and save that character from dying. Dying by ambushes is common because it most often seem to happen when your character is not quite close enough to your other characters so he fights alone.

The last boss:
Well I was excepting harder seeing how the whole game was way too hard. BUT you absolutly need to modify him. Why? Well it is not very fun to watch him take 8 turns in a row, but I can do a single action. Yes 8 turns in a row. Thats my personnal record. 

Life steal:
- Another thing is you shouldn't have (ever) attacks heal for the same amount it did in damage, specially since it ignores armor. Monsters healing mid battle is incredibly powerful, I would gladly kill one of my characters to have a weapon with such abilities. Enemies with said ability are amongst the hardest since you cannot attack them first (too tank because of their healing), so they destroy you while you try to clear the other mobs. Even when they are alone, they are a challenge if you do not always get perfect rolls to kill them quickly. It should heal at most for 50% of damage dealt. Though, it the monsters damage are nerf (has mentionned above), life steal could very well be in a perfect spot.

0%:
- Once I had 93%, 7% and 0% odds. 93% being the odss of a perfect roll and 0% of a critical fail roll. And yes, I did get a critical fail roll at 0%. If it was 1%, sure thats very bad luck, but 0%? Thats plain magic. This NEEDS to be fixed.

Coop:
- I haven't personnaly played the coop and I don't think I want to. Why? Well the game is WAY too hard as is, if we were to split just a tiny bit (you know since every player wants to do his thing and not just follow Player 1 right?) we would get obliterated even within the first or second area. This wouldn't so much a problem (though could still be) if the game difficulty is readjusted with the changes above, but mainly reducing enemy damage. As the game is right now, it is NOT a coop game, it is a game where you get to do the clicks the Player 1 wants, because otherwise you lose.

Loot:
- I do realize the game just came out so I expect for divers loot to be added, but I thought it mention it anyway. There isn't much loot variety. I ended up with the same helm of my three heroes and sold 3 more of the same helm. There is a bigger variety for weapons however which is good.

Breaking weapons:
- I did not use them once, why? Well, most of those I got weren't better than my regular weapons, which makes me wonder why they aren't better? But some of them are indeed interesting. The main issue with them is, the game doesn't explain what happens when they break mid fight, does it make your character unable to fight for the remaining of the battle? If it does, I am never using them. If it doesn't, it should be made more obvious.

Ending:
- THIS SECTION HAS A MINOR SPOILER, when you see the heroes statues, it really feels weird that they do not represent your heroes at all. They gear is different, they appearance is different, everything is except gender and class. This is obviously not major BUT it did ruin my joy of finishing a game because I was focused on thinking of how inaccurate the statues were.

Basicaly, it is a game with a good concept. But it needs some rebalancing to be enjoyable. I played 14.7 hours and I cannot say I enjoyed most of it. A major part of it was raging on how inbalanced and unfair the game is. With the current game balance, I cannot recommand this game. HOWEVER, if future patches fix said issues, I will modify my review and probably recommand the game.

[h1]For the Kings (3 of them)[/h1]
For the King is a turn based dungeon crawler, you fight monsters, complete quests and collect loot. 
This game is VERY team based and literally requires three players to complete, learned that the hard way. 

It's slow paced but addictive, feels like playing a board game or dungeons and dragons so slow is not a bad thing here but allows you to relax and build yourself and your team mates for your best chance at survival. Bring friends or play solo so you can control all players.
Normally I'm bored of any new game after the 2 hour mark during a session but this one 3 hours can pass easy before you even realize. Shows this game has staying power and is just a fun rewarding time that teaches you teamwork. 

Lots of game modes, unlocks for items, cosmetics and random spawns during the game.

Small bug with online where people can only join your lobby sometimes and most often when everyone is in the main menu at the same time or restarting the game/resetting the lobby.

First and foremost For The King is a unique game, I can't really think of another game quite like it, it has achieved a good balance of several different genres of games that gives you a truly one of a kind experience.

Now the game is difficult, I won't lie. At times that can be frustrating, especially if you've just spent the last 8 hours or so getting to a certain point before dying/losing. But the game does not take it self too seriously, it's full of silly gimmicks and small lines of dialogue that make you naturally want to take it less serious as well reducing the impact of losing. And more importantly it makes you think and re-strategize. It's fun to find new team builds that can "cheese" the game in order for you to win. 

It is also much more enjoyable playing with other people. It's great to sit down with a couple of your close friends and just relax playing some FTK. But it still can be fun by yourself and shouldn't discourage you too much from buying it. As it's essentially the same, but your just playing 3 characters instead of one. Though gameplay can be a little awkward with just 2 players.

All of the adventures available in game are fun (Except for gold rush or whatever it's called) and change it up just enough to where you won't get tired of the same formula of game-play. And the cosmetics in the game are just generally silly and cost no actual money. The lore store is a fairly interesting way to make playing you next adventure different, or give you something else to work towards. For example trying to find a specific item you bought on the lore store because you know it will be helpful in fighting a certain boss. Or maybe collecting enough lore points to unlock new encounters, or a specific cosmetic you want. The same can be extended to the DLC, which is worth every penny.

That being said there are some downsides to this game. The first being how much time it takes and pacing. The game is slow paced, it takes hours to go through even a mildly successful run. Not to mention once you've lost, you've completely lost and have to start over. As I stated earlier, the game is hard. But there is a save system so you don't have to sit down for several hours at a time to play, you can split you game up into several 1-2 hour days. And, most of the time you will have gained lore from a failed run and can use it to help you in the next run, giving you a sense of progress.

Another downside is that, at the end of the day, this game is based on luck. Just like any other video game based on RNG, sometimes you just lose. You can strategize all day, reduce the chance of something happening as much as you can, but the game usually prevents 100% guarantees. For example when you attack with a weapon it shows you your chance (%) of hitting a creature with it. And this percentage scales with a certain stat. Stats max out at 95 giving you at most a ~90-95% of hitting. Which is good, but not 100%. Now there are exceptions when it comes to using focus, but yet again focus is a limited resource that you  can only get back through in game money, or more random chance. With that all being said, the random chance in this game is actually fairly balanced and can give it a fun twist, especially when luck works out in your favor. But, if you are someone who seeks out skill based games to avoid RNG, then maybe this game isn't for you.

TLDR:
For The King is a great game that will entertain you for hours on end, especially if you have two friends to play with, and if you don't mind relying on a little bit of luck. It can be frustrating and slow at times, but it gives you a sense of progress and let's you discover new and fun ways to try and beat it each time.

Game is very fun. It is a hextile, turn taking, board game style world navigation,  xcom/darkest dungeon style roguelike dungeon combat (without the roster mechanic) 3 player RPG.  There are several different campaigns and game-modes with different mechanics and various difficulty settings to challenge yourself with.  You can collect lore points by playing the game to unlock new starting classes, cosmetic items, and various NPCs, events, and items to add to the list of possibilities each playthrough.

If you choose to buy don't forget to download the free DLC's for additional cosmetic items you can unlock in the lore store.

Unless you like investing a few hours into a run/characters you like just to have them all die to some unbalanced progression, I wouldn't recommend it. The combat ramps up exponentially while player progression is very linear, it feels like you're always faced with impossible challenges far too early. I've tried different tactics, from just rushing it to spending more time on side quests but the rewards don't level the party up enough to make it worth it. There is a timeline of random terrible events that happen so if you spend too long leveling up, the game shits out some game ending boss. 
If we kept something between runs to advance our abilities in the next run maybe I could understand why it gets so impossibly hard so quickly, but you don't. You just have to build a new party and set out on another doomed-from-the-start adventure.

Evidently you have to be a masochist to actually enjoy this game. Every attack you make fails while the enemy gets perfect hits every time.  The few times you actually do get an attack the enemy blocks it. You have as much health as the enemy, but no where near the hit potential they do. It's ridiculous.

I played through it about 10 times all last roughly 10 mins a piece tops. The only thing you can actually kill are the wolf/lions? Cant really tell what it is. However, they are the only animals alone and when you go 3 on 1 you might get 2 attacks in before he has half your team almost dead. If he has any other support you will just out right die. Not because of bad choices you made. However, it's because while the game tells you that every pip is a 75%+ chance of success it's more akin to a 10% chance of success. Considering over 90% of the pips will fail out right. Only way to off set this is by using focus on every strike. However, each character only has 3 focus points so attempt to "manage" this is impossible just use them all then camp. Hopefully you get enough gold to go into town every other turn and mediate you will never have the focus needed to kill the next enemy. 

Forget using decent weapons that they give either. Because the very first attempt you 1 pip of 85% success right will fail and the weapon will instantly break making it impossible to actually use and see how effective it is. 

My suggest, buy a bat (much cheaper) and beat yourself up. Much more fun then this mess of a game. IMO

Disclaimers so people know though:

+Completing a campaign can literally take 6 hours. 4 if playing with people who are experienced. If playing with others you really need to make sure you have a serious amount of time free. People will get annoyed if you want to start a campaign with only an hour free and then bounce.

+Some people enjoy this game solo but on the official discord voice chatting with others is where the game shines. If social interactions with new people generally give you anxiety then you may want to pass.

+There are quite linear optimal ways to play. So if you want to be creative and experiment with lots of different builds this isn't really that type of game. You pick a class and you will generally pursue your primary stat/gear 9/10 times.

What do you get when you combine a number of different game elements like For The King? An interesting rogue-lite - that's for sure. 

Begin the game by creating a party containing up to three members, pick a class and customise them if you like. You roam the overworld using movement points that are rolled each turn - you defeat enemies (using different weapons which all have their own abilities), complete quests and work through the story of the campaign you're in. You can also collect gear and unlockable tokens for future runs. Once you're defeated, you can spend your tokens to unlock new events on the map, items and more - making future runs more in your party's favour.

I got it on sale and no regrets. Would definitely recommend. There's a number of campaigns with the base game, all with varied difficulty modes. Along with the DLC, it makes for plenty of varied game play if you're into it. If you've made it this far and haven't decided - do it!

Game balance is all kinds of out of whack. Playing the easiest mode on default rules is really fun, for the first hour or so. You win fights, take some damage, get some stuff, cool. After leveling up a couple times and going to the next area, things get really frustrating.

As turns go on, one mechanic is that certain enemies will spawn that cause negative effects. To clear this, you have to go to where they are and beat them. One of these makes it so that item drops can just get stolen. And where these spawn is a bit random. So, having a mini-boss that steals my items from across the map is really, really frustrating. By the time you get to and clear the first one, the second one spawns (in my case, it just spawns 3 ghosts after each fight that give nothing, so you just take more damage after a fight at best).

A lot of enemy mechanics also get really frustrating. I.e.: Enemy confuses you ENTIRE TEAM, making you lose control. So, 2 characters flee, leaving a single character to do a random attack and get hit by 3 enemies. There is also a mechanic called "focus" that lets you guarantee a single success (an action can require multiple successes to get a perfect roll). However, a common ability enemies have is to just drain all focus from a character. Since many abilities REQUIRE perfect rolls (for armor ignore, igniting enemies, splash damage, etc.), giving a mechanic to overcome RNG a bit only for an enemy to block access to it is really frustrating.

Overall, if you enjoy really difficult situations that you have little to no control over, this can be a fun game. It takes too much control away from me for my preference, however.

I love the turn-based combat with ragdoll physics, more games should have it.

The systems are not very complex unfortunately: your main goal is to max 1 stat on any character so they can exceed at whatever their job is (all combat and non-combat actions are determined by dice rolls and the respective stat).

In order to keep you engaged it has to play with breadth rather than depth, but so far it has done a great job at that, and if I didn't have such an irrational fear of "finishing" games, I'd have played it a lot more already. Also a blast with friends in local coop every time

Impressive systems; challenging rogue-lite; RNG mechanics can be devastating but mastery comes from learning to utilize all you can to marginally improve your chances along the way. The many game modes that currently exist and the expanding world that evolves with your lore book allow for a highly replayable experience.

I greatly appreciate their smooth inclusion of local co-op, which many modern games have unfortunately forgotten.

Update: On the negative side, I was expecting more long-term support, but it appears as if content updates can't be expected into the future for this game as IronOak has expressed that their efforts have turned to new projects. There is plenty of room for growth as QoL updates, balance additions, and more general content, so it's unfortunate for the devs to leave the game as-is for so long but shouldn't be a deal-breaker to interested players.

This is game is a really quirky, relaxing or challenging (depending on difficulty), honest-to-goodness adventure game that never gets old. I bought this on Xbox and logged about 100 hours on that version (I recommend it on console but not as much as the Steam version since it has not crash; whereas console crashed several times a session); however, on Steam, it opened my eyes to the entirety of the game's potential and buyable expansion. While problems may occur, none of them detract from how much joy and excitement this game can bring within its fantasy world. The many gamemodes not only keep things fresh, but the in-game "Lore Store" allows you to unlock more characters, destinations, and events without having to put more money into the game. Not only does make this game a fun adventure with or without friends, online or offline, progression feels a little bit more meaningful as you toil and learn the nuances of turn-based combat with a plethora of enemies that will spring a new mechanic or status effect that makes you stay on your toes. Each difficulty is a whole new adventure that is not just a annoying cycle of BS or immense enemy health pools. Everything is meticulously designed, which is why I will be unlocking everything again on PC as I did on Xbox just because it is a joy to start from the humble beginnings and achieve everything once again.

RNG in favor of the AI.

After replaying in 2022:

It still has horrific RNG that entirely favors the AI. Enemies always go first, sometimes attacking twice or three times before your entire team makes a single turn. Enemies barely, if ever fail rolls. You fail rolls every other roll. I'd say half of the enemies have a one roll ability that always lands. You have around 3-4 rolls, of which 2 or 3 inevitably fail and cause you to do 2 damage. Even after wandering around the map, getting every person good gear and weapons, I fail to get past the glittering mines. It's wave after wave of impossible enemies while even with godsbeard flowing from my bags, I cannot survive. 

It's sad because the game is actually fun. But when progression actually matters, having RNG decide whether or not you repeat 3 hours of grinding over again is so boring and you'll most likely quit instead of playing another run. This is especially true considering the loot is all generic and doesn't do much for your stats. There's no legendary items that can give you the upper hand or interesting builds, it's a bunch of low tier stat sticks that you throw on your guys and hope to god it has some improvement on the tremendously shit gameplay you've been experiencing. Consumables are laughably weak and are walled off behind upgrading some obscenely expensive pipe. 

TL;DR: STAY AWAY IF YOU DO NOT LIKE RNG BASED GAMES. The game is entirely RNG, there is no "skill."

This is not a multiplayer game!  Difficulty scaling completely ruins both immersion and agency.  

I enjoy For The King's game mechanics. I like exploring the beautiful maps, leveling up, gathering loot, and completing the quests. I think this style of game has a lot of potential for other kinds of games within it (e.g. a Talisman style PvP mode).

I enjoy playing rogue like games and I also play a lot of complex board games, so For The King is really a perfect mix of the two.

That being said, the biggest issue and flaw is the difficulty scaling of this game. I play with an experienced group of friends, and we struggled to barely beat the first adventure on the easiest difficulty.

The game offers a 3 player co-op functionality, but this proves quite problematic if you want to play the Normal or Hard difficulties. The game's combination of timer mechanic, monster scaling with you, and economy inflation mean you can't ♥♥♥♥ around. You have to optimize every move. You essentially need to min-maxing every choice if you want to have a chance to win.

So when you're playing with 3 or even 2 players on any difficulty above easy, it's really not fun when you realize you need to tightly coordinate your moves to have a chance to win. It takes away your agency completely. This tells me the game was really designed for single player, and multiplayer was just tacked on. If anything, the difficulty scaling should be lowered if you are playing with 2 or 3 people, simply because your team won't always coordinate perfectly. And if your team is coordinating perfectly, you might as well be playing single player, because everyone's choices will be predetermined. This goes against each player controlling their own individual character--yes we should come together to fight the big bad, but each player is naturally going to want to spread out and explore on their own.

The map is quite beautiful and it begs to be explored. It's even funner when you can sail and discover islands, new continents, etc.. This exploration seems only possible on Easy mode. If you waste any time unnecessarily exploring, you'll likely get out scaled by the Chaos/Alignment/Scourge mechanic and lose the game. Why design such a beautiful map when we can't explore it?

On top of the timer mechanic, the game punishes you with the economy inflation mechanic. Buying basic healing items becomes prohibitively expensive in a short amount of time. Since healing is so precious, this discourages you from exploring, because it means you'll take damage that can't be easily healed.

What makes RPG/rogue like games enjoyable is the progression mechanic. As you level up, you get stronger and are able to take on more encounters/battles. Unfortunately, the monsters in this game level up with you (and will level up past you if you're too slow). Meaning you will always feel like battles are a struggle. This ruins any sense of progression, and feels like the game punishes you for even leveling up.

For The King dangles in front of you beautiful maps to explore, 3 player co-op, loot, leveling up, etc., but most of it you won't enjoy because you need to be consulting all the online guides to heavily optimize your turns to even have a chance of winning. This game feels more like Chess disguised as a medieval fantasy RPG.

I'd recommend the developers creating a more free form mode that lets players actually explore and be immersed in the world. At the very least, there should probably be more difficulties, like a Easy - Normal - Expert - Master - Legend, and then make easy/normal actually "easier".

Let me just say that I love this game to death. FTK has been the source of so many great moments in my friends group and many late night hilarity. We have been playing since the beta and fondly remember when simply getting to the King's Maze was a feat all its own due to the sheer difficulty and the mind boggling realization that the game continued after it. 

That being said, the power creep in Lost Civilization is enormous and, in our opinion, generally for the worse. I admit, the addition of the gladiator, arena events, and dual wield weapons were a great additions as well as wands and caster shields. But the sheer power creep of the Astronomer and its one shot passive and the item that has a 3 charge mead for your whole party matched with the sheer power creep of the mobs that you face simply for having the DLC makes the game more frustrating to play because it shoe horns you into a meta if you want to make any meaningful progress.

The challenge level is just right, but be warned... its RNG. Like every rogue-lite there is a chance you will simply have a bad run. I find however most my runs can be won or recovered from when it goes badly for a bit. This game takes intelligent thought to prepare yourself for boss fights within. Make sure your pipes are upgraded, you have your godsbeard and tinderkits. A well rounded party is a must so you don't compete for the same gear. The negative reviews I read seem to be people who have rogue-lites and didn't realize they were buying one... or complain about the UI? UI is just fine.

My only real complain about the game is the total incompatibility with modders, this is the kind of game that would THRIVE if they had made it friendly to modding but as it stands you can only find three pseudo-mods on Nexus that don't add content.

Its a shame really the developers are in it for the easy cash grab of DLC rather than letting people mod and generating a larger community.

TLDR: If you think you are a "super lucky man" and can overcome something so called "RNG". Then this is a perfect game for you (and your friends) to test your LUCK.

This game is fun, especially if you love board game and you have other friends to play with. But I cannot recommend it because "RNG" in this game is a shit.

When you first open the game, the game will tell you something like "Don't think you can success in the first run".
And YES! This is correct the game is very difficult. But most of the difficulty are come from the "RNG".

Most of the game play in this game:
Me: (95% successful rate) > OOOX > attack fail
Friend A: (95% successful rate) > X > attack fail
Friend B: (90% successful rate) > XOOX > attack fail

Enemy A: OOOOO > Perfect attack on whole team
Enemy B: OOOOO > Perfect attack with negative effect 
Enemy C: OOO > Stun whole team

In this game, nearly everything is base on "roll a dice" or "probability".
You roll a dice for your movement, action in combat, random encounter event, etc.
The game is trying to test your luck in everywhere, however "RNG" in this game is just a joke.

At first we thought we were just bad luck, but it was not.
The probability showing in the game is like a fake number, you probably fail most of the event and action with a very high successful rate (like fail an action with a 85% successful rate 3 times in a roll) .
But your enemy are not. They are like "super lucky god-like" enemy and can get a perfect movement in every attack.

There is no problem if they are really pure random. After ~30hours play time, I think the game is not.
I think the dev. just don't want to make a "EASY GAME" and add many "random" event to it. But I cannot accept that most of the difficulty is come from "RNG" and the "RNG" in this game is just a shit to fuck up your run.

If you don't believe me or think that I was just bad luck and suck in this game, go and get this game to try out your luck.

Meh it didn't quite capture me.  It was okay, but I think there are better RPGs, and rogue games out there.

The combat was okay.  But on the campaign map your characters can split up, and have different move values.  To keep them together in fights, which is what you want, you basically play follow-the-leader, but it usually results in waiting a turn or several for other characters to catch up.  It's sometimes convenient to go get loot to be able to separate.  But in general you want all of your guys grouped up and the individual movement I just don't like.

The quests aren't clear where you're supposed to go.  Where I got "stuck" it told me I had to enter a dungeon and hovered over a small town in the middle of the water.  Forced my whole party into the water and sailed all over the place and could never find it.  Went to the town, nothing, looked all around, nothing.  Went to the other side and kept on going.  Asked the forums later apparently it's just some small thing I missed that needs exploring to find or something.  Very unintuitive, and I am way too far ahead on the other side of the landmass now to go back. 

This whole game is predicated around a global timer, bad events happen every so often and you spend a good chunk of your time trying to avoid and push back those boundaries.  That means there's no going back, usually.  It means exploration has a steep cost.  I guess it adds pressure to a game that would otherwise be very easy if you could take your time.  But for the above reasons in my other paragraphs, it really doesn't fit well with the other mechanics.  Or those mechanics dont fit well with this time pressure mechanic.

Either way I would say pass on this.

This game is a lot of fun.  GF and I have spent 80 hours in it, which is one of the longest in all the games we've played together so far.  That being said, you need a friend or two who's willing to play for 3-6 hours at a time, which is how long a run is.  There's online mode, but I don't believe strangers will stick for that long and have the same level of cooperation.

There are many things this game does well.  Particularly I'd mention that the classes are well balanced and every class has its pros and cons.  For example, you may find Hunter well-rounded and stronger than others at first, but then you realize Hunter doesn't really offer any supportive skills and bows don't tend to do high damage in late game.

There are things I wish this game does better, which I will list below.  Despite these, I definitely recommend this game.
- Lost Civilization Adventure DLC shouldn't be on top of the adventure list.  It's significantly harder than others.
- Sometimes things are not explained.  Such as buffs and debuffs, some of them are not intuitive: being wet removes immunities, being frozen takes more damage, diseases changes defense and can spread, etc.  Most butt-hurt thing is the Witchdoctor lowers the whole team's pipe levels without saying.  For a long time I thought pipe was bugged.
- I know this goes against the boardgame style design, but I wished gears had variances.  The same knife is always the same.  Would be nice to be a bit different for same knife each time I get it.  Maybe numbers are different, or attributes are different.
- After finishing all the adventures, I already know what happens in them, I have already tried all classes, there's not enough motivation spend so many hours to play again in higher difficulties.  There's an endless mode, but it feels extra disheartening for some reason, especially when you get cheesed to the death (sometimes fights are unfair).  The adventures, including the endless mode failed to make me expect that a new run will be much different.  This may sound bad, but by the time you finish all adventures, the game has already provide many hours of fun.

One of the main aspects I love about this game is its decision making mechanics. 

When you're rolling for an attack or action, you have the option to increase the success of said role by expending focus points. This makes the game more controllable by the player's hands and makes you weigh your options more cautiously where one bad roll may end you up to a halting play through.

The game is exhilarating to play. If you're a fan of RPGs and Rogue-lites, this is the one.

This game is a lot a like Miitopia in gameplay, just a tad more manuel in the saving department. In order to save the game I make a desktop link to the steamcloud file of the game and a folder of my current save. The save is only recognised after you "save and exit" from the game and the game is closed completely with the "Exit" button or close out of the steam application of For the King. Once you boot the game back-up, then, the save should update on the steam cloud. This is when you copy the save from the shortcut (or from the cloud file) and paste it into your "personal save folder" ;)

Bought this to play with friends, when they moved on, I couldn't. 

My first serious attempt at finishing a Roguelike, and it was 50% fun and 50% pain, but 100% rewarding.

A really nice and straightforward D&D style game. Especially fun if you have two other friends to join you. There's like 6 separate campaigns in the game too.

I'd describe this game as Gen Z board game, mainly bc the overworld sports a board game aesthetic where players have to roll for movement. But unlike regular board games For the King has a plethora of locations and mini encounters for players to discover while exploring the map. Some of these mini encounters can also happen randomly, so player turns can end up being more interesting than expected.

While playing the game, you acquire Lore Books which can be used in the game's Lore Store to buy new character classes, special weapons, other mini locations, and more for future playthroughs. They're quite generous with giving out books too, so it doesn't feel like a grind to unlock things 

Character stats can be a fun thing to play with, and its always a good idea to have a well rounded team. One of the most fun stats that you can speck into is evasion. Towards the end of one of my playthroughs, I had a Hunter with 60 base evasion and a weapon that could increase that number to 95 (in other words, 95% chance to evade all attacks) practically making me untouchable.

You know what, we bought it in the sale, and we haven't put it down! A real gem of a 3-player game! If you have three of you in a discord and you're stuck on ideas, this is the one for you!
Annoying to play, shitty low-effort artstyle, feels like a mobile game.

It's a fun little game that suffers from a few too many oversights. 

Unlocked buildings and explore locations in the Lore Store can break and ruin the main campaign by overriding spawns for various important locations - like dungeons in Dungeon Crawl.

While this is a small issue in and of itself, when you've spent several hours playing this one campaign just for all of it to be for nothing, kinda sucks really hard. A real buzzkill. 

Now I feel reluctant to start any new campaigns because I don't want all my fun to be ruined by one small 'bug' of sorts. 

Also, this game is not suitable for two or less players. You really need a full party of 3 to really stand a chance at the many difficult encounters that do not scale to accommodate smaller parties. I have managed to succeed at the odd campaign with two players, but it does feel like an inexplicably harsh uphill battle and not a fun challenge. This was on the easier difficulties as well.

I'm also not a fan of the camera snapping me back and forth when I'm looking around the map, so it just feels a little clunky and counter intuitive at times.

Also, Lore Books aren't shared across players, so if I start the campaign and have a certain character slot on the character creation, I'll be hard locked into getting the first loot roll and never get any Lore Books
Fun game.

Fun casual couch co-op play. We tried using our phones as controllers with Steam Link but it was laggy and unreliable while also streaming from my gaming rig to NUC connected to the TV but using my wireless keyboard/mouse combo works well. 

While playing as two players on one screen it can be easy to forget whose turn it is and make an unintentional move. We haven't tried using controllers but it looks like control would be shared then as well.

I think this might be really fun to play with a couple of friends, but, as a single player, managing all of my party member's movement and inventory separately was mildly cumbersome and boredom set in quickly due to bland story and characters, both of which I think would be less of an issue if you were playing with others. 

The game is hex-based exploration and turn-based combat. While both are reasonably polished, neither was engaging enough for me to want to keep playing. Your characters have no personality and do not develop in any way aside from gaining arbitrary levels that give you more HP. Combat skills are determined by your equipment, and while in a way this was quite fun because it meant you were constantly trying new skills as you got new equipment, it felt like there was no real progression of your characters (this is true 5 hours into the first campaign, I don't know if it changes later or is different in other campaigns). 

Mainly, playing this game just made me want to go and play WIldermyth instead, because I missed growing attached to my characters as they developed in a bunch of unusual and fun ways, and watching them fall in love or become enemies or joke together. The main reason I didn't get on with For the King is because I felt it suffered by comparison, but there's nothing wrong with it, it just wasn't the game for me.

It is kind of a Heroes of Might and Magic mixed with a Baldur's Gate feel.  It's turned based combat, but each individual person in your party moves independently in the overworld (when engaging an enemy, a friend just has to be close by to engage with the current character, and I think this is something I dislike about the game.  I basically have 3 parties to attend to, instead of one.  Let me move around the world with one party.

There's not a lot of healing (except when you have the healing herb, just stock the fuck up on it).  It's really easy to play, but there's kind of a lot you have to manage.  Each character gets their own inventory and the "healer" can't heal someone unless they specifically have the healing herb in their inventory (can't heal if it's in another character's inventory, even if they are close by...however, you can trade instantly with nearby characters).

Overall, it's not a game for me, but I can see the appeal.  I feel you'd only be interested if you played the fuck out of Baldur's Gate and Heroes of Might and Magic.

Do you love the XCOM element of dying to an enemy when you had a 93% chance of hitting them with an ability and still miss every time? Does 5 layers of RNG per turn get you turned on? Is your idea of a good time getting a piece of gear, joyfully equipping it hoping it will finally help you progress quick enough to surpass the timer, then a moment later having a crab smash the everloving shit out of it so now your character is stuck naked and afraid in the middle of a fight?

Well boy, do I have a game for you! Initially the game is fun. Borderline addicting. However, as you try to progress, you are absolutely PUNISHED for any advancement by monsters immediately scaling up, costs of goods increasing, and a dozen different RNG shenanigans to wreck your shit 10 ways to Sunday.

The reality is, with some reasonable balancing changes, the game could be a 10/10. Hell, even an option to disable certain mechanics would make it more approachable. As it stands, I can't say I'd recommend the game, unless you're the kind of person who enjoys spending hours upon hours with your balls in a vise-grip.

”Joe Momma…” the creature whispered.
The man cried out in pain as he disintegrated into dust, and the whole world fell silent in fear.
"I did a little trolling." the wretched creature remarked before burrowing back into the earth.
