Well. don't judge it by the kiddy graphics.  In actuality and my opinion, they suit it. It gives it a relaxing feel. It's easy to get lost in.  Just old school, turn-based RPG (kinda lol).  One thing I didn't like was the time limit, but there are campaigns that don't have them, 3 I think, and you can jack up the chaos in the house rules and it's so much that time isn't a factor anymore really.

It's a little slow, and I do recommend reading the help manual because even though it doesn't seem to make much sense at the time, once you start playing it has that "Oh!  That's what that mess was about!" factor to it.  It is addictive, and a calm way to pass time as you will get pulled into it.  You just want to see how far you can get, or even make up your own strategies on how you want to play it.

I went into it happy it had full controller support, however once I started it became more of junky and awkward and then I had a Homer Simpson moment *DOH!*  It's basically point and click easy, I felt silly at this realization.

If you want a colorful way to be drug into a point click RPG style kind of game, this is it!  Beware, before you start playing or even start over after dying - they do have a warning telling you that you more than likely will not survive.  Don't be disheartened though, it's a totally chill and entertaining game if you're a slow paced RPG adventure kind of geek like me! :)

Gorgeous looking game, a lot of replayability, achievements, weapons armour and items to unlock. The game is made up of a handful of different campaigns to choose, the map is generated randomly each time so every game will be different even if the end goal is the same. Different campaigns have different mechanics, for example in the "For the King" campaign you get a bit of everything, while there is also a winter-themed expansion based around town sieges and cold damage, and an ocean-themed one that mostly uses the ship travel mechanic.

It's not really a game for people who hate rolling dice, every attack you make has a chance of missing that seems to be frustrating for a lot of people. It's also a game that puts you on a timer, you can't just grind your way out of problems - though with good time management you should be able to know when you can afford to gain a little more experience. I also wouldn't call it a total luck-fest (got to be sure I type that right..) because as you learn the game mechanics you find there are ways to mitigate bad luck, and play risk management. Of course, it's a double-edged sword - it's always great too when luck goes in your favour and you find a really powerful weapon for one of your heroes (like that awesome double-edged sword.)

I do think the game is somewhat unbalanced in the class system, basically I found the fast classes are the best because they can take out enemies before they attack, which is a lot better than being slightly more defensive and slow. Some classes added later like the Treasure Hunter have cute but situational abilities and seem way under-powered compared to the rest.

I probably would never have picked [i]For the King[/i] up if I hadn't got a big discount coupon for it, but I think it's a pretty good game, a solid "B" Tier in my collection. The unique visuals, humour, and the thrill of every run being a little different overcame the moments of frustration for me.
Remember this piece of knowledge and you will always succeed in your runs; Dragons are bitches.

I have a bit of a hard time recommending this game because there's a lot of problems with it. If you want a adventure boardgamey RPG to play with friends then you should at least consider it, because there's good stuff here. Even then be prepared, there are missing UI features which prevent you from doing almost anything during someone else's turn. You can't check your equipment during other people's turn, or see combat pull ranges, honestly I just pull up the browser on the other monitor to toil while I wait for my turn. Also it's unclear that a surprise event disappears if you leave it. The game gets better when you unlock things like new characters, events, and weapons (which has become a extremely common crappy mechanic that game devs think is awesome but really only serve to be annoying for first-time players), but at least if you are playing with friends it combines what everyone has unlocked. This is certainly a game I would have bounced off of if it wasn't for friends who had already unlocked things, and even then I only play it with other people as I do other stuff on the second monitor.

The enemy balancing is garbage. Enemies almost never miss while players miss when they shouldn't. Enemies move way to fast in the turn order with no way make it better, enemies have too many abilities, and for some reason, even though players need to get 100% just to make their abilities work, enemies often times do not. Unless they're normal enemies, almost none of them are fun to fight against.

The adventures are hit or miss. The normal one, dungeon crawl, and lost civilization are alright. The frost level is just annoying to play through. Not the hardest, but clearly needs work.

Into the deep was straight up amateur in its design. Unnecessary spikes in difficulty, uninspiring encounters that should never have been allowed except for the highest difficulty, with sluggish and obnoxiously crafted dungeons. You either can't play through them because you're level 2 and they're level 6 (which matter more than one would think), or you're at the right level but the overpowered enemies get to you after sometimes 5 rounds of combat. There is no way to heal consistently in between. And because everything is so unbalanced, you HAVE to rely on statues just get by. I shouldn't have to rely on an optional point of interest just to have fun with a campaign.

I won't comment on endless mode because I don't care about it, and probably won't matter much aside from completing achievements.

The stat system in this game is also awful. while the stats themselves are fine, they're no reliable way to level them up directly and relies way to much on weapons and equipment. And the accuracy system tied to is clearly not something the developers took time to think about. Everything in this game has accuracy slots that must all be passed to deal the full damage. higher stat = hit better. Except because the game RNG was made to fight the players instead of being fair or reasonable, unless you waste focus for basic attacks, you will be screwed not matter what.

And speaking of focus, it's a necessity in this game. You use for fighting and reaching places barely out of grasp. Too bad the game didn't come with a system to either have them regenerate over time or by day.

And the movement system is probably the second worst aspect of this game. RNG for MOVEMENT. Who thought that was a good idea? Just give the characters predetermined movement or movement that scales over time.

The random events are hit or miss. Not much to say other than, meh.

While this game is fun at stages, there is just so much wrong with this game. Unless you have 2 friends you want to play with (Which is way to small for this game. 5-6 should have been the cap), don't buy this game unless you're one those gamers who like rediculous and maddening odds, or mistake unbalanced, lazy, and poor game design (Mostly talking about into the deep) as "challenging." 4/10. Not completely irredeemable, but into the deep alone destroys most of the fun as it perfectly highlights the numerous and embarrassing oversights. At least its cheap. Cheaply crafted game for a cheap price.

Hard but addictive.  For The King is a dungeon crawl RPG that is constantly going to have you yelling at your screen screaming that the computer cheats, but you're not going to stop playing.  As you unlock more and more cool stuff from the lore store, like new classes and items, you can't help but keep going back for more punishment.

I am sad I waited 3.5 years to play this game. This scratches every rogue-like RPG itch out there. The amount of content and play styles are bound to keep me busy for over 100 hrs. You'll have to play and lose your first few games in order to learn the rules and collect credits to unlock extra characters and events. But that is OK because there are like 6 different procedurally generated worlds to play all with their own randomized content. My first 20 hours in are just from playing (and failing) the same world 3 times. If you don't mind brutal difficulty and learning through loss and you want a good rogue-like that sucks you in, this is your game. Honestly it's like a dream come true. Take you time to read the already well established intro guides out there, no need to recreate them here in a review. Give this a chance, you won't be sorry.

Quick update. I picked this up for the Switch, very awesome to play as a grab and go. However, there is a hit to in-game performance. Turns and rolls feel like they take longer to process thus making already lengthy games more lengthy, but the controller UI feels better than Steam's. It's not as bad as the slowdowns you get on Civilization, but it is still worth it in my opinion. Just note that there are no achievements for the Switch so Steam really needs to get that Steam Deck released

Hats off to the creators of this one. The game is extremely engaging and is ideal for two or three friends to have an excellent time with. This one should have you cheering and cursing with equal enthusiasm. They've captured most of what makes a tabletop RPG wonderful and added on to it here. The art style and relatively simple character design are a plus here, given the challenge level which dissuades getting TOO attached to an adventurer that could easily be wiped out by a few consecutive bad dice rounds. Just like real life and DnD, it's incredibly unfair, which will be a turn-off for some while deeply investing for others.

That said, take heart! For every grievous beating your favorite polygonal champion takes, you'll get to see a deeply cathartic mega-crit on some annoying enemy which sends them ragdolling into the distance.

This is my first time commenting on a game, and I have to say, this game has been a blast for me and my friends!
It has a D&D feel to it, yet as a 3-player platform, each round moves so smoothly. 
When it comes to their lore/stories, they have so much variations to choose from. 
Along with completing objectives, and encountering adversaries, I find that this is what keeps the game more engaging. 

By far the most entertaining aspects of the game is how each character specializes in a important role to help another, and the adventure you'll have with everyone working together as a team. 
It's also exciting to see what kind of drops we'll be rewarded with, as they can deliver significant boosts and other immunizes. 
But, be sure to never go unprepared for their dungeons cause there will be consequences to deal with.

Overall, I had a lot of fun with this experience and became addicted to play more.  

P.S. ~ I like to express my gratitude to Qurureco, who recommended this fantastic game to me!

This game has some pretty serious rng issues, and i can't recommend it until they do some balancing changes. I've spent a long time trying to enjoy this game, i've unlocked over half the lore store, i've tried dozens of builds, i've even played with a full party of experienced tactical gamers, the game is just unbalanced plain and simple.

If they make some changes to how much damage the enemies do, or make their rolls more reasonable (at least make it on par with the players rolls) it would fix the majority of the issues with the game. The focus is a nice touch, but it's so difficult or expensive to get (in some case making you choose between getting focus back or health) that it can hardly be considered a balancing feature against the near perfect rolls the enemies seem to get every combat. 

Great art style, amazing concept, probably the WORST rng mismatching i've seen since Fire Emblem, or XCOM and i'm pretty sure they had better balancing than this.

tl:dr - CANNOT recommend until they fix their balancing issues, and update their UI to reflect the accurate roll percentages. the features they have in place (focus) do not equalize the difference, and leaves the entire 2-5+ hour run entirely on chance.

Awesome set of mechanics and game modes. Perfect for any table-top RPG fan.  Really fun to play with friends. The campaigns are well written and the dungeon crawl mode is fantastic.

* This is only a review for the single player experience, I can certainly imagine it being a much better game for co-op with friends.

TL;DR  Too much RNG spawning of enemies.  It would be more fun for a single player if it was more roguelite than roguelike.

        I realize the high difficulty of this game is intended and multiple replays are very much expected, but there are some RNG moments that, for a single player trying to make progress, just make the whole game overly frustrating and completely diminish the appeal for replay. 
       The map shows where enemies are, but not really, as they can RNG on any player adjacent tile without warning as an "ambush".   This is a cool difficulty mechanic i guess, but it happens so often early game to parties that can hardly get around the map as it is.  The game is "stifling" for that reason.  After an intense boss battle where all of my party members were depleted from a very narrow and intense victory, a powerful enemy randomly spawned at a tile adjacent to the battle and wiped my whole party instantly.  You have to let players enjoy their victories to some extent, as they are difficult to accomplish as it is.  The random spawning of enemies adjacent to players occurs far too much to expect me to keep at it when it becomes obvious that this happens constantly.  I have had more encounters with unseen RNG ambush enemies than enemies actually visible on the map, and for me that removes a lot of my ability to use the map for strategic movement.  Too much getting beat down by out-of nowhere enemies, not enough mechanics that favor the player and the ability to continue the game.
       The game otherwise is beautiful and inviting, a well crafted visual experience, and it really does have an awesome DnD-like tabletop vibe.  I just wish I could get past the RNG on steroids aspect that can make it super un-fun.  If my characters kept at least some of their progress,  that would definitely raise the appeal for replay.
      Dying is always more fun with friends, pretty much across the board on most games, so I imagine people co-opping will have a much better experience.  If you plan to get this game to play yourself,  I can't recommend it.

There are a great number of digital board games on Steam these days. These games are often competitive in nature forcing players to actively work against their fiends to determine a winner. For The King is a pleasant divergence from the competitive formula. While the game can be played solo I much preferred it with friends.

There's not a lot going on under the hood of this one, and it has a few elements/inclusions that really only serve to aggravate once the novelty's worn off, but it accomplishes the feat of being a relaxing RPG.  

Better with friends, much better with beer.

For The King is cRPG rouge-like, inspired by hexcrawlers and OSR, brilliantly capturing the feel of those mechanics. Don't come to it looking for a story, but if you enjoy TTRPGs like Forbidden Lands and other OSR, this is for you. Discover secrets, defeat your foes, get good gear, and then die anyways after a string of bad rolls. That may sound like a condemnation, but half the fun of this game is how brutal it is. The RNG giveth and the RNG taketh away
This is a game that many refer to as “a hidden gem”
Years on receiving updates and still one of the best co-op games about

If you are a fan of board games and rogue-likes than this is the perfect game for you. It has its pros and cons which some of the cons are just bad game design when it comes to how fast enemies scale and the tank and healing system in my opinion is just bad but the game itself is a lot of fun. The enemy design is fantastic and the game can be a lot of fun with your friends or even just by yourself. It is an RNG based game which can be manipulated in your favor so don't let the negative reviews of people complaining about RNG in an RNG based game steer you away. The game is worth the asking price and if you can get passed the dumb tank mechanics and healing mechanics then everything else is gravy!
tis good

For the King fits neatly into the "computerized tabletop game" realm. I don't know if I would particularly enjoy it as a tabletop game, though. I want more heft from my tabletop experiences than what I allow video games to get away with. Since my bar is a bit lower in that way for video games, For the King works for me, but only just.

I like the roguelike elements. They provide a reason to return to the puzzle. I like the classes and other design elements, though after my first 8-hour encounter I could tell that I was starting to want more variety.

In short, For the King is a delightful little number that might best be enjoyed in co-op play with friends. It's definitely worth the sale price I bought it for, at any rate.

I have played many, MANY turn-based RPGs over the years, most notably the Final Fantasy series, and after a certain point, the entire genre gets stale and boring. For the King has found a way to revive the fun I used to have with them back in the day and it's always a joy to play it. All of the maps always have some level of randomly generated tiles, monsters, traps and loot in them to keep it from getting stale, which is one of the reasons I like it so much. Despite being an indie game, they have also managed to keep the balance very well. I feel like if I failed a run or a fight that it was my fault and not the game's. Of course, again, there are some RNG elements in the game that can definitely make it harder sometimes and feel like it's not always your fault, but I think that brings in another layer of fun.

It's also amazing to be able to play with you friends. As I am getting older, I find it harder to focus on singleplayer games and continue with them, so even a genre like this I always enjoy being able to bring my friends in with me and it makes it even more fun. Not having to control all three characters allows me a little downtime and to relax while I play. Making fun of each other when we roll bad, or getting hyped up when we roll crits is way more fun than when you are by yourself.

The cosmetic rewards in-game and all of them being free is also very nice. I'm generally pretty sick of every single game these days charging money in a cash shop for cosmetics, but going the classic route of unlocking through achievements and/or in-game currency is the most fair and fun way to go about it, so it's nice they went that route. 

Overall, the game is a solid 9/10., I think the only really negative things I can say about the game are that it does have RNG elements, and while I enjoy them a lot, I can understand why some people dislike that kind of thing. And of course, it does have very blocky/indie graphics. It feels more like a stylized choice than anything bad, and I enjoy them, but again, I can easily see how some people might not. If a few layers of light RNG and some polygonal graphics isn't a negative for you, you will probably enjoy the game as much as me.

Overall, I would say this is a pretty good game if you have friends to play this with. I would never [i]personally[/i] play this game by myself or with randoms, but find this game to be an enjoyable experience. To get a better idea of this game, think of D&D if it were laid out on an actual board for you. It works a lot like that in my opinion with options on predefined missions to go on and different modes to play on. 

[h3]My Likes:[/h3]
[list]
[*]Art Style
[*]Animations
[*]Turn Based Combat
[*]Different Modes & Missions
[*]Cool Unlockables for Cosmetics, Items, and Interactions
[/list]

[h3]My Dislikes:[/h3]
[list]
[*]RNG can screw you over (it's to be expected though)
[*]Game does feel a bit unfair at times due to the RNG
[*]Frost Mission is more annoying than fun in my opinion
[*]Boomers (a giant skeleton enemy) are broken and [i]un-fun[/i] to fight
[/list]

For the King can be played by 1-3 players, each of whom can chose their own class and use limited options to customize their characters. This turn-based game uses roll-of-the-dice chance and a player's stats to determine attack and damage, similar to D&D.  There are several stories/modes to play in, house rules one may change, and three levels of difficulty to choose from. While the quests themselves are always the same, no two playthroughs are identical. Given that, unlockables, and the continued updates/added content by the developers, it keeps the game fresh for those who like to play again and again.

It's a great game to spend time with your friends... 

Untill they get bored and leave you with another unfinished co-op game. :(

Extremely poorly balanced game. Don't bother wasting your time on it. The game starts out fun but the difficulty quickly spirals out of control and there's nothing you can do about it. 

You will quickly find that enemies deal way too much damage and inflict status effects that are so devastating and costly to get rid of you will constantly be out of resources, money, and hp.

Oh and the game is also basically a race against the clock so you don't even have time to try and gather resources or try to get a foothold. The game is constantly adding enemy hp multipliers, and even more annoying game state changes on a timer, and you move so slowly you can never keep up.

Everything in the game costs tons of money - even resting becomes insanely expensive - it's stupid. For example, midgame a single herb costs 160g and you'll need about 3 per fight and at the end of the fight, you only get like 65-100g... And if you want to rest you'll need a super rare item that costs a ton of money just to camp, or spend 85g per person to rest in a town, plus you'll need even more money per person to get rid of all the permanent curses or poison that will keep ticking long after a fight is over.

Then there's enemies that will literally steal all your gold and run away, and there's nothing you can do to stop it...

There's enemies that spit acid that destroys your items permanently and there's nothing you can do to block it, just hope you still have a super expensive, limited supply herb to fix it.

Monsters deal way more damage than you, have higher resists and more hp... There's literally nothing you can do. 

Everything that happens in this game is extremely frustrating and unfun. As-is, the game is complete garbage - I would not recommend buying it unless you just like being miserable.

I've changed my class now and approach everything differently, which opens new opportunities and adventures.
We've just discovered the impact of passive abilities on our battles. Again, the combinations are endless. 
Also, the steam achievements have added a new excitement...seeing a statement that we accomplished a unique feat that only 6.9% have achieved made my daughter very proud.
We grabbed the latest DLC yesterday and are armed and dangerous!

For the King is an interesting spin on D&D-style adventures. The monsters and classes were based on the classics, but with modifications to their appearance/abilities. The graphics look amazing and I'm in love with their art style.

Unlike D&D though, the game doesn't have a great story. I don't even remember what the main goal is even though I played through the start many times. Instead of relying on its story, For the King bets on its mechanics being strong enough to carry your interest.

It has great mechanics and its loop feels great. It's a roguelike wherein you take a group of characters out into the game world and fight your way through story beats or just explore around until a misstep or RNG introduces the group to the grim reaper. This is important: **** the game is heavily dependent on randomly generated content***

The world map changes on each try, attacks depend on random dice rolls, so do saving throws, surprise encounters placement in the map are random (and I feel like so are their difficulty), resources placement in the map are random, item drops are obviously random, etc. Everything depends on RNG. So, you gotta be able to be like Elsa and let it go when the game seems to punish you for no particular reason. For example, frightening all of your characters at once because they all failed a saving throw even. This basically forced me sit back and watch my characters get pummelled without being able to do anything. You can build up some stats against some of those things, but I found more efficient to just amass items that grant immunity. The problem with that strategy is that the RNG sometimes will give you none, so you're sh*t out of luck there. To be fair, the fright thing happened once and in general the game has been fair to me. I feel like my efforts to get further have been rewarded well.

You amass some points for completing events/encounters and these points can be used to unlock more characters, chance encounters, chance items, resource spawns, etc. These ease the blows from RNG and basically make you feel like you gain something with each try. That is basically what keeps me playing. I do worry that I may lose interest once I've unlocked everything there is to unlock though. But, I think that won't happen for many more hours to come. So, overall great re-playability from For the King and I feel like it is well worth the asking price.

Reminds me of D&D without the Dungeon Master. I like the artwork and the animations. The randomness of the dice is both frustrating and fun, it resembles the rpg pen & paper experience. I have managed to flourish in the game and then completely die in two rounds, because I failed my rolls and the opponents nailed them. It happens.

The game is relatively boring if the player plays it alone, for controlling three characters at the same time is a really tiring job. Comparing to it, playing with other guys provides a better game experience. Three players could chat and mock each other's bad luck while playing.

To ensure I'm not just some scrub complaining about being bad go and read all of the positive reviews that talk about how much fun they had initially and then it just ended up becoming completely broken.

A lot of the negative reviews here talk about the RNG, which I didn't find to be much of an issue. If you take risks conservatively, are frugal with resources, are mindful of the game clock, the risk of RNG-wipe is comparable to similar games. 

So that didn't bother me. Instead, I found the game dull and a bit tedious. For being an RPG, there's not much going on. There's no skills to upgrade, and the loot system is pretty constrained. (In the first biome, you can find boots +1, in the second biome, you can find boots +2, etc). For being a roguelike, runs don't vary much. Each restart feels pretty similar, except that now you're a bit more efficient. 

This is compounded by it being a pretty slow-paced game. With little randomization in events, world-generation, items, or characters, there isn't really any sweetness to the grind. And it makes the game feels more like a puzzle-solving game than an RPG roguelike. 

I did appreciate it's whimsically generic setting, puffy graphics, and oddly down-to-earth fantasy role playing. However, in 2021, I feel it really needs some mechanic diversification to make me excited about starting over to see what happens this time and thinking about how I'll adjust my strategy.

The game is enjoyable.... WHEN YOU DO PLAY WITH FRIENDS.

Unfortunately, even if it was enjoyable, I do consider this game a negative point. Don't get me wrong, it is a good game. The battle mechanic, the random chance that makes you sue at times.  Die and repeat. Everything that I laughed and having funs with my friends. 

But, whenever you do play the game and someone is going afk for a while, you will wait that long time until your friend returns. There are nothing to do while waiting. I quite often did my laundry or my chores at home while waiting. But since the campaigns are also quite long, they really feel shallow as you go farther in your current story. Without forgetting that the objectives are repeatitive from one campaign to another. The big difference between those campaign would be more the map mechanics that you do need to differ.

After one full run to complete the game, I really felt my dose for the game. When we managed to play the second campaign, I felt bored to finish it. For me, it's quite some bad repeatitive quests and unfun on a full run. For a Roguelike, the game itself is really a longplay that it could require around a roughly 5-6 hours average. I am no joking. If you die at the end, you lost all those hours you wasted and you restart the game from scratch (with the little benefits you will unlock. But still). Even other Roguelike games aren't that long. That's my big deception.


In the end, the game is good as concept. But due to the long hours of sessions with the repeatitive quests/sidequests, For The King burned me out quickly as for not playing it after 1 or 2 victory games, getting unjoyable on the long run.

This is a hesitant recommendation. 

You'll find this game fun if you're able to keep it casual with friends or just roll with the punches in a single player game. I say "roll with the punches" because 99% of this game is based on random chance - attacking, critical hits, casting spells, discovering/getting rewards from random encounters, almost everything is based on a dice roll. The only things that aren't are a select few spells scattered around, one such being the "party heal" skill which is a life saver much of the time.

Enemies have a much easier time with their rolls. They share the same attack system of rolling a dice several times to determine effectiveness, but where your mage might need to roll a perfect 5 action roll to set a single person on fire, the enemy kobold can fail an action in his 3 action roll and still light your entire party on fire. I mention mage specifically because even if you fail much of your roll trying to damage the enemy with a sword or bow or basic magic damage, the enemy still takes minimal damage. On the flip-side however, if you fail even a single action roll while trying to cast a buff/debuff spell, the spell fizzles and does absolutely nothing.

There is a Focus system that you can use to guarantee successful dice rolls (e.g use 1 point of focus to guarantee 1 roll), but it's incredibly limited and with many of the in-game missions being on a time limit, you're scarcely able to properly refill your Focus bar before any big fight without wasting time or items, making the game harder as a result.

The game is very sided towards losing; which isn't necessarily a bad thing, but it's sure as hell frustrating to lose because not one of your heroes succeeded at more than one action over the course of 4 turns. If it took even one less action roll to do more powerful abilities I might like this game a lot more, as it's an incredible turn off to find a powerful spell or ability and have to succeed at *six* rolls just to be able to see its effect - all this on a character that was designed to use the spell or ability to begin with (and therefore has an easier time casting it).

It's easier to ignore just how unfair this game is at times when you've got a friend or two to play with, but solo when you've only got yourself and the teasing dice rolls can be grating.

For someone like me who can't resist the urge to nerd out and micro-analyze every aspect of something until I understand it, trying to get this game down to a consistent science for each playthrough like other games is a pointless task. With everything being rng it's hard for me to find any fun beyond a certain point or to get much farther than I have any previous run. The only thing that you can do is *hope* that you get better roles and better items/encounters along your journey (which you can unlock more beneficial ones via playing but these are again, randomly generated).


TL;DR: I wish it were a touch easier. Fun with friends.

For the King is a great tabletop rogue-like adventure game. It supports up to 3 players but you can also play solo and control 3 characters. The game a has a lot of replayability with there because different campaigns you can run and different team comps you can build. 

Story-wise there isn't much. Like it introduces one and it's there, but it's there's not much to it and it's uninteresting. At least I felt that way. I honestly can't even remember what the main campaign was about. 

This game is entirely based on RNG and that's a huge turn off for some people. Most of the negative reviews are because this is the way the game is structured. If you like trying to maximize your RNG chances or succeeding a 20% chance roll then I highly recommend this game. If you don't like the concept of RNG controlling everything then maybe stay away. Even if you aren't too good at the game there's a lot of game rule modifiers that make the game a lot easier. 

I have yet to encounter any bugs in this game except the ones that attack you. 

I think my main complaint for this game would be that, generally, you need to follow a balanced team comp of: healer, damage, and tank, to actually win. There's different comps you can try and still beat the game with but on the harder difficulties something like a full damage team won't work.

To explain: Scourges are deities that can pop up in your campaign, and they mess you up some how.
Fergus is a lepracon that has a random chance of stealing your drops.
Normally in my experience, they are at the level you are or around there when they are in effect.
I was barely at level 4 in my party and level 8 Fergus pops up.

What makes it worse, is Fergus has MULTIPLE advantages that can render him impossible to beat under bad circumstances
- You need literally perfect roles, or they are guarenteed to miss
- He has a really high chance of stealing your stuff, and immediately running
And when he runs, you need to fight him again with him back at full health.

I'm going to have to restart this run because no way am I putting up with my loot getting taken at random with no way for me to fight back. Even when I managed to take down half his health, he would without fail steal something, run, and make me fight him at full health again.

This game has a bad problem with some situations feeling rigged, that you can overcome with strategy.
Yeah nah, situations like this I'm just gonna call "Overwhelming odds to the point that the game is cheating." Like seriously, giving me a level 8 boss when we JUST got to level 4?

God this game is frustrating. I'm still playing it, but if you plan on buying this, be prepared for a lot of rigged situations.

Seriously unpolished with a lot of frustrating balancing issues.

You fail rolls a lot as a character, and yet enemies nearly never ever fail them. While some challenge is in order, PERFECT ROLLS grant additional damage or status effects. These enemies get this almost guaranteed which doesn't seem to have been taken into account.

Also some poorly thought out enemy types. Like an early game one that does about half a healthbar of magic damage, can only be hit by a perfect roll, and inflicts shock. Shock makes it impossible to get perfect rolls. Also makes it impossible to run away.

For The King is an strategy turn based rpg where you and two other friends fight your way to through monsters on the map by taking turns to move in order to reach certain objectives and ultimately stop the evil chaos from flowing into the land. Extra content like new weapons and classes is unlocked through a shop in the main menu of the game called "the lore store". You can obtain lore by completing dungeons in different game modes. The game play is addictive that can bring you hours of fun with your friends. But sometimes it can get annoying waiting for your friends to end their turn especially when your next turn is going to relatively simple and quick.

Final Score: 7.8/10 wait for a sale.

So this game has me on the fence, pretty majorly. On one end, it's a pretty good game. On the other end, it's an RNG nightmare that almost constitutes as a cop out to play longer. As with most of my reviews, this is going to be a long read, but I make sure people understand what they're buying before getting it. 

[h1] THE GOOD [/h1][list]
[*] There are a LOT of different classes and different builds, including the Hobo, which can basically be any class but doesn't get any kind of special bonus. 
[*] The cell shading art is pretty good, but it's nothing to write home about. I am very impressed that each piece of equipment actually does change the design of your character, which is nice.
[*] It is very much so a Rogue-like, and death is basically guaranteed.
[*] Multiplayer is always fun. [/list] 

Unfortunately, this is where the cool things about this game ends. 

[h1] THE BAD [/h1][list]
[*] 99% of the things in this game is RNG based, except for the mobs who will almost always hit you, get buffs off, or debuff you. 
[*] The RNG is to the point where it's extremely frustrating. I can understand RNG on getting attacks or doing whatever, but does everything have to be rolled individually? Why can't it just be a flat percentage based on the requisite stat? Having up to 5 "Tokens" that are individually rolled to see if you even do anything is a bit absurd. It would be much better if if were just ONE roll based on the requisite stat that determines how effective your action is. Look, I've played some HARD games, ok? I've conquered all the Dark Souls games, all the Castlevania games, and survived games that are brutally challenging, but this seems difficult in a way where the player can't really adapt for. Your survival isn't based on tactics, it's based on 100% dumb luck, which takes all kinds of control from the player. 
[*] Some of the mobs aren't even fair, and some of their mechanics are broken. The "Evasive" property found on certain mobs is completely unfair when 9/10 of the mobs disable your characters, and the Lightning debuff is horrendous. Basically, it auto-fails one token, which doesn't sound so bad until you're faced with mobs that have the evasive property and now you're effectively stuck in a never-ending loop until you die, because there's basically no way to beat it. 
[*] I've had this game for like a year or so now? And I can only stomach the 35-36 hours I have on record. It's just that frustrating. Want your tank (Blacksmith) to tank? Roll twice on a rare stat and if you fail them, you wasted your turn. Want your damage class to do something? Roll 4-5 times, and if you fail one roll (Which is very likely), you'll do basically no damage. Want your Support class to buff? Roll 3-4 times, and if any of them fail, the entire thing fails and you wasted your turn. [/list]

[h1] TL;DR / CONCLUSION [/h1]

I really want to like this game. I love rogue-like games and I am a fan of challenging games, but not to where the challenge places the challenge to actually play completely out of your control. There is very minimal RNG reduction and I just can't be bothered to continue this. Take from this what you will, but I can't recommend. If you want a challenging rogue-like that isn't completely shaming you for playing, try Hades, Slay the Spire, One Step from Eden, or Darkest Dungeon. Those are very challenging and yet feel like the power of having control is up to your decisions and your ability as a player instead of total luck.

I have been a "hardcore mode" and rougelike fanatic for over a decade, and have thousands of hours logged across dozens of titles. I've lost many, MANY runs and had characters die on which I had spent weeks of my life. I say all this to give you some perspective, so you don't think I'm just "mad because I'm bad".
This title has so much potential, but as it is now the game has several mechanics which are frustrating, un-fun and in my opinion, inherently incompatible with each other and the genre as a whole. 

Point #1: A single run in this game is Loooooong. Of my 18hrs. of playtime, more than 14 was spent on a single campaign from beginning to final boss. Not only that, but much of your time is spent clicking around the overworld trying to scrape together enough gold to buy gear and supplies for the next boss dungeon. (Grinding)

Point #2: The turn based combat has very little depth or strategy. There are two types of damage in the game, Physical and Magic. Some enemies are resistant to physical, some magical. 90% of your turns are going to be doing the same middling attack with the highest accuracy rating against the weakest enemy. "But wait!" you might exclaim,"What about the 50 status ailments, buffs and debuffs in the game? Surely they provide some spice and variety? Surely you would want to cast other spells and use other abilities?"
To which I would reply, "Nope." and in Point #3 I will tell you why.

Point #3: Risk aversion & Action economy are the two biggest forces that will drive your decisions in game, and you will constantly be forced to skip events or play it safe in combat because [i]the penalty for whiffing a roll is way too high[/i]. I learned this lesson the hard way a few hours into my very first run. I saved up enough gold to buy a nice boat, set sail and happened upon a "Nice fishing spot". I made the mistake of accepting a random roll with unknown outcomes and next thing I know, the Kraken had destroyed my boat and shipwrecked my entire party. I ended up out 200 gold, wasting 5 turns, and a permanent -1 to all stats for each hero. I don't know what the positive outcomes were, but if it was in line with other events I probably would have found a free item of medium-low value. Many other events are similarly not worth the risk.
Likewise in combat, as I mentioned earlier, every single special effect, debuff or buff [i]without exception[/i] requires a perfect roll to take effect. It has proven to never be worth attempting these abilities, because when you fail, your entire turn is wasted. It is also usually never worth it to switch weapons because that eats an entire turn as well. Staying in combat for as few rounds as possible and minimizing damage is key to survival as the devs did not see fit to include combat healing magic. Every point of HP you need to heal will cost you consumables or gold.

What it feels like: Picture this scenario - You're 8 hours into the run, just sailed across the ocean in high spirits after beating the area's boss. You pick up a bounty from the next capital city and head off into the wilds to fight some monsters. You spend a couple of hours slaying overworld mobs and mini-dungeons until you can finally afford that upgraded wand and boots in town. Now that you are ready you head down to the next boss dungeon. On floor three you get crit twice, everyone is on fire and one person is petrified. One failed armor buff roll and a failed taunt roll later, everyone goes down, run over. Guess you should have spent another hour grinding to buy some more consumables.

Final thoughts: No one wants to devote this much time to a roguelike run. No one wants to lose a run to events they felt were beyond their control. I personally don't want to play a game where you never get to make real and impactful decisions, you just roll the dice and hope for the best. With a little reworking this game could be great, but as it stands now it is not worth buying.

For The King (FTK) definitely scratches that turn-based DnD RPG itch with your merry band of heroes taking on a growing evil in the land of Fahrul. The overall aesthetic and visual design is charming enough, the rough polygons mould a world that jumps right out of a storybook page.

My one gripe is the game's core reliance on RNG. I understand that the idea of your fate being influenced by chance and circumstance is integral to DnD and, broadly speaking, a "hero's adventure". But it can get substantially frustrating when you fail an almost guaranteed attack roll 3 times in a row, which then results in a party wipe. Even more so when you're taking on the final boss during a Master-difficulty run.

Of course, FTK does provide mechanics that help mitigate the ire of our RNG gods. For instance, the Focus system provides a guaranteed success roll per Focus point used. This goes a long way to preventing that Critical Fail at an unfortunate time. Additionally, your equipment and consumables all provide stats that influence your roll chance. However, there's always a chance of failure no matter what.

In short, if you can stomach the inherent RNG-nature of FTK. Then you'll find the rest of the game undoubtedly enjoyable.

It's a good game to be honest. It has a good animation, lore, and quite fun for the first few hours of game play. One of my concerns of this game is the game mechanics where everything is just decided by "chance". The amount of damage you deal is by "chance" then followed by if it actually hits the enemy which also by "chance" (i.e. dodge, block, or hit). Then there also unexpected events that is also by "chance" which will reward you or disappoint you by "chance". Basically, if you're into games that depends on "chances" this will be the game for you, but if you're like me, who is not a fan of Gameplay-is-decided-by-chance game, well you should probably look for something else.

At first it's alright, it's fun to play and quite enjoyable. But when you make your way into the mid game, the flow of the game will entirely be by "chance" which, personally, I find a really really REALLY disappointing.

Note: I tried asking for refund but I already played more than 2 hours :(... That's what I get for giving this game a "chance" to prove itself to be fun when I entered the mid game to end game...

This is the most frustrating game I have ever played.

I really want to like it. Cutsey, party, turnbased gameplay is 100% my jam. 
But the $&%^#$& randomness for everything will drive you insane.
The 25 hours of playtime I have is over multiple years because I unistall this game for six months, come back, enjoy it for a couple of hours then rage quit and uninstall it for another six months.

Now, I'm not one to say the RNG isn't correct with the percentages, I have absolute faith that that 68% happens 68% of the time because the law of large numbers will absolutely apply.

EVERYTHING is random. Oh you want to swing your sword... random x 5! Oh you want to do a stat challenge, Random x 3. Oh, you want to freaking MOVE random x 6. 

So basically when literally everything is based on chance at some point it will bone you. You have focus that you can use to lessen your luck but guess what... you get 4 focus points and every swing of your weapon is 2-4 rolls. So good luck.

And yeah, I guess I could spend the time to figure out all the methods to try and minimize your luck but at the end of the day if I wanted something this random I'll go play monopoly.

Honestly, this is a must-buy for anyone who enjoys party-based RPGs. The amount of build customization is insane, and the rogue-lite nature gives it near-infinite replayability.

Story:
The story of this game is pretty average, but it fulfills its purpose. There's evil in the world, and it grows stronger if you ignore it. Follow the main quest to uncover its lairs and progress towards the source. 

Combat:
The combat is designed around a party of 3 characters, though you can play with fewer if you really want to ramp the difficulty. Turn-based, where the turn initiative is based on your speed stat, but you can use various weapon abilities to slow down enemies or speed up allies. The damage feels good, and the ragdoll on defeated enemies feels satisfying.

Sound design:
Hits feel satisfying, the Minstrel/Busker attacks being guitar/lute riffs are a nice touch, and the background music is calm and enjoyable.

Graphics:
It's a low-poly style, but everything feels unique. They manage to get details across with simple (but well-made) models rather than high-resolution textures. Lighting is atmospheric, and everything is interesting to look at.

Unlocks:
The game will pay out Lore Books that will allow you to unlock game content from the main menu. These can only be used on playthroughs after you have unlocked them (as far as I know). Everything from weird weapons and armor to new and unique map tiles can be purchased with this token-like currency. There are even a few classes to be had this way. Worry not, however, as you can get Lore Books by simply playing through a game normally, or even using one of the non-story gamemodes that have a higher payout percentage.

Difficulty:
Honestly, the difficulties are actually pretty nice. Apprentice, the lowest tier, is good for you first *several* playthroughs. The Journeyman difficulty is definitely challenging (at least for me). I haven't tried any higher, though I'm positive the 3rd difficulty level is absolutely insane. Additionally, you can set up House Rules for things like Chaos frequency (how often the game tries to corrupt the world), starting Lives (you normally start with 6, 2 for each character), or Economy Inflation (how much more expensive things get as you progress). These do affect your Lore Book payout, but the minimum is still 50% of the regular gameplay on Journeyman, so it's not like you can't progress at all on super-duper easy mode.

Let me start by saying this ths is simply my personal opinion and therefore it should hopefully be taken with a grain of salt.

Pros:
The game has an insane amount of replayability as it slips right between the cracks of being a rogue-lite and a rogue-like. What this means is that pretty much everything in the game is procedually generated and your progress is reset whenever you get a game over, be that by beating the game or losing.
The only reason why I consider a TINY part of the game to be a rogue-lite is due to certain upgrades, such as statues and shrines.
Another great thing about this game is the focus system. Every character have a resource called focus that can be spent on certain things. Some of these things can be gaining more movement spaces or automatically suceeding rolls, thus removing part of the RNG while still retaining certain aspects of it.
Speaking of rolls, the majority of things that happens in the game are determined by dice rolls, similarly to TTRPGs (Table Top Role Playing Games) and as such the game lets you somewhat manipulate the odds.
Spending focus is a way to suceed MOST rolls automatically but the resource is not something that recovers naturally. Another way to increase odds which is really common is by boosting a characters stats.
If you boost vitality for example, your odds of succeeding when attempting to taunt will increase IN ADDITION to increasing max health. All but one stat have these effects.
The difficulty is largely tied to how long you take in the game, like the Risk of Rain games. You see, this game can get more challenging the longer you take but spending more time lets you get stronger. Also the difficulty of the game is highly customizable.
There are way more great things about the game I won't mention here but if i can only name one more, then it has to be the fun you can have with friends. The game is kind of like Mario Party as it can both make and break friendships.

Cons:
The game has a fairly small playerbase and therefore your best shot to find online lobbies is by using the games discord server.
There is one stat that doesn't quite make sense to me and that is luck. It doesn't increase any stats, not even luck or dodge and its only uses are accuracy for very specific weapons and also certain random events/encounters that are far and few between.
Equipment matters WAY more than levels or anything else really when it comes to making your characters stronger but this is just a personal dislike.
The "endless" gamemode ( called Hildebrants Cellar) is probably the one thing that doesn't feel randomly generated. Atleast when compared to the rest of the gamemodes.

Conclusion:
The game can be really fun if you play it with friends and it's still a really solid game if you play alone.
RNG matters a LOT but can be easily manipulated.
There is nearly endless replayabillity and playstyles.
One more thing I didn't mention before as it is a neutral opinion is that you can easily sink a long time into this game as the campaigns are randomly generated each playthrough. This also means that if you don't have a lot of free time, then this game might not be the game for you.
And lastly, focus is an amazing mechanics while LUCK IS STUPID.

Waifu Secret 2 is more of the same from its original counterpart, offering lewd stories broken up in segments in between pipe-connecting minigames. You play the role of an author looking for story ideas when you're approached by someone who offers you details about people you know and people she knows until you inevitably have sex with her as well.

The dialogue isn't flawless and there's definitely a bit of cryptic guess work trying to figure out what some lines actually mean, but it's definitely serviceable. The visuals, while still decent, feel like they're an overall downgrade from the first game. At times the animations come across as lazy, such as moments where a character will be spread open before penetration begins. There is occasional voice acting, which is nice to see, but nothing that overly stands out in the game.

There are some minor technical issues as of the moment of this review, one of which includes missing pipes that makes certain levels impossible to conventionally complete. The developer has stated that these will be addressed shortly. Fortunately, pressing the F key seems to instantly complete a level. What makes this even nicer is that achievements and progress are not tied to your ability to earn 3 stars on each level, merely that you are able to complete that level. What this means is that if you want to skip the puzzles and get to the story/lewd bits, you have the full capability to do so.

Ultimately, I think that if you played Waifu Secret 1, you've already experienced the full range of what the sequel game has to offer. I had hoped there would be more of an expansion on the gimmick, but gameplay really doesn't seem to be at the forefront of their attention. I understand it's a lewd game and so you want to show people lewds, but you're also selling a video game.

If you're going to buy the game, get it at 50% off if possible. Two dollars is a decent price but I stand by my belief that playing the first game amounts to the same experience as the second, and so it's kind of redundant and feels like you're just buying the same game twice. I actually found the first game to be much more enjoyable and had a better range of characters. This honestly feels like it could have been DLC for the first game and done better-- but it is what it is. You know if you'll like it or not.

I enjoy this game enough that I bought it on both Switch and Steam. It's a great, chill game to play with a friend or two, and the rogue-like nature helps prevent you from ever getting too attached or taking it too seriously, as you will likely need to restart a few times before you finally survive. It can be a little frustrating that it sometimes comes down to dumb luck, and the runs take long enough that an unlucky death near the end can sting worse than other rogue-likes that have shorter runs. However, the feeling is adventurous, and there are plenty of surprises, along with many campaigns, many character classes, and many ways to switch it up and have it feel fresh. The overworld hex crawl and the multi-room dungeons along with side quest options and turn based combat replicate a fun, simplified version of playing Dungeons & Dragons.

Well, over the past 2 weeks of owning the game, between Steam and Console, I've easily put 80 hours into it.  If you like turn based strategy games at all, you'll probably like this.  I'm not even personally a massive fan of the genre, but this one is put together well and has vast replay-ability.

My only critique might be that enemies probably have too good of RNG on rolls, especially when they can get added effects from their attacks with out getting perfect rolls, where as players generally have to get perfect rolls to do things like bleed, stun, slow, etc.

I really wish they hadn't discarded their plans to make the game mod-friendly.  This game could suck up so much more of my time with custom campaigns/chars/items/events/etc.

It is like a classic DND but at PC.  It generates unique world each time you run it, Balance is almost ideal. 
It does not try to surprise you with high level graphic, but what it does shifts initial expectations - real physic in turn based battles, thousands different looks of the heroes and the enemies. 

The only thing I do not like is how co-op game immediately ends when one player disconnects. Would be good to have an option to replace him/her with  another person or with a bot or even decide to continue without him. It is pity when you game progress lost because a guy in 1000 km from you lost his connection.

In general, being a game developer myself I can say it is one of the best games I ever saw.
I never wrote game reviews before, but I feel I must do it for this game.

Me and my 2 friends have tried the normal campaign and enjoyed it enough to try one of the other campaigns, Frost Adventure. We were extremely disappointed with how similar, even stripped down, it felt to the normal campaign. It had less features compared to the original and there weren't enough quests to do, we had to just grind without much aim which is exactly where the game falls off significantly. When we saw that the next campaign in line, Into the Deep, also had a somewhat similar structure, we decided to drop the game.

The characters don't even bring enough differences to the table, playing all characters feel more or less the same and most passives trigger so rarely that you don't even feel its effects (Justice, Inspire etc.) but especially one of them is extremely dominating, Party Heal. Playing a support character felt quite frustrating too, due to needing perfect rolls everytime to contribute something meaningul to the party. I found Talent stat in general to be extremely lacking as well, not impacting the game enough compared to Awareness or Speed.

Overall, this is a game plagued with many design flaws and a gameplay that can rapidly bore the players with no meaningful way of differentiation between runs and close to none replay value. I would advise against purchasing it if you are expecting a long lasting experience.

For The King holds a special place in my heart, it is not my most played game but most certainly my favourite one available on Steam.

It incorporates a bit of everything I enjoy! Simple yet very detailed visuals, cute in its own way! RPG and Roguelike elements that are not overwhelmingly difficult to understand yet challenging and enjoyable! A multitude of weapons and a wide array of obtainable loot! A turn based combat system allowing you to pause at virtually any time! Multiple gamemodes with local and online coop support!

It does include an RNG system and some dice rolls might seem unfair at first, but the odds of getting a successful roll can be upgraded, with enough preparation, the right gear and some strategy you can almost guarantee a successful fight. Sometimes a strategic error or a bad roll can be very punishing but this game is about adapting and making the best out of a bad situation! 

This game is not easy but it was never meant to be which is good because it makes achieving victory a lot more satisfying compared to other games where stats are just numbers you can overlook and abilities don't matter. This game is however not overly difficult either once you start learning about abilities, skills, stats, buffs and debuffs!

[b] For The King forces you to think ahead, anticipate the enemies next moves and adapt to the situation at any moment! Victory is not the goal, the journey is, victory is just the reward! [/b]

It's ok. It's a board game style rpg, so you can build a character or get better gear but at the end of the day an invisible dice seals your fate. The game warns you at the front not to expect to beat it right away and you might think it means the game is challenging but in reality the game has absurd spikes in difficulty that make it borderline unfair. The prices of items raise with your level so a simple healing item that cost nothing in the beginning of the game can cost right at 200 gold around rank 10. Not only that but the enemies especially in the later game are keyboard smashing levels of frustrating. A simple undead will be the same level as you yet do as much damage as your strongest fighter with just a swipe, some enemies get multiple moves before you without any explanation, the aforementioned chance aspect will result in a lot of combat encounters that you just go "huh?". I made sure to do enough runs to get a good feel for it, made it to the final boss for the first campaign before he pulled out a move that one hit my entire team, but the fact the game doesn't really commit to the board game or the rpg aspect fully just kinda leaves it somewhere in the middle in terms of quality.

Having a few issues with the game at Adventurer mode (simplest difficulty) :
1) With all party characters/enemies at level 10, enemies move close to 1.5x-2x as fast as my characters, and therefore have plenty of opportunities to buff themselves/debuff my party while maintaining their attack rate; 
2) While my mage had a wand that allowed her to use one healing herb to heal all 3 members at a go (thereby saving two additional herbs which would be needed otherwise), the herb supply (and gold required to purchase them, or to rest at the inn) is unable to keep up with the healing that I need to do after each battle.
3) Enemy damage output can easily take off 20% of HP after accounting for armor. Coupled with point #1, this is a heavy disadvantage to the party.
4) Level 10 enemies do not tend to miss often, and have very high armor ratings of about 30 which almost negates any damage that I can deal to them.
Mixed reviews btw!

I've come back after 17 hours of play to rewrite this review. I still love the game, and there are no doubt problems that make it a less-than ideal experience. However, I do think that this game is a worthy purchase (but only if its on sale.) The main story is a rather linear, yet enjoyable experience. The story itself doesn't change from playthrough to playthrough, but the way you go about it does. A lot of the game's core enemies you'll be fighting are randomized, meaning that difficulty curves can often be steep. Additionally, without knowing what you're doing, you will be wiped in a matter of seconds.

Pros:
-Fun gameplay
-Robust Customization options
-Extreme Replay Value
-Surprisingly Deep and Strategic

Cons:
-Sometimes, RNG will just screw you over
-Enemy leveling can be downright unfair at times
-Without prior knowledge or research, you will have a hard time

All in all, I sunk in more hours into this game than I thought I would, whether I'm playing it, researching stuff about it, or watching others play it. It's one of those games that has a surprising amount of depth to it. However, in order to appreciate the amount of depth it has, you'll have to sink in some hours to get a grasp on how the game is played.

Would I recommend this for beginners to the RPG genre? Not really, no.

Would I recommend this to people (like myself) that enjoy games that are extremely challenging? (Such as Darkest Dungeon/Binding of Isaac/Sekiro)

For the King has been a game I have come back too time and time again for a number of years. I have seen it develop into such an amazing game with a huge fan and player following and additional stories, classes and more get added, all around not spoiling or adversely affecting the base game or its other various stories. It is supported by an amazing community of people in the discord that have fun, help each other, create groups and all have the support of the Ironoak Team in the cord for when things occasionally bump. 

At the time of writing this I'm just over 400 hours or more of playing, I've unlocked everything in the Lore Store and slowly getting the final few achievements. But regardless of all of that, its the people and the game itself that keeps me coming back for more. Trying different teams, different approaches to combat, dungeoning and questing.

I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys Turn Based game play, and an adventure they can loose themselves in either solo or with friends. 

Thank you to everyone at Curve, Ironoak and the community in the discord for making this such an amazing game! <3

[h1] For The King [/h1]
For the King is a Rpg Dungeon Exploration game pretty much like DnD just without the GM. The game offer multiple different campaigns to play from giving a whole different experience to enjoy. With each new campaign there is different and new encounters so the experience is always new and different giving you endless replay ability. you can play solo or with two other friends as a party of three to make your experience enjoyable.

[b] Pros [/b]
[list]
    [*]Campaigns always have different encounters 
    [*]A lot of different classes to play from with there unique play-styles
    [*]Just like DnD do not split the party you are better as a group.
    [*]Game is very easy to pick up for a first timer.
    [*]Certain encounter may unlock something permanent for your next play through to.
[/list]
[b] Cons [/b]
[list]
    [*]A lot of things are locked behind shop so you're limited pretty early in the games.
    [*]Game can get really punishing when the whole party wipes then game over there no check points.
    [*]New DLC seem to prove difficulties and need retweaking 
    [*]Gold economy can be hard with friends so do expect some teamwork sharing as limited time shops fly by
[/list]

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
In all this game can ruin friendships as well and make happy moments. This is a game i'd recommend people to play with friends because you can share accomplishment and experience the campaign together to talk about your enjoyments and your dislike with the game. There can be some frustration with the game at the time but that part of the game just gotta be prepared for the next time going into your encounter.

gud gaem

Luck, The Game
Just wanna start off by saying, nothing like failing 6 78% attack rolls across your 3 characters all in a row,  only to not hit the enemy once.
 you must be thinking, wow that enemy must have a lot of evasion stats, or caused some effect that jangled with my accruacy but nope. He had a skill where you can only hit him if its a perfect rolled attack.What a fun thing for the player, great design, just click a button for rng and see if you win or not, not too much skill in the game.
Dont get me wrong, i love a game with stats, i dont mind my weapon doing a variable amount of damage between X-X amount depending on rng, im ok with randomly missing swings because it lists the % chance of that landing. What i find really frustrating about this game is the balance between RNG and trying to play it safe. There is no middle ground when doing a mini game/ challenge on the board. Its either RNG is on your side and you get a item, or some gold and some XP, whoo nice work! Or its not on your side and your whole team gets hurt, or you get minus some XP, or a enemie encounter with just your characters that are close by. There is no, middle ground where nothing happens, thats what makes this so frustrating, if you want a good run, just keep on playing till you get lucky and are able to do all your rolls, hope enemies dont attack first for battles or target your healer, hope the shop is selling a better weapon instead of lower tier ones. Just so much luck in it, i understand its supposed to add a replability factor to the game, ny making every run different, but games have gotten to the point theres so many mechanics and features that are never explained but left up to chance and guessing and learning from death. Oh neat a enemy spat acid on me, Oh it dissovled my only weapon . . . Hey that imp is spamming spells so i should focus him first, oh he has a evade perk that makes it so anything that isnt a PERFECT rolled hit is a miss . . .  Oh you wanted to attack? too bad your in a stun loop with enemies so have fun watching them attack 4 times while you attack once. . . 
 The death in this game, theres no way to make saves, so once your team gets wiped, have fun restarting that whole campaign. . . How come a spell that has a 80% land rate, fails almost every time when i try it on a enemy 1 or two levels higher than me? im guessing because they have higher evade stats but the game dosent show or tell even what those are or do. If you already know everything about table top games like this and get the stats lingo, i can see how its fun, if you have no understanding of any of it, the game dose very little to break down what all the numbers at the bottom of your screen mean.

Wooow, so theres a in game shop to spend tokens to unlock different board pieces and better end game gear, i fucking hate games that put this grindy mechanic in to their games for the sake of "content". A lot of the things you unlock are pretty much needed if you want to beat the game. Your first 5 attempts in the game you will fail no matter what because of this artificial sense of progression. It forces the player to play the game longer in order to beat it, when this stuff should be unlocked from the beginning, like idol statues giving better stats, or being able to encounter random tiles with healers on them, instead of wasting 5 turns getting your 3 players back to a inn to heal. Then theres unlocks that are strictly chance based, They have results that range from getting a free item or some xp, to wiping out your ENTIRE PARTY, causing you to restart the campaign. Why is that even a punishment for a game in a game? theres no middle ground like mentioned earlier, so your are either doing a all rng run and praying to what ever god you believe in, Or playing it safe and dying fast due to horrible rng.

For The King is a great little D&D-style table top adventure.  One of the best things about For The King is that it scratches a lot of itches in one small game - it feels like a proper fantasy RPG with a bit of strategy and a bit of urgency (much like XCOM), but all within a reasonable scale.  And like any indie roguelike, it’s adorable and unforgiving in equal measure.

Movement mechanism is tedious at best.  No idea why you would RNG movement points every turn.  All this does is slow down the game.  Faster characters arrive at destination and have to stand around and wait for the rest of the "party."  How hard to grasp the concept of lightly armored moved faster than heavily armored and then the party moves at the pace of the slowest member?  It's like a bad horror movie.  "Let's split up and go off into the dark woods alone!"
Simple, easy to understand, hard to beat!

It's enjoyable if you play with friends. Strip off your social interaction, and this game leaves much to be desired.

Pros:
1. Straightforward gameplay
2. Sometimes comical

Cons:
1. There's no point collecting weapons from loot or buying from tavern, they can break even from first time use.
2. Huge dependence on luck and dice roll

I've gotten my money's worth out of this. It's a good chill thing to play with friends but not have to spend a ton of mental effort strategizing. It's also a nice casual thing to play by yourself, for those times when you want to play something, but also have other things you need to get done at the same time.

I think the art style lends itself well to playing on lower spec hardware, so it's also great for laptops or portable systems. 

I won't pretend that it's perfect -- since it is just a turn based RPG, the core game loop can get stale after a while. The lore unlock system helps to keep it somewhat fresh, forcing you to try different game modes to unlock all the gear, but there's only so much you can do with ground this well trod.

I'd say get it. For the price, you probably won't be disappointed, and it's an instant recommend if you happen to get it on sale.

So I went back and forth on whether or not I recommend this game.  I really enjoy it.  It's a fun RPG style game and if you have friends that have it, it's a cool way to all play together. 

However....

The story isn't all that great for me.  I've sunk nearly an entire 24 hours into it and I still can't really get past the first big boss no matter how much I grind beforehand or how many things I buy to buff myself.  And that comes down to the luck aspect.  In my last run, things went pretty well for me until I got into the maze and then, despite my 90% accuracy items, my attacks still missed 78% of the time (I was annoyed enough to do the math.)  So it's a fun little game.  Neat concept, I like how it works as a game itself, but the luck function is just too far off for me in my several hours of play for me to recommend others spend money on it.  If it's on sale, get it!  But don't pay full price.

Honestly, it is a great, simple, and well designed RPG with hints of DND mixed in. I've been playing for a while now and still have yet to find my favorite character or favorite build, they are all well done and balanced! The graphics are simple and just about everyone should be able to handle them, the story is straight forward and the UI and Character info at the bottom is INCREDIBLY well done and well thought out. Weather you're doing one player, two play, or three player the quests and adventure can be a ton of laughs and challenges. If you like to min max, you'll like it, if you like to be silly, you'll like it, it has something for everyone and some of my friends who were skeptical at first have come to enjoy it. There is a challenge to it, especially on higher difficulties so don't be discouraged, just try again and maybe the RNG gods will help more the next game!

With one or two friends, this game replicates a good chunk of what makes D&D good. Fun monsters to fight,  unforgiving RNG and cool loot. Because it has rogue-lite elements, different classes can be over, or under-powered in any given quest. Totally recommend, would get absolutely bodied by a lich-king again.

You enter a colorful world with crisp polygonal design and hex-like patterns which invite you to explore, and upon venturing, you discover towns, shrines and enemies...and bubble text from... who? So far so good! After a few battles you begin to realize you don't know who your character is, what's their mission, or how they are tied to the world of Fahrun... or Farras, Ja Rule?? I forgot already. After a dozen-some-odd battles and random map spawns, you might feel like even the game itself does not understand what is going on. With all the unwanted solicitations of NPCs that you never approached you still struggle to understand what the character's objective is. Do you kill the hag that spawned in your path or do you build a boat to sail to the shores of another vaguely uncertain plot? God forbid that you try to have a little fun! Slowly you feel un-invested in your character while wandering aimlessly around Fail-run hoping that you will find an interesting anecdote, a clue, a weapon, ANYTHING to hold your interest. Die, repeat, die repeat, confusing objectives, bass-ackwards controls in a plotless rogue-like game that feels like getting up and going to work at the job you despise. After a couple hours of this, you may find yourself asking if you really want to spend another 20 minutes with NPC bubble text, repeating the same lines, telling you to go nowhere for nothing, you start to think, "nah. I'm good."

This is a long form Roguelike, probably the longest I’ve ever played. Getting a run to the end can take upwards of 8-10 hours on the main campaign, more of less depending on difficulty. It’s a fun game to play with friends, and anyone who enjoys turn-based RPG’s will probably enjoy this. 

It’s basically a much smaller scaled version of Divinity Original Sin, with lots of replayability and other campaigns. However, this game can be brutally difficult if RNG does not work in your favor in terms of finding appropriate loot, and can scale very harshly if you’re unlucky. Despite that, it’s very fun and I thoroughly recommend it.

This is a great game except for two things: 

1. You can only play permadeath.

I don't know who gave game developers the idea that erasing hours of progress made a game more fun, but even if it did, to have permadeath as the only option only amounts to a way to frustrate players who don't like that kind of "challenge."

It's not really a challenge. Nothing should be called a game if it's only an all-or-nothing scenario.

I made it to the final fight and lost in round 2 after hours of traveling that map. Okay, so I should show up with a penalty in some inn, minus some items, perhaps. I should have to work to get tougher, recoup some stuff.

Nope. Gone. Erased. Start over.  F**k you, developers.

Devs: Add an option for a reset to a previous save point (go ahead and institute a penalty if you really feel you just have to hurt the player somehow).

2. When you get into a dungeon fight, you might have an inventory of stuff that could help you, but you can't use any of it once the fight starts. You can only change your weapon. 

Normally, someone might say, "Well, then, plan well before you go in."

Uh huh. Except that to make a plan you have to have some idea of what you're facing, and you often don't. Level one of the big end battle was an ice fight. Level two was a flame fight. Super. I have devices that will not only be useless for half my fights, but they'll weaken my character as well. This means that, just doing the math, it's better not to equip the Immunity to Fire device you earned from previous work, because its aggregate worth is zero. It helps you win one fight and nerfs the armor, resistance, talent you could have had by just equipping your catch-all device. So why bother to use these wonderful, powerful items if, when you need them, you can't get to them?

Developers: Why? Why not just let the player get a backpack item by sacrificing a turn, just like switching a weapon? Why be punks about this. "Oooo, look at that awesome talisman you just picked up. Too bad you have no idea whether or not to equip it when you go into this dungeon. Hahahahaha!" 

The virtues of this game are many, but the flaws are pretty annoying. It's like the game was designed to p*ss you off and pretend that makes for a "challenging" game. Yeah, it's challenging having purposely punk-a** game mechanics kill the fun instead of raise the difficulty.
