Let me start by saying I do like the game, but feel there is not a lot of difference between runs. Hildebrandt cellar runs feel almost always the same regardless of what party you bring and the main stories are short. I would like to see more item variation at the start of the game and some different ways to heal other then the very meta party heal with godsbeard. 

I understand the game should be punishing but at the same time it should be rewarding. The game for me just doesn't seem to reward players enough to balance out the punishing.

Another feature that would be very nice would be to allow people to join into other peoples games. 
For example: You and your friend are playing a run but you leave the 3rd character slot open for people you join in and take control of that character for the rest of the run. The lobby could show what character it is and it's level and it's the choice of the person who hosted the game to have the slot open or locked. I feel it would it would make the game more multiplayer friendly as there is not much of a player base playing online with an open lobby to join.

If you get the game on sale and play for a weekend, then its a good deal. I wouldn't advise paying full price as the game is currently.

Me - "So, what is 'For the King'"?
Friend - "Its the mix between a board game and a classic RPG video game.."
Me - "I see...done, purchased!"
2 seconds.. That's how long it took me to decide to buy this game after hearing an accurate description! I LOVE table top board games AND classic RPGs... this is that - perfectly blended AND CO-OP! 
It really is like playing a board game - and oh my is it fun. Graphics are clean and pretty. Story is 'meh' - whatever though - a board game's story is 'meh' too..if the game play can make up for it who cares? 
I played for 2 hours with 2 other friends and had a blast. Laughs, triumphs, and failures (breaking a brand new bow on a crit fail..RIP..such is a rogue-like). The time went by so quick and I cant wait to hop back in. 
So - with that being said, don't listen to the negative comments like I did for so long while pondering to buy this game. If you got one or two buddies to join up with and go on some adventures that are reminiscent of the ol' FF days, then don't wait - grab a copy and go to it!
only ONE negative comment though - I only wish they made it 4 or 5 player co-op..that would be even BETTER! for the time being, max of three will have to do :/

For the King, on every startup, warns you that you'll probably lose a few times. This is not because it is a hard game, or because it was designed to be a challenge to the player. It's because, ultimately, the player does not decide whether they win or lose.

This is a game where every single thing you do is determined by a dice roll. Fortunately, boosting your stats will make you [strike] more likely to roll successfully [/strike] fail an 89% chance roll 3 times in a row, costing you your entire game and forcing you to start over.

Unlike DnD there is no charm or fun to be had in the rolls. Either you roll well and win or roll poorly and the game punishes you severely for nothing more than being unlucky.

In fact an entire crucial gameplay feature is that you can spend 'focus' to bypass levels of your dice rolls to give you better chances or even guarantee a successful roll, but its at this point the game clearly exposes itself as being a convoluted disguise for gambling, with the only reliable way to avoid gambling every single fight being to stock up on consumable items, which itself is an unfun and contrived way to play any game.

For the King is, sadly, a game where player decisions do not matter. Every last thing you will ever do in the game is at the mercy of the machine and the best of attempts or most solid of strategies can crumble instantly for no fault of your own. Unless of course you begin a monotonous grind to buy more consumables to fill up your focus (which is also even more impractical since there are limited amounts of consumables to be bought), but then you're having even less fun.

Excellent turn-based Roguelite RPG with stellar options for both online and couch co-op in addition to the classic single-player.  Gameplay always feels challenging, but doable.  A variety of character classes and campaigns to choose from, as well as various unlockable content which can show up in your games once "purchased" for lore points (acquired through gameplay only--no microtransactions here!) keep the game interesting even for multiple playthroughs.

After having watched the fine folks of the Yogscast play this game for hours on end, I finally had to purchase it for myself, and I have to say I am not disappointed.  It's even better than I expected.

TL;DR: Excellent turn-based RPG with singleplayer as well as both online and couch-co-op.

Pros:

- Cool aesthetic/art style.
- Turn-based RPG game with some fun abilities and wide range of classes.
- Interesting grid-like exploration.
- Some goofiness.
- House Rules built into the game for more game custimozation.
- Multiplayer so you can die with your friends.
Cons:

- The enemy RNG is ridiculous. I had a very high level team with top-tier gear and near-perfect hit chances and still missed multiple times while the final boss of the standard campaign (on Easy difficulty) never missed an attack and I barely won.
- It's a Rogue-like. Interesting concept, but it's not for everyone. I don't mind it, but I would've preferred this game just be a straight RPG.
- Balancing and scaling is just wonky sometimes, and can be very frustrating, as I'm a player who likes to complete as much stuff as possible to be prepared for an area (that will just go up in level without you realizing it).
- Most game modes make you feel rushed, which isn't great sometimes, in a "tactical" turn-based RPG field.

Overall: 

The game is sadly addicting and I do very much so enjoy it, even with it's quirks. For it's price, it's definitely worth a buy.

The RNG is blatantly unfair. If this is something that will make you whine and pout, go play a different game. The stupid RNG is something that in my eyes adds to the fun of the co-op experience - nothing is more fun than laughing at your friends missing an 89% roll.

Highly recommend for a group to play, partially recommend for solo play.
